reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Dishonored
Original Release: 2012
Genre Tags: Stealth; Atmospheric; First-Person; Dark; RPG; Action
My Overall Grade: A
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 15-40 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Game atmosphere connoisseurs; Strong narrative advocates
REVIEWDishonored is a riveting, immersive, and downright pleasurable experience.  Decent graphics with superb artistic direction and a fitting soundtrack set the ambiance.  There is a captivating world to explore, rife with a subtle-but-present wealth of lore and history.  The gameplay can range from stealthy-pacifist style to murderous-warrior style, or somewhere in between; it is easy to find a playstyle that suits your preferences.  There is much to like.

The atmosphere of the game is really its heart and soul.  The gameworld is masterfully crafted to be immersive and intriguing as you explore your way through the campaign.  Wandering through side passages and windows, you not only find collectibles and items but also notes and books which provide lore and background information.  This supplements the primary storyline and few sidequests that compose the main narrative.  That narrative being enticing and well-told, although not without a few clichés.

The gameplay is structured to offer varying, branching options to choose from as you progress toward your goal.  In each level, there are various paths to take and various ways to take them. You could blow open the front door and slaughter everyone or you can slip through an attic window and never allow your presence to be known.  A lot of games try to offer this, but Dishonored is exceptional in how balanced the gameplay is to truly allow for both stealth and loud options.  It does lean slightly toward stealth, undoubtedly, but you really have a lot of freedom to get creative in how you want to go about each mission.

Another premiere aspect of the game, tying together the atmosphere and gameplay, is the evolving gameworld.  Depending on your methods of completing earlier missions, as you get deeper into the campaign the gameworld changes to reflect how your actions have impacted society.  The effects are ultimately rather subtle, but contribute to further highlight the outstanding atmosphere of the game.

The various styles of play and mission paths combined with achievements and collectibles make for some good replay value and decent playtime.  If you explore and immerse yourself in the lore, the game can be quite substantial; if you bulldoze through the main campaign, the game can be quite short.  Also the DLC can add a decent amount of content, so the GOTY edition is probably a good bet if you are looking to maximize gameplay hours.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText: Dishonored is a true memorable game. It does everything right. You have a diverse arsenal of weapons and powers at your disposal in your story of revenge. As Corvo Attano, you put the mask of an assassin in a city tormented by chaos. Your way of dealing with problems will influence the city, since killing will take chaos to new levels or being a pacifist will get you a happy ending. Level design is well thought, so being the good guy is not impossible but rewarding, while being the bad guy is really fun. The chaotic play style is the one where you'll fully enjoy your ablities and their upgrades, but as you progress that way, things get harder, as the game adapts to you to be challenging. Assassinating your targets is fun, but handlling things peacefully is actually more attractive, as you'll deal with fascinating NPC's . If you'll take your time to explore, you'll get to know an engorssing world. Overall, this game is a gem that deserves everyones attention and while it is kind of short(I didn't wanted it to end) the score of 9.4 does it justice.

reviewText:
The world of Dishonored is fantastic; it is so rich and well-established by way of in-game books, notes, overheard dialogue and even just little scenes upon which you can stumble. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=303411450 Some people call Corvo, the protagonist, boring and characterless, but what's facinating is the effect that your actions - and by extension, Corvo - has on those around him.
People treat you differently by way of subtle changes in speech or tone and the lasting effect on one particular character is nothing short of brilliant.

As far as gameplay goes, Dishonored isn't perfect. The stealth mechanics are pretty close to perfect, with leaning around corners, clearly visible alert warnings and a multitude of clever ways to get around without being seen, http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=304088002but it falls apart a bit in the combat. Corvo is heralded as a master of arms, able to 'beat three men at once', as a guard can be heard saying. Ironically, fighting more than one person at a time can be infuriatingly difficult. And that's on moderate settings.
Because almost all NPCs use a combination of sword and pistol, you can cross swords only to be shot at point blank range by someone you can't stop, they can kick you; an unblockable attack that deals as much damage as a bullet, or they can just swing their sword as you jump backwards out of range and hit you anyway. Their sword range is about three times the length of their sword and you must block every single hit.

The killy death tools are nicely varied, allowing for very stylish kills with grenades, crossbow bolts and shrapnel mines, and that's not even touching on the supernatural powers. Adding them, the game becomes a flowing action of combat adding a clever third dimension to swordplay (at least the way I fight). Aside from just jumping and teleporting high, time manipulation, rat control and blasts of wind are just some of the tricks you can use.
Admittedly, you'll probably find one or two powers that you use more than the others, but the options are there to experiment.

While the story can be a bit predictable, it serves as a good framing device to take you across the breadth of Dunwall, killing and stalking people of all kinds. Also all of the cutscenes are skippable for those who want to try speedruns.

The DLC is an interesting topic, allowing a new perspective on the story as well as some different powers and amazing sprawling levels.

The downside of these slow, stealth-based games is they can be lacking in F**k Yeah moments, but Dishonored makes up for that in lasting enjoyment, http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=304087909
replayability and a world that you can be lost in for days.

reviewText:
Dishonored is a first person stealth action game were you play as Corvo Attano. He is the bodyguard of the Empress of the Isles but you are framed for her murder and now have to become an assassin to seek revenge and save her daughter who was kidnapped in the process.

You are freed from prison by the Loyalists who are a resistance group that seek to take the city of Dunwall back. Your first night out you are visited by a mysterious character called The Outsider while you sleep. He burns his mark on your hand and imbues you with special powers to help you through your missions.

These missions can be completed in a variety of ways. You can sneak through all the levels without killing anyone or go ahead and kill them all. Why not try a little of both if you feel like it. The only thing is the more you kill the more chaos will ensue. With more chaos you’ll see more rats and more plagued citizens. There are also small side missions you can complete to earn other goodies to help you out.

Your weapons consist of a small sword, a crossbow, or your bare hands which can silently take out your enemies or help you in moments of confrontation. Another thing you can do is peek through keyholes to see what may be on the other side which can help you choose how you will accomplish things. You are also given a choice of ten supernatural powers which five are active and five are passive. You will need to find runes to unlock more powers or upgrade them. There are also 40 different bone charms to help enhance your powers or abilities.

The supporting cast were well voiced and had many likable and unlikable characters. Everyone was well voiced which always helps add to the immersion. The story was pretty good but I just never really understood what the whole purpose of the Outsider was. I’m not sure if I missed something in the end but I felt all he really did was give you some powers and then never explain why. I also felt a there really wasn’t much to see since most of the game was basically in one area.

Overall Dishonored was a great game to play and would love to see a sequel perhaps that may explain more about the Outsider. Maybe even add more missions to flesh the game out some more just not ones that make it feel like it’s just filler. If you haven’t played Dishonored yet then now is the time since the game can be picked up for cheap and it’s worth the money.

Bear Rating: 9/10

reviewText:
Not the most difficult stealth game but perhaps one of coolest...

Dishonored is set in a world that resembles Victorian London, but with an odd asortment of technology that looks like it came straight out of a HG Well sci-fi novel: It is somehow familiar and alien at the same time. The visuals are pretty good as is the story, and the game mechanics are easy to pick up.

The AI is generally quite good, except for a minor issue with leaning .... basically the AI will not spot you unless you could be seen when not leaning. This means occassionally you can lean around a corner and look someone right in the eyes and they wont see you. Not that this is a big issue because you soon unlock special powers that make 'leaning' seem prosaic. With the addition of magical talismans and very cool gadgets the game does become somewhat easy even on the hardest difficulty, but it somehow manages to remain a lot of fun.

The missions are very well done, often allowing many different ways to succeed. You can be the cat burglar or the ghost killer, or maybe you want to possess the minds of men and beast to help gain access to somewhere new? It is up to you. Add to this many different routes in and out of every place and you have the feeling of really being free to do things your way rather than being herded by the game

In the end, whilst I would not classify it as the greatest stealth game ever made, it is certainly one I recommend to stealth game lovers without any hesitation.

See my video review here : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QFhxSBRENDw

reviewText:
Dishonored - A perfect example how games should be made.

11 out of 10. A masterpiece.

Your actions add to story, and by ending the story you can either win or lose big, or in between. This game has everything, you can play it like an action-filled FPS, you can play it like Thief and stay hidden, you can play it being manipulative and experiencing with your magical skills and play around with your skills almost endlessly.

And the story? It was great, too. I can´t figure any major flaws, even figuring out if there were minor ones is hard! After playing through I just had to sit still for 15-20 minutes and think what I had done, feelings were so great throughout the game, and passing it left so many unanswered questions that I do have to play it through again some week.

Definitely worth any sum you invest into it. Went into my all-time-top10-best-games-ever-played list.

reviewText:
Great job Arkane Studios!!! Let me start by admitting that Dishonored is not a flawless game. The AI and the stealth system could use some improvement (better overall AI, and a stealth system more similar to Thief's Dark Engine). The game has great art design and story (a little bit predictable, but still good...). The music and sound effects are really good. The city of Dunwall, which is modeled after late 1800s-early 1900s London and Edinburgh is just amazing!!! The world of Dishonored is rich and complex.

I enjoyed the non-linear and flexible maps, and the different powers the player can upgrade during the campaign! That adds a lot of replay value to the game!

I wish there have been more weapons in the game...
A Great overall game!!!

reviewText:
Holy hell, this is one well-executed game. Just two hours into it, and man, oh man. It is freaking amazing. I know I should have gone further into the game before reviewing it, but I couldn't resist; the game is that good; and the beginning of the game was pretty awesome. Dishonored is I guess what you may call a 'sneak-type' game. So, on to this review.

Gameplay: Dishonored is a stealth action-adventure video game played from a first-person perspective with an emphasis on stealth action and the use of special equipment and the environment to eliminate opposing forces. The world is a series of self-contained, mission-focused areas designed for various avenues of exploration in terms of scavenging loot, or seeking new powers. Between missions, the game takes place in a central hub called the Hound Pits pub where the player character, Corvo, can meet with his allies, receive mission briefings and alternate objectives, and convert recovered loot into new equipment and upgrades. Dishonored also features a few role-playing game elements, though not much. Whether it's make moral choices with a focus on non-linear consequences, or enhance your supernatural powers.

Story: The game takes place in the industrial city of Dunwall, where the game's protagonist, Corvo Attano, the former bodyguard to Dunwall's Empress, Jessamine Kaldwin, has returned from a long, foreign journey to seek the cure to a deadly rat-involved plague ravaging the city. After an incident, Corvo is taken to prison for interrogation regarding to the situation. Six months later, Corvo receives a letter from an unknown force and with their aid, he escapes. With their help, now he seeks revenge as their former assassin to help find a lost girl kidnapped from Dunwall's assassinated Empress, and restore order by killing the Dunwall city's traitor. I must have you confused on some points in this summary, but that's intentional, as I don't want to spoil it for you.

Pros:

+Great presentation values.
+Do you like to stab people? Maybe use a crossbow to ensure their demise? You have your own personal arsenal at your disposal. Almost every screenshot I have of Dishonored is of me killing people in the most brutal ways. But hey, if you wanna talk about stabbing, read this: http://steamcommunity.com/id/dorroile/recommended/205100/
+Masses of re-playability value.
+Wide selection of decisions.
+Different tactics are rewarded.
+Great soundtrack.
+Great upgrade abilities.
+Various, spacious environments riddled with pathways and secrets.
+Openness of the levels' designs. But with the role-play elements, this game's world could have been more open.
+Freedom to be creative within combat.
+AMAZING combat design.
+Great controls.
+Good graphics, the Unreal Engine has never looked better for a 2012 game.

Cons:
-A Somewhat short game.
-System requirements are small, but somewhat demanding.
-Stilted voice-acting. The voice-acting... some of it is meh; though I've heard of MUCH WORSE in other games.
-Options menu. If there's something I hate in video-games, it's lack of several options, as with the Metro games. Of course, this regards to just the graphic settings menu, nothing else.
-Occasional AI and physics glitches. Rarely happens, but when it does, you'll laugh. Once, I threw a grenade and two guards looked at it while walking up to it saying That's probably worth checking out" only to discover it was their death.
-Steep difficulty can be discouraging sometimes. Sure

reviewText:
Dishonored.

Pros
Great Art Style
Alot of hidden objects to be found
Rock solid Gameplay

Cons
Typical Story line
Rushed Ending.
Short Story line (9 levels)

Review :
Dishonored is a Game made by Arkane Studios And published by Bethesda[/i] And Was Released on 9 October 2012 in North America and 12 october 2012 in Europe.
Dishonored put the player in the shoes of Corvo Attano, The empress of the Isles (Jessamine Kaldwin) her Bodyguard.
The game is set in the Industrial City of Dunwall.
When Corvo came back from a long mission he was Framed for the murder on the empress and the Abduction of her Daughter (what he did not do).
And now corvo is Being forced to become an assassin to take revenge on the people who killed the empress and framed him...

The game plays in a first-person perspective.

In Dishonored you are an assassin with a mix of magic abilities and normal weapons (Pistols and Swords) and the mix between those two really benefits the gameplay a whole lot...
at any given time in the game you can use a Teleport magic (Blink) to teleport to nearby locations... (you can teleport about 8 to 10 meters with blink Level 1) and this really give you alot of interesting ways to take down an guard or gang member...
One of the great things about this game is the fact that you really can choose how to do a mission, you can go fully stealth or go complete non lethal if you want, this gives the game alot of replay value.
Other than that there are alot of hidden items and loot to be found, money you find or steal can be used to buy upgrade from the hub world.
in the game there are these so called bone charms and runes what upgrade your magic abilities and just overall luck...

The story of the game can become a little boring and its kinda short with giving the player only 9 missions to play...
the DLC kinda fixes the problem by adding a whole 7 level extra, where you play as the assassin who killed the empress : Daud.

The game has been praised by alot of big reviewing companies and in my opinion rightfully so...
Even players with an Laptop or an Older PC can enjoy the game because the art/Graphics style is very simplistic and clean.
and don't get me wrong... the game doesnt look ugly by any means but its not the leave of bioshock infinite

The game has been released on : PC, Xbox360 and PlayStation 3
Publishers website : http://bethsoft.com/
Developers website : http://www.arkane-studios.com/uk/index.php
More information about Dishonored : http://www.dishonored.com

Special mention : The game truly heaven for People who like to SPEEDRUN Games...

There for i would recommend this game to everybody who loves Action adventure game,
just think of it as being Thief but with more over the top action...

Thanks for reading :)

reviewText:
This game started out kindof slow for me.  But, it got better and better as the story progressed and is now one of my favorite games.  It has a great story, great scenery and style, and great stealth mechanics.  I would describe it as steampunk-inspired as long as you replace steam with something called whale oil.   It has a 19th century industrial feel to it and lots of wierd tech.

Speaking of stealth, it is refreshing to play a game, for once, that doesn't force you to kill everything in sight.   You don't even have to kill the bosses!  In fact, the only time I had to use deadly force was when I royally screwed up on a stealth approach and had no choice but to defend myself.  And there are consequences in the game when you continue to do so.  My skill choices probably had a lot to do with this, but I found fighting more than one person to be inherently hard.  This made it alot more exciting because setting off an alarm meant serious trouble for me in certain areas.   I found myself having to run a lot, which may not sound exciting at face value, but it forces you to change your strategy and look at problems from different angles.

Like most games I own, I got this one on sale and it is definitely worth more than what I paid for it.
voteText: 103 of 106 people (97%) found this review helpful 5 people found this review funny

reviewText:
The game borrows heavily from the Thief series but in all the right areas. It has the stylised graphics of RAGE and the sword-play of Dark Messiah of M&M. The open-ended level design and assassination objectives are very much like the earlier Hitman games. There's something slightly Deus-Exy about the upgrades and something thrilling about how overpowered the tools at your disposal are. Summon rats to eat your victims! Stop time and run about your helpless foes! See through walls to find the treasure and to track the enemies ahead of you! You've probably already heard about the 'blink' move, but it's worth mentioning again. Yes, you can now teleport across levels whenever you like! Teleport onto that windowsill above the guards and they won't spot you. If they do, simply teleport behind them again and take them down within seconds.

What a fantastic game! Recently I find myself getting bored of a game before the end, or even struggling to get into them, but Dishonored isn't like that- once I understood the game mechanics I played through to the end in one long sitting. Give it half an hour and you'll feel at home in the complex and dark world that it offers you.

Every level is like a beautiful sandbox for you to destroy as you do so please. Just like Hitman, you sometimes go in undercover and can easily eliminate the whole level should things go wrong, but you won't want them to. That's how good this game is. It almost WANTS you to exploit the levels, but encourages the stealthier routes with more rewarding payoffs.

After every mission you return to base. Back with Deus Ex I loved exploring, but now I find those bits rather dull as I want to progress to the next level as quickly as possible (only because it's so fun!). There is a decent story if you bother to follow it and your actions are mirrored by the people you're trying to save. Much like Bioshock, you're in for a rude awakening if you think that you can just go around killing people without consequence.

If you like any of the games already mentioned in this review then you'll more than likely enjoy Dishonored. It's just as fun to watch as it is to play and I have had great nights with my friends simply replaying the same mission over and over again in different ways.

My only issue is that it's rather short without all of the extra DLC. Or maybe I just enjoyed playing it so much I didn't realise how long it was. I know that there are a lot of things I didn't manage to do in the levels and will definitely be going through it again at some point to try the choices I didn't make before. Give Dishonored a go and hopefully get your honor back. I didn't.

reviewText:
There is so much I could say about this game. I got it on release and have been sipping from it occassionally like a fine wine ever since.... Holding off from going too deep into it. It's been over a year, and It's time for me to put it to rest and move on.
Simply put, the engine is similar to Bioshock... The major gameplay twist beng it offers you more story-based reward for sneaking, and not killing as much as one would like.

When you don't care about the effects your personal body-count has on the world around you, the combat is incredibly satisfying. Sneaking and purging each level of each sentry systematically and with precision, knocking them out and tossing their snoring bodies onto tables to avoid them being consumed by wandering rats has its level of satisfaction and professionalism as well.

The art is incredible. The lead artist for HL2 has helped to make sharp, stunning geometry flare out from a victorian setting.... New technology bursting at the seems of an industrial revolution, all happening in a victorian-steampunk era world beset by plague.

If you can appreciate a game that focuses on skill-systems, player focused creativity and level-flow... And if you can take your time, and let the world of Dunwall seep into your office, living room, or wherever you're experiencing this.... Rather than put on blidners and sprint right to the end, then you will love this game.

Put yourself in Corvos shoes and really dig deep. 10/10.

reviewText: Probably the best solo game I've played since several years. An interesting scenario and multiple opportunities to complete a mission by choosing a different path remaining invisible or killing everyone, you choose. Play Dishonored at maximum difficulty to enjoy the game to its fair value, previous difficulties being too simple. To understand the whole story, I also recommend the two best DLC: The Knife of Dunwall and The Brigmore Witches.

reviewText:
What a fool I was.. I pre-ordered this game back in 2012, the trailer gripped me and the screenshots got me pumped... and then I never played it, until recently.

I really can't believe that I didn't pay attention to this masterpiece of a game for 3 years, it's up there with Bioshock and Half Life for me.

The very first thing that will grip you as you play is the unique world and amazing atmosphere, the game is set in an industrial steampunk city that resembles victorian London, struck by a mysterious plague.. it's dark, it's gloomy and it's beautiful.

There's a genuis blend of technology and magic in your arsenal and in the world around you, I lightly compare this game to Bioshock because as you progress you will unlock supernatural powers which you can use together with your weapons, you'll be able to bend time, teleport onto rooftops and even posses enemies and animals.
And that's why I like Dishonored so much more than other stealth-focussed games, thanks to all these powers and weapons/gadgets you can go through a level in countless ways be it slipping through undetected or murdering everyone who crosses your path.

Even better is that how you play the game actually carries weight, if you wreak havoc wherever you go the city will become even more chaotic and you'll become more notorious. There's a great amount of player choice in this game, whenever you are asked to eliminate key targets there will be multiple paths you can follow, some even non-lethal, you can literally play the entire game without killing anyone.

The only minor point of criticism I have is the length of the game, just as I got really immersed I was already nearing the end, and once I beat the game I was longing for more though luckly there is DLC which is really good as well and this game definitely has a load of replayability considering of all the different playstyles and loads of collectibles in the world.

I still can't believe I let this game sit in my library for 3 years, it's absolutely worth playing!

reviewText:
Dishonored is inspired by the late nineteenth-century London and Edinburgh atmosphere that puts players in the skin of an empresses bodyguard named Corvo, who is framed for her murder and forced to become an assassin seeking revenge on those who conspired against him.

An excellent example of what a good adventure and a first-person action game should be, Dishonored can count itself as one of the top games of its many genres.

Overall aspects of Dishonored
Storyline plus the adventure:

The storyline in Dishonored is solid without losing its flexibility and well-constructed, being more than capable of giving players a very deep and easy understanding of it as it drastically changes or gets either molded by the players progression.

The characters couldn’t have been better selected. Everyone’s characteristics and roles match perfectly with the game's storyline and the situation that is present resulting in a very pleasant experience for those who wish to be part of a high quality story full of events and changes.

The adventure in Dishonored is something to admire. Despite being at its first look a game that resumes into successfully assassinate traitors and murderers, Dishonored offers in each mission a huge vast variety of ways on how to succeed in them.
Without mentioning the numerous side quests and other characters you may encounter, contributing to an extended exploration and adventure that may or not, again, affect your main quest storyline.

Graphics and game play mechanics:

Dishonored uses the Unreal Engine 3, with a huge inspiration from the Victorian-Era world of England during the late 19th century.

The game's graphics despite not being cutting-edge or breath-taking, match perfectly well with the game overall environment and the time period it has been designed in.

The game play mechanics might look at first slightly complex or confusing due to the huge amount of ways and styles that allows players to choose and adapt in each given situation depending on the creativity and style of each player. Such complexity can be easily be turn into something simple as players get the hand of the game and get used to it with a bit of time invested in it.

User interface:

The user interface is simple, clean and it can be easily mastered in a short period of time despite having a fairly wide variety of weaponry which also includes magic.

Music and the voice acting:

The music is mostly atmospheric sounds that match up fairly well with each situation and stage that the game presents.

The voice acting is formidable, it successfully combines the voice in each character to his or her role, to their physical characteristics and way of thinking.

Game difficulty:

The game difficulty is very well balanced to meet the tastes of those who wish an enjoyable adventure without struggling that much, to those who want it hardcore with difficult and sharper opponents.

Price:

The game price I would say is reasonable. A polished game with a high quality adventure with a beautiful story without any bugs/problems to point out.

Despite being only a single player game, I personally believe it deserves its base price.

DLC's

Dishonored has a few DLC's with the purpose of expanding the existing single player game play/campaign for a very balanced price making them worth every cent you spend on.

Conclusion
I would rate this game a 89 out of 100 or 4.5 out of 5.0 stars. A game that combines a good storyline, adventure and combat game play mechanics perfectly, making you ask for more and more of it.

reviewText:
Dishonored is several years old now, but it doesn’t feel like it has aged a day. It’s inspired by Thief and Assassin’s Creed, but is quite a bit different from either, making it feel unique. It has many problems, but the things it does well are so good they overshadow the negatives.

I’m sure it must have been a nightmare trying to market Dishonored, because it’s hard to nail down what it is in a simple way. In the reveal trailer Dishonored looked like Assassin’s Creed, but it isn’t like that at all. Like Thief, it encourages slow deliberate movement, listening carefully, and striking when nobody is looking. But at the same time the combat mechanics give you plenty of power to stand against any enemy, making it the power trip Thief never was. For example you have the ability to teleport with an ability called “blink”. This totally changes the power balance between you and guards. Despite this you don’t feel invulnerable like in Assassin’s Creed. Traversal isn’t easy, and running around is terrifying. When you sprint it feels like you’re relinquishing control and allowing yourself to miss things.

The most successful part of the game is the city. It’s brilliantly realized and is what will leave a lingering impression long after you’re done. It’s decaying, with feral rats attacking townsfolk, and deadly plants getting a foothold in the poorly maintained sewers. It feels like you’re seeing the last gasps of a once great culture, where whoever is left after the tumults will have a hell of a job piecing it back together. The rest of the story gives a cold and distant impression. It’s a revenge plot, but because of the silent protagonist it’s hard to engage with it. He has no personality, and the people you interact with keep the conversations to politics, again deemphasizing simple human connection. It’s not “bad”, just cold. The plot twists can be seen coming a mile away, but when they happened the motivations made sense. They nailed what mattered most for this game. The world, the sensation of exploring it, and the power of your character felt completely in line with how the story presented it. I don’t remember the finer aspects of the main story, but I remember the streets, and the people who lived there. It’s clear that was what the developers were most interested in, and they succeeded in making it memorable.

Huge parts of levels are optional, giving you a rewarding sensation of exploration that for example Bioshock never did. If you go straight at the objective you’ll only see maybe 30% of the level. The things hidden away in optional sections are often surprising, like it “should” have been part of the main path. But I’m glad they didn’t force you down a straight line, because this approach gives you a sense of control over the pace of the game. If you’re sick of a level and want to see what happens next, then you can just go ahead and advance. But if you want to take it slow, there’s nobody shouting at you to “move move move” like is so common in first person shooters. Here’s where the game feels most similar to the Thief games, as they also had sprawling worlds to explore. It’s the kind of design that makes it feel like you’ve barely scratched the surface, even if you were thorough. I love the sensation of feeling like there was more to the world than I saw, even if there might not have been. And even if I never replay the game, that air of possibility and mystery will never go away.

To give the world a strong impression, the graphical style uses hand painted textures and lighting which gives it a timeless look. It looks great now, and will most likely still do so in 10 years. There’s nothing obviously wrong with the style which will date it. Color, contrast and lights all look like they should. While it might be technically simple, it shows how much more important an inspired art direction is over raw technological grunt. Instead of a dynamic lighting system, the focus was on beautiful texture and color. This works well with the kind of game Dishonored is. In Thief you were so dis-empowered that the most terrifying thing in the game was a guard with a torch. Dishonored isn’t that kind of game as you can close the gap and take out guards in seconds.

One of the interesting missteps in the game is how the branching story is handled. Depending on how you play, the ending changes. This is a concept I find exciting, because this is where the developers are unavoidably saying something about how the world works. Whether you want to or not, the second you express how choices affect the world, you’re expressing a world view. Unfortunately Dishonored feels a bit too simplistic in how it manages this. If you kill people, your “chaos” ranking increases, putting the world’s story down a more violent path. This system doesn’t seem to take into account who you kill, or for what reason. The terminology of chaos and order tells a pacifistic message, that violence is never the answer, no matter the who or whys of the matter. I don’t think they should have exposed this stat between missions, as several people I know felt pressured not to play the way they wanted, because of the implicit messaging telling them they were doing it wrong. I feel they should have kept the branching story a surprise. Then when you got to the end and saw the result of your actions, it would have had more gravitas, as you’d be reflecting on it in hindsight. I’m hoping this system becomes more complex in the sequel, because it could add quite a bit of extra challenge and replayability if the story changes based on who you kill, knock out, or leave alone.

I could go on and on about how good the game is. Like the little touches like how if you crouch and move close to furniture you automatically crouch even lower to squeeze in under. I kept crawling in under tables for no practical reason, because it felt safe there. It opened up new possibilities for traversal other games don’t do, as their movement tends to be more rigid. The sensation of being able to play freely inside the game’s playground without adult supervision is important. It’s why I loved Crysis 1 and hated Crysis 3. The freedom makes the game more chaotic, clumsy and less “cinematic”. But it ignites that sense of ownership of your own actions. It makes it feel more personal. And this is what Dishonored does best. The story isn’t exciting enough to inspire a drive to see the end. But the sensation of exploring this world which is on its way out, to uncover its mysteries, and the beautiful art, makes up for the shortcomings.

reviewText:
Successful new intellectual properties are typically very difficult to produce in the world of game design. The process requires the developers to build all aspects of the video game from the ground up. They have to decide what type of art direction they're going for, conceive all pieces of the plot and characters from scratch, and build all of the technical systems such as graphics and combat from scratch. This is why new IPs are often rough around the edges. Sequels are so ubiquitous and generally more critically acclaimed because the developers already have an existing foundation to build upon from the previous title and they can focus on adding polish.

Dishonored is one of the special few new IPs that manages to avoid most of the pitfalls and delivers a diverse, adaptable, polished experienced right from the get go.

The most noticeable aspect of the game is its art design, which was deftly crafted by one Viktor Antonov, a Bulgarian art director famous for his work on designing City 17 and its outskirts in Half Life 2. His touch is recognizable in Dishonored as chaotic Dunwall shares many similarities with totalitarian City 17. Nothing feels like it was pasted over from Half-Life 2, though. Dishonored is a true steampunk game and Dunwall has it's own feel that's inspired by Victorian era London gone bad. There's a dirty river, loads of industry, and even a familiar-looking bridge. All of it is given a unique touch, and the result is a very immersive world. This is escapism at its finest; be prepared for the Dunwall to suck you in immediately and carve away the hours of your day as you explore every nook and cranny. I haven't been as enamored with a new setting since playing BioShock and first experiencing Rapture.

The plot is serviceable though predictable. Daud, the conflicted villain of the game, is the strongest and most interesting character. It's a shame he doesn't get more screentime, though Arkane have remedied this with a pair of DLC episodes in which he is the playable character. The player character, Corvo Attano, is a silent protagonist. This is a negative for me since I personally detest the silent protagonist trope in video games. I understand that the goal of the silent protagonist is to allow the gamer to project his own reactions into the game, and I know that many gamers enjoy it, but it pulls me out of the experience when I don't hear my character speaking to anybody addressing him because it's so unnatural. I can't logically connect the fact that my character is mute, yet nobody in the game ever seems to comment upon it. I don't enjoy it in the Half-Life series, and I'm not a fan of it here, either. I will say that the game deserves a mention of its voice acting, particularly the role of Daud as played by Michael Madsen of Tarantino fame. Other praiseworthy roles are played by John Slattery (Mad Men), Chloe Grace Moretz (Kick-♥♥♥), Brad Douriff (Lord of the Rings), Lena Headey (Game of Thrones), and Susan Sarandon (Thelma & Louise). They spent some money on voice talent, and it pays off. The one qualm I do have is the reptitive nature of the guards' canned conversational quips, of which there are few. They repeat themselves regularly which breaks immersion.

The wasted landscape of the plague-ridden city can become tiresome and a bit grating. There are corpses littered about, filth, rats, and crumbling buildings galore. The design is fine but the pacing leaves you in these types of areas for a bit too long. The more civilized settings in certain levels such as the gentlemen's club and the high society party feel special by comparison, but the pace would benefit from seeing more of the inhabited areas of the city and fewer of the burned out, deserted ghettos. There are only so many ways you can depict diseased ruin before it becomes repetitive.

The game's graphical muscle won't blow you away if you're used to games like Crysis 3, but the art direction props up the visuals enough to make them astounding in certain areas. There's an old oil painting feel which permeates the game, and it fits the look and feel of the setting very well. I get a sense of great design while playing this game. There aren't all that many graphical options to tinker with, but there is a field of view slider, which is always cause for celebration with PC ports. The game also runs exceptionally well on PC, so even if you're not wowed by the visuals and the art design like I am, the technical aspects of the visuals won't hinder you from enjoying the gameplay at all.

Dishonored is fully adaptable to your style of play, which is refreshing in a game that emphasizes stealth. If you're a stealth fanatic (as I admittedly am), then you'll enjoy it here. It's possible to finish the game without ever killing anybody or being spotted, and you're able to accomplish this thanks to being provided the tools to move quickly and silently throughout huge areas. Blink allows you to teleport instantly a certain distance across the map, and you can also acquire the ability to see through walls. Mobility is a requirement in many stealth games, and Dishonored gives you the tools to traverse the environment quickly when needed.

The beauty of the strong stealth play is that it's balanced by an arguably better combat system. The combat powers at your disposal (slowing or stopping time, possessing enemies, finishers, etc) all synergize incredibly well with one another and they allow you to take out your enemies in endlessly amusing ways. It's a sign of the design team having clearly described objectives, and I was genuinely amazed at how well the game flows between stealth and combat. I expected to play this game for its engrossing, artistic setting and ended up getting the biggest kicks out t's combat system. In my opinion it's the strongest aspect of the game, which is indicative of the game's greater value considering its already great art direction. There are multiple reasons to play this title, which helps it appeal to a broad demographic. It's no one trick pony.

The only real criticism I have of the game is the clumsy way in which it handles morality. Great games have been bungling morality mechanics for nearly a decade now (BioShock immediately comes to mind), so it's not surprising, but in Dishonored it becomes a glaring flaw because they get so much else right.

You're informed very clearly that the city will descend more and more into chaos if you kill your enemies rather than avoiding them or knocking them out, and your allies will begin to view you unfavorably the more deadly you are. While this is logically understandable (a lack of law enforcement officials presumably increases chaos in a troubled city), the mechanic unintendedly puts shackles on your ability to transition between stealth and combat. The gameplay seems designed to be freely adaptable so you can move seamlessly between stealth and combat when you're spotted, but it then tells you via the plot that playing stealthily and non-lethally is better. You begin to feel corralled into playing the game stealthily rather than being free to adapt to combat situations if you get caught. The plot punishes you for being spotted and having to fight your way out.

It's a disconnect in design between a plot that wants to make you accountable for your choices and gameplay that wants to be flexible. A potential solution would be leaving the chaos meter to be regulated entirely by how you choose to dispatch your assassination targets. Then it's isolated to the plot and doesn't have any effect on the way you choose to play the game. It's a disappointing flaw, but it doesn't take much away from a game that offers so much to begin with.

Overall, this game is a beautiful, immersive experience and it should absolutely be played by anybody who typically enjoys stealth games, or games that offer rich, engrossing settings. I'm very much looking forward to Arkane's inevitable sequel to this game.

reviewText:
English Version:
When I saw the trailer for the first time, It intrigued me a lot, especially for the wonderful soundtrack that I still listen, so I decided to try it.

The plot is fairly simple and straightforward, but you still manage to appreciate some of the secondary characters, who result very intriguing, even if they seem to me very poorly characterized. Corvo Attano is a quite complex character (also because his personality can vary depending on the choices you make during the gameplay) and so External and Daud are. In addition, the city of Dunwall, with its specific scenarios in different missions, is very suggestive.

The possibility of having always an alternative option in all missions makes the game much more enjoyable, so you can play completely stealth. But I played it several times, so I could enjoy every final and the simple consistency of having a different ending for the actions you take in the game is something that I thoroughly enjoyed and which can not be said of many other games.

It's the story of a city, Dunwall, gripped by a plague epidemic. When Corvo Attano, who is the royal guard of the emperess (who was looking for a cure to the plague that afflicted the city from other countries) comes back bringing bad news to the Empress, she is shot to death by a murderer appeared from nowhere and little Emily, the daughter, is kidnaped. Our protagonist is indicted and brought to the prisons of Dunwall and from there the adventure begins ...

I highly recommend it, I liked it a lot.

Italian Version:
Quando vidi il trailer la prima volta mi incuriosì parecchio, sopratutto per la splendida colonna sonora che tutt'oggi ascolto ancora, così decisi di provarlo.

La trama è abbastanza semplice e lineare, tuttavia si riescono comunque ad apprezzare alcuni dei personaggi secondari, che seppur poco caratterizzati mi son risultati molto intriganti. Il personaggio di Corvo Attano è parecchio complesso (anche perché è la scelta dell'approccio al gioco del giocatore, che determina la personalità dello stesso), così come quello dell'Esterno e di Daud. Inoltre la città di Dunwall, con le sue specifiche ambientazioni nelle diverse missioni, è molto suggestiva.

La possibilità di aver sempre un'opzione alternativa in tutte le missioni rende il gioco molto più godibile, in modo da poterlo giocare completamente stealth. Tuttavia l'ho giocato più volte, in modo da potermi godere ogni finale e la semplice coerenza di aver un finale diverso per le azioni che compi nel gioco è una cosa che ho apprezzato moltissimo e che non si può dire di molti altri giochi.

È la storia di una città, Dunwall, in preda ad una epidemia di peste. Quando la guardia reale dell'imperatrice, Corvo Attano, torna dalla missione (nella quale cercava un rimedio alla peste che affliggeva la città da altri paesi) portando brutte notizie all'imperatrice, la stessa viene colpita a morte da un assassino comparso dal nulla e la piccola Emily, la figlia, rapita. Il nostro protagonista viene incriminato e portato alle prigioni di Dunwall e da lì inizia l'avventura...

Lo consiglio vivamente, mi è piaciuto parecchio.

reviewText:
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
-3/4 cup white sugar
-3 tablespoons cornstarch
-1/4 teaspoon salt
-1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon
-4 cups fresh blueberries
-1 recipe pastry for a 9 inch double crust pie
-1 tablespoon butter

Directions:
-Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
-Mix sugar, cornstarch, salt, and cinnamon, and sprinkle over blueberries.
-Line pie dish with one pie crust. Pour berry mixture into the crust, and dot with butter. Cut remaining pastry into 1/2 - 3/4 inch wide strips, and make lattice top. Crimp and flute edges.
-Bake pie on lower shelf of oven for about 50 minutes, or until crust is golden brown.

Tip:
-Aluminum foil can be used to keep food moist, cook it evenly, and make clean-up easier.

reviewText:
Do YOU like loading screens? Well then you're out of luck, 'cos in this game, they're more of a subliminal message flash than a loading screen. I probably didn't even get to read the majority of the loading screen tips.

A very Assassin's Creed-like game, if Assassin's Creed were capable of producing a story you actually cared about.

As predictable as the story can be (Really, we're achieving all our goals this early? That seemed a bit easy, I wonder!), I found myself connecting with it, with Corvo, with Emily, with poor, ol' Sam. The game isn't just about calculated choices to achieve ends that I want. I found myself passionately hating certain characters. I felt disappointment when I realised I won't get to put a knife through their eyes. I felt mercy after hearing the tale of another character. And so it goes.

And if you want a bit more challenge, play through the game without killing anyone, or being detected - and not just because of the associated achievements. There's genuine focus and thought necessary to clear out clusters of enemies. Figuring out the enemy patrol patterns, best angles of approach and the timing. Heck, I probably spent a good hour clearing out one part of Flooded District, home to the Assassins. I felt genius anxiety about there being an assassin around the next corner or on the next rooftop, and very overlapping patrols/sightlines.

Overall, it's a great game with a less-than-original story that is presented incredibly well. The combat mechanics aren't the greatest if you just run around with knife and pistol, but once you start being a bit more creative, you can have loads of fun decimating piles of Watch Guards. Just do yourself a favour and reconfigure the combat controls, blocking with Mouse2, Sword attack with Mouse1 and Power/Gadget on a thumb button of preference worked really well for me.

reviewText:
Dishonored might be one of the best stealth based games EVER made. Hyperbole aside, I'm not even kidding.

Dishonored places you in the very capable hands of the Empress of Dunwalls head bodyguard Corvo Attano. The game begins with everything very calm and rather jovial. The empress's daughter Emily even invites you to play hide and seek as a form of a tutorial. Soon after the Empress is attacked by assassins and Corvo easily fends the first few off, however one succeeds after restraining Corvo and quickly vanishes leaving Corvo lying next to the slain Empress. Thus, 'Dishonored' begins.

Near the beginning of the game you're greeted by someone known as the Outsider. He grants you the ability of magic to include teleportation, seeing through walls, among other things. For obvious reasons, he remains elusive throughout the game.

The freedom of movement is rather unique and something I've not really seen other places. The movement, the narrative and the setting (London-esk during the late 1800's ) Where technology and magic exist together though the latter remains known only to a select few; Comes together in a package that feels unique like no other games quite hit every spot right like this.

Additionally, the narrative goes along perfectly with the actual gameplay. Each target as well as each objective that your rag tag team of seemingly misfit people assign to you in an attempt to prove your innocence and regain order, can be dealt with lethally or non lethally (which leaves some room for ambiguity) This may seem like a trivial distinction in most games, you might assume that doing either will get the job done and your next task will be marked. However, this game keeps track of each kill, each time you where seen and a number of other things that all go into your overall chaos rating; which markedly changes the world. The way people react to you and what defenses may or may not be set up to dissuade you from completing your task.

I've played through twice now, DLC included (which is remarkable. Some of the best DLC I've played since Bioshock Burial at Sea and the Witcher 3 DLC. I am not even close to joking. And I wholeheartedly think you should play that as well should either having more missions interest you or seeing the story from another perspective interest you) I've taken the High Chaos and the Low chaos route; the game takes the best from Thief and adds more content and playability to make it a near perfect product.

You can be the stealthy rogue on a mission with a heart of gold or play the ruthless killer bent on revenge and the world will reflect that sentiment. I am in love.

reviewText:
You should play this game. Briefly, here's why:

1) It is fun. Not content to simply shoehorn mediocre gameplay into the gaps between story, the developers have managed to make a game where simply BEING Corvo is fun. Running around, double-jumping, and using Blink to explore rooftops... these are actions that would be enjoyable even in the absence of story entirely, and other powers continue to add interesting ingredients as you unlock them. That they THEN wrapped this gameplay in an interesting story is the proverbial icing on the cake.

2) The art. LOVE the art. The character designs are in my personal Top 3 (with Brink and DE: Human Revolution) and the environments are beautiful too. I could (and probably have) spent hours just appreciating the visual style.

3) Open to different play-styles. You can treat it like a shooter and kill everyone, or you can finish the entire game without killing a single person. (Or somewhere in between.) Furthermore, the environments themselves offer great flexibility in terms of your desired approach, instead of just being narrow corridors funneling you along the intended path, like many other games I won't name here.

4) It is a polished, AAA, single-player-only, original IP. If that sentence doesn't make you nod with respect, you haven't been paying attention to the past few years of AAA games and the epidemic of Sequelitis." It takes real stones to make a game like Dishonored happen in an age where publishers are VERY reluctant to take risks. The fact that Arkane and Bethesda stepped up to the plate is admirable
date: and the fact that the resulting game is actually GOOD is something worth supporting."

reviewText:
My absolute favorite game EVER!
Let me explain you why:

Dishonored can be played in a countless of ways, not just stealth, or non stealth; every level has many different ways to be cleared and explored. I started playing this game the non stealth way, destroying anything that so much as looked at me sideways. What I love about this, is that it affects the ending a great deal, your actions have consequenses!
So, after my first playthrough, where I brutally obliviated everyone in my path, I decided for a more stealthy approach, and it was the most fun I've ever had playing a game!
There's so much to do in Dishonored, I'm still not done discovering, and I've cleared this game quite a couple times.
That gets me to the bit of the game that I didn't like so much.
Dishonored has a VERY short storyline, and I feel like they rushed it, an extra mission or two would've helped.
Then again, the story is VERY well written, and it all checks out so well, on both endings.
Also, there's a lot of side missions, and non-lethal approaches for dispatching key targets, and a lot of hidden objects to be found, wich makes the exploring of a level a lot more interesting.
I also love the special ability's Corvo has, the 'Blink' is a teleportation wich comes in handy whenever you find yourself in a nasty situation, and you need to escape. It also proves its worth in combat, when you blink up to an enemy and slash his throat, he'll never know what the f*ck hit him!
There's a HUGE number of upgrades and tools that can be bought, powers will have to be accuired and upgraded by finding 'Runes'.

One thing is for sure, you will never find yourself bored playing Dishonored.
Graphically, this game lacks very little, the only thing I'm a bit bothered with, is that it doesn't run very smooth on my PC, but that's more due to my PC, I can't blame the game for that :P.


So... to summarize:

Pro's
+Beautiful graphics.
+Great gameplay, many different options and approaches.
+Very good storyline.
+A lot of secret areas and side missions to discover.
+Combat is fun, but stealth is AWESOME
+A HUGE number of different tools and weapons, which makes the killing all the more fun!

Con's
-Short storyline, could've been longer
-You need a decent PC to run this on.

10/10 -It's a piece of ♥♥♥♥ing art in my opinion!
voteText: 19 of 21 people (90%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
You play as Corvo Attano, the bodyguard to the Empress. You go on a personal mission to rescue her kidnapped daughter Emily. In the dark and depressed city of Dunwall.

It's always nice to see a new quality franchise. Dishonored is a first person stealth assassin game, where you get the freedom to choose who to eliminate and how. Your playstyle even has some effect on the surrounding world, for example if you go on killing everybody, there will be more rats in the city. Your choices also shape the ending. It's possible to do completely non-lethal run of the game, which is one of it's great features.

The art style is magnificent, it's a bit caricaturized victorian steampunk. There's also huge amount of high profile voice talent in the game. Including Susan Sarandon and Chloë Grace Moretz.

The games weakness to me comes from the upgrades, while most of them are inventive, fun and open up different possibilities how to approach the game. Some are just bit too overpowered and make the game too easy and other skills useless.

Highly recommended to anyone looking for a great stealth game with rich characters and story. If you want, you can also play it as straight up action game. While it truly shines with more stealthy approach. The choice is yours.

[Score: 92]

reviewText:
INTRODUCTION:
Dishonored is a First Person Stealth Action-Adventure game released in 2012. It seeks to be the spiritual successor of the popular Thief series who, back in 1998, had set a very high bar for the stealth game genre.

The player steps into the boots of Corvo Attano, an elite bodyguard to the Empress of the Isles who was murdered by a shadowy organization of assassins. Accused by the people and condemned to death by the State, the player will follow Corvo's struggle to redeem his name, avenge the death of the Empress and stop any usurper from claiming the empty Throne.

PROS:
+ Action and Stealth Balance: -The game offers different ways to finish a mission and multiple methods of completing an objective. The game can accommodate player preference, whether they like action, non-lethal stealth or assassination oriented approaches. Use the various tools, skills and powers available to your advantage. Just beware of the consequences of your Actions.

+ Great Visual Design: -The city of Dunwall is dark, wet, dilapidated, poor, disease stricken and all of this are completely beautiful. The game boast a unique texture design making the whole world look like it was oil painted, this gives it a unique personality and a gorgeous aesthetic. The city itself has great atmosphere due to the people and the overall level designs along side the Steam Punk theme. There is a large world to explore in-between and during missions.

+ Rich World: -If the player takes time to explore and discover some of the lore that is spread around the game, (like books, letters, conversations, the different character's thoughts by using 'The Heart' item), the City of Dunwall, 'The Isles' and the world in which it is set, suddenly becomes alive.

+ Complex Political Intrigue: -The main plot itself is straight forward and a bit cliche, HOWEVER, if you take the extra time to listen to conversations, reading thoughts (See above), and go out of your way to discover non-lethal solutions to your main objectives, you will uncover a conspiracy that goes far deeper than what you expected.

CONS:
- Voice Acting: -The voice acting is not 'bad' per se, but at times, specially with certain characters, it feels kind of stiff or lifeless. Some people might find this annoying since it can really pull you out of the otherwise great immersive experience.

- Limited Non-Lethal Takedown Tools: -Aside from your choke hold (which have only ONE animation by the way) and sleep darts, there is simply a noticeable lack of tools for the non-lethal track. Watching the choke hold animation gets boring after a while. Would have loved it if they incorporated other animation types or different moves for non-lethal takedowns like an inverted grab and choke from a ledge or a ceiling beam perhaps?

-Occasional AI Glitches: -I normally don't put glitches or bugs as cons, unless, they occur more than I would like. I have played this game 3 times already and on each one, I encountered some bizarre (but hilarious) bugs that causes some of the AI to do some weird stuff. Not game breaking though, it's more like a minor annoyance than anything else.

CONCLUSION:
GREAT GAME! A true spiritual successor to the Thief series, Dishonored creates an amazing stealth system while adding new characteristics and twist that makes it a truly exceptional game.

If you're the type of gamer who is into gun play than anything else, then I would NOT RECOMMEND this game for you. Dishonored encourages combat variation by mixing ranged, magical and melee attacks. The different weapons and tools, including the gun and crossbow, only compliment each other and it is ill advised to only focus mastery on one.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

reviewText:
Unlimited assasination combos, this is the life.

You are Corvo, the Queen's formal bodyguard. Within this game, the emphasis is on choice. Throughout the whole game you can choose, to assasinate or detain, to kill all opponents or dispose of them non-lethally. You gain rewards, medals if you do the mission non-lethally. Another large part is gaining Whale Bone Charms or Runes to upgrade spells. The game can be played over and over and over again each time trying a different difficulty, or collecting all the Runes and WBC, or doing the mission non-lethally.

Although I found this game fairly short, I was amazed at the possibilties and graphics the game had to offer. Every detail was considered and looked into to improve the gameplay and quality. There are many ways to eliminate enemies, such as backstabbing them, or jump stabbing, or pulling off epic blade combos, or assasinating the enemy with a bow, or shooting them with your gun. There are also non-lethal ways, such as Sleeping arrow, smothering the enemy unconcious, shocking the enemy with an electric bullet. The possibilities are endless..

All the characters were thought out carefully, every aspect of their emotions and wording showed there personality. The plot is fairly good, between missions you can relax and talk to your so-called allies"
date: each ending with you sleeping. All-inall this game is amazing and I enjoyed every second of it. I failed in the end
recommended: and made a mistake. having known the characters so well
hoursPlayed:
I felt sad for a while. This game is something on its own.

9.8/10

reviewText:
With its fantastic mechanics and grim but dull setting, Dishonored remains a favorite of mine, and a great accomplishment for the genre.

Dishonored is a first-person stealth action game set in a heavily Victorian London inspired world where you play as Corvo Attanowho after being betrayed and blamed for the murder of his beloved Empress to whom he served as an agent and personal bodyguard, meets a being shrouded with incredible mystery.. A higher entity referred to as the Outsider.

With the assistance of the Outsider, who chooses neither evil nor bad, only whatever is of interest to him, Corvo gains 'magical' powers.

Dishonored does a great job in balancing your set of physical tools and magical abilities. Neither are enforced. These only give to the already vast variety of playstyles and add through the magical aspect of this game a great deal of depth to the gameplay and mechanics.

As a silent protagonist, Corvo is an empty shell the player is supposed to fill.
Little to big differences in the world are made as a result of your actions in it. Your actions have impact. The way you affect the world is not common.
It's not just what you say to this person or that character, it's your playstyle.
You dared not to hurt a soul? From that you gain as part of your reward cleaner sewers. Meaning less weepers (a certain type of enemy) to avoid or kill or render them unconscious.
You've been a good boy? Good job, little sweet Emily's drawings is that of a happy, sunlit place. You've been bad? Well, you can see that reflected upon the new dark, sinister characters in the paintings.

This succeeds in making you feel regret for acting as you did, playing as you did as Dishonored manages to get you emotionally invested in Emily's character, and when you see her drawing of you, smiling bright, you smile in real life. But when you don't get to see that happy creation, cheerfully titled 'Daddy' you see the masked murderer you are.
Whether you choose to see her turn you into her savior or her fear, a tower with flowers and a rainbow or murderer with a bloody knife and a pile of bodies is for you to decide through your playstyle alone. It's important to mention that these specific details are not forced, as you might not even notice them while playing through the game. They are worth glimpsing at though.

This all sounds awesome, right? What a wonderful mechanic.
Well, not necessarily. The only reason to purchase any game at all and play through it, is for the sake of your personal entertainment. It's your game, you should choose to play it however you wish to. Now, although I am all for the specific player-action-affected events I stated above, Dishonored has one heavy punishment for the player should he choose to be a bad boy.

Paintings are one small thing. Game ending is another. And that is broken. Unknowingly, you will be punished by the game's ending if you carelessly killed all who stood in your way.
This is wrong. This is not a 'your choices matter' game. This is a game you play for the fun in its gameplay and mechanics, for its openness in level design, letting you move on from this place to the next however you'd like to.
Giving you a bad ending is a needlessly unforgiving and punishing mechanic.
Your way of enjoying this game shouldn't be a negetive deciding factor for the ending which you receive.


For stealth-action fans, I'd consider this game a must have in your game library.
Of course, not that you can't have incredible fun with it if what you're into is decapitating enemies or watch them being eaten and devoured alive by swarms of rats controller by you. Honestly, it can be just as satisfying as bypassing every guard without being noticed.

Dishonored is a fantastic game. Its setting is an incredible fit. Its mechanics in gameplay are a joy to use and the animations do a magnificent job in delivering the satisfaction of a kill. And while the story may not be the most interesting, I did find myself invested in some of the characters and I did find myself immersed to extreme measures with the world of Dishonored to the point where I found myself reading the different notes and excerpts scattered throughout the game to enrich my knowledge of the interesting lore behind it all.

I'd also like to mention the DLC expansions in which you get to play as one of the antagonist and see through his eyes and reason. The extra story enables you to experience and understand the mindset of the very person who set you upon this stuff for the sake of money and greed. A path which brought nothing but horrors bestowed not only upon you, but the entire city as well. If you were a fan of Dishonored, these are a must-buy.


Overall, it was one hell of a ride and I enjoyed it immensely.

reviewText: I have a hundred steam games, played some more non steam games, and have went through stacks of console games that are longer than a Tyrannasaurous Rex's ♥♥♥♥♥, and out of all these games, Dishonored still stands to be my favorite. Although the game may be short, I feel like this is a good thing as the game is so good it makes you want to replay, and as you replay thhe game you get to experience new things you never experienced on your first playthrough, whether it be your first time shoving a knife in a guards neck, or your first time sparing your main targets, the gameplay stays fresh whenever you replay the game. One thing that disappointed me with this game is the lack of stealth equipment, as your arsenal is quite low for stealth, and it makes the stealth route less appealing, however the stealthing itself, and the mechanics of it are really nice and make it enjoyable for me. If you enjoy murdering everyone in sight then this game will make you very happy as there are so many creative ways to kill people using the supernatural arsenal of corvo, when someone shoots you, you can freeze time, put them in front of their own bullet, then after their dead summon a swarm of rats to clean up for you. The story, although being short is really good, especially since the choices you make directly change the story, and you progreesively see the choices you make changing the environment around you, making you feel more connected to the choices you decided to make in game. I bought this game around when it came out and it went on sale for 30$, the prices has obviously dropped since then, but I feel I have gotten way more then my money's worth, and I guarantee your money would not be misplaced upon buying this game\n

reviewText:
Favorite game of 2012, I pre-ordered it and loved it.

Gameplay is smooth whether on a mouse and keyboard or controller. Combat has several ways to integrate all types of play styles, from murderous desperado to a ghost, Dishonored gives you the option to take out enemies (or don't) however you want. The powers Corvo has (which are optional as well) are interesting and help create some of the most interesting game moments, and the upgrades actually do something. AI could be better, but it's passable on higher level difficulty.

Great design and art direction make Dunwall (despite being plague ridden and filled with a corrupt stand in government) an interesting place filled with colorful characters. The lore in this game is a bit buried, but listening to conversations or reading some of the many books you find around Dunwall will clear a lot of it up.

Story is pretty good, there are two endings based on your chaos level (how many people you kill, alarms you sound, how many bodies are found yada yada yada) but it's probably not what you'll be focusing on, with the exception of Daud (which is why the Brigmore Witches and The Knife of Dunwall DLCs are highly recommended) nonetheless it's a nice part of the game.

Dishonored is a beautiful game that still plays and looks better than some stuff getting shoveled out, if you didn't like the Thief reboot, or want a stealth game you can play over and over, I really really recommend Dishonored.

reviewText:
Dishonored is becoming one of my favorite stealth games, nay, one of my favorite games of all time.

It has it all. Amazing gameplay, dialogue, story, art direction, world, level design, freedom, and replayability. The biggest strength of this game is that you can be extremely creative with how you kill your enemies or sneak around, lending itself to many playthroughs and playstyles. The amount of detail and lore put into the world is just staggering, each note and book you find only adding to the fascinating world of Dunwall and the cities beyond. As icing on the cake, the voice acting is top notch and you can always catch interesting conversation between guards and noblemen alike.

I can ramble on and on about how wonderful this game is, but you should play it for yourself. It's rare to see a game that's so well crafted in every aspect. 10/10

reviewText:
Dishonored is a 2012 stealth action-adventure video game developed by Arkane Studios and published by Bethesda Softworks. It was released worldwide in October 2012 for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 3, and Xbox 360. Set in the fictional, plague-ridden industrial city of Dunwall, Dishonored follows the story of Corvo Attano, bodyguard to the Empress of the Isles. He is framed for her murder and forced to become an assassin, seeking revenge on those who conspired against him. Corvo is aided in his quest by the Loyalists—a resistance group fighting to reclaim Dunwall, and the Outsider—a powerful being who imbues Corvo with magical abilities. Several noted actors including Susan Sarandon, Brad Dourif, Carrie Fisher, Michael Madsen, Lena Headey, and Chloë Grace Moretz provided voice work for the game.

The game is played from a first-person perspective and allows the player to undertake a series of assassination missions in a variety of ways, with an emphasis on player choice. Missions can be completed through stealth, combat, or a combination of both. Exploring each level opens new paths and alternatives for accomplishing mission goals, and it is possible to complete all missions, eliminating all of Corvo's targets, in a non-lethal manner. The story and missions are changed in response to the player's violent actions or lack thereof. Magical abilities and equipment are designed to be combined to create new and varied effects.

Storyline is amazing.
1 of the best games I have played. :D

reviewText: A wondefully crafted story. You are a bodyguard hired to protect Queen Victoria of England from the Black Plague, but when Budd from Kill Bill murders her, you are framed for it. After escaping prison, you systematically assassinate everyone in the entire city to prove that you're not a deranged killer. Then you wake up in the boat from Willy Wonka on the choclate river, but you ate way too much choclate, so the Oompa Loompas bring to Budd and he takes all your stuff. You get really mad at him for that, so you kill him too, and then you're done. Oh, and there's some subplot about rescuing a girl or somethnig, but that's not important.

reviewText: This game's artistic style is a mix of Thief 1+2 and BioShock. Of course I liked it, is that even a question? I also commend the game designers for successfully creating a game that was equally fun playing either fully stealth or mass murdering everyone. Unlike Garrett, Corvo is fully capable of fighting guardsmen head-on and there are all sorts of weapons that make it fun, interesting, and satisfying the entire time. On the other hand, if you choose to go stealthy there are lots of little conversations to overhear that further add to the fantastic amount of world-building. You really can't go wrong here playing either way, though I'd recommend picking one style and sticking with it.\n\nThis game has a lot more Thief-y feel than the actual sequel Thief (2014) did. It's a real shame that game turned out to be what it was. Unsurprisingly, I discovered that there's some overlap between the production staffs for the original Thief games and this one. The blood will tell, as they say.

reviewText:
Goddammit, I promised this one a LONG time ago and now with my vacations, I can actually put some love into this one. [Thanks to HateBreeder for the reminder ;)].
Anyways... Dishonored went under my radar because 1) It looked like it was sh*t; and 2) The moral choice didn't encourage me to buy it at all (which I will explain why later).

It's hard at all to give a good premise to a game and Dishonored gets it half well and half badly: The lore is great, you have an Empress who rules Dunwall with it's lords and assistants, a very... steampunk-ish city where the plague infects everything and everyone. Everything feels depressing and everyone just ♥♥♥♥♥es about how they are sad and hate life and lifes hates them.
The game succeeds in putting you in Corvo Attano's shoes (the protagonist), a guard for the empress who, right off the bat is accused to murdering the Empress, that moment.. sucked! It was so stupid as to how Corvo (he can't ♥♥♥♥ing talk!!) didn't say a word, he just stood there while everyone said TRAITOR!" or "MURDERER!". It totally breaks from his character and the immersion of the world. Sadly... Dunwall falls flat as well with all this:

Dunwall doesn't have character! (I know
date: it sounds weird...) It all sums up to you finding a dead body somewhere with a suicide letter because their wife or girlfriend or sister or mother and/or whatever died because of the plague!\nIt shoves depression down your throat every. Single. ♥♥♥♥ing. Time! It's not appealing! It needed (not much
recommended: but at least a little bit of) life or joy somewhere
hoursPlayed: hell! Even the mission at the party is ♥♥♥♥ing depressing in groundbreaking levels of depression!\nThe Steampunk city could also be better described

reviewText:
I am only a couple of hours in the game at the time I write this, but my impression of this game so far is very good. The graphic design is very nicely done and feels immersive. The overal game mechanics are solid and the UI works like a charm (good port). So far Iam not really sucked into the story yet, but thats not a big deal, I am having to much fun with sneaking around and exploring :)

The gameplay feels like a hybrid between Fallout, Deus Ex and Bioshock. If you like these type of games then this is a recommended game for you.

reviewText: If you can buy one game in 2012, it should be Dishonored. From production to its ingenious gameplay, Arkhane Studios' title is outstanding, with its multiple references to many games such as Deus Ex, Thief, Bioshock or Half Life 2. It's simple, Dishonored is a 2-in-1 game you can finish either with violence and lots of action sequences, or with discretion, applying stealth strategies to kill your enemies without being seen.

reviewText:
Combine a murderous acrobat-wizard with:

- A first-person perspective,
- A mass of tricky gadgets,
- A living, breathing, dying city that actually reacts to your actions,
- An original steampunk-fused Victorian universe,
- Linear levels that don't feel linear, and
- A story made bigger through curious mini-stories hidden throughout the world

And you would still only have fraction of what Dishonored is.

reviewText: A unique and awesome action game created by Arkane Studios! It definitely fits every gamer's profile since you can acomplish every single mission by your own personal way. You can either be stealthy or you can unleash Ragnarok to everything and everyone. As a fan of stealth games and stealth style in general, I have to admit that they did a fine job with this one. The moves, the compact and fight style and mechanisms...everything was designed with great accuracy! Last but not least, I must also give my respects to the game's storyline and its environment which actually ROCKED.  A perfect example of how stealth games should be designed!\n\nI give this game 9/10
