reviewText:
Bethesda really has done a great job on this one,
you can walk through the city like a killing machine (not one the highest difficulty though).
sneak over roofs and pipes. or run through sewers as a rat.
kill your assasinatian contracts or let them live by marking them as a heretic for instance more difficult but more rewarding.
every choice you make comes back to you in the future.

how does it end for you? does the plague take over? do you lose everything you toke as assured? or do you restore the peace and the throne of the new empress?
i should say: buy the game and find out.

reviewText:
Ахх, Дунвалд өнгөрүүлсэн 45 цагийг би хэзээ ч мартахгүй, хэзээ ч! Хэрвээ биелээгүй мөрөөдлийн талбар болсон виртуаль ертөнцөд, тэр дундаа Гристолын нийслэл Дунвалд хүрч очвол би ... загасчдын гудманд сарын 10 алтан зоосоор байр хөлсөлж, Гулерогийн тамхины үйлдвэрт ажил хийж, байгалийн философийн их сургуульд сурахын зэрэгцээ шөнийн цагаар халимны тосон дэнлүүний гэрэлд эрдэмтэн Пьеро Жоплин, Антон Соколов нарын онолыг шимтэн судлах байлаа. Харин зунд нь тэнгис далайд гарч, халим загасыг агнаж яагаад болохгүй гэж? Хэрэв би азтай бол залуу хатан Эмилийн эрэлхэг хамгаалагч Корвотой өөрийн биеэр учрах тавилантай ч юм билүү?

Эерэг талууд:

[+] Сонирхол татам зохиол.
[+] Сонирхолтой зураглал. Ер нь фото реалистик зураглалтай гэж хэлж болно. Хэй, харин ч энэ нь тоглоомыг чимж өгсөн шүү!
[+] Хамгийн гол нь өнгө болон дизайн. Ялангуяа уг тоглоомын дизайн нь үнэхээр гайхалтай болсон! Тоглох явцдаа та ажиглаарай, жирийн нэгэн шүүгээ, сандал ширээнээс эхлүүлээд хотын байшин барилга, гудамж талбай, хүмүүсийн өмсч байгаа хувцас, хэрэглэж байгаа хэрэглэл нь гээд л бүх зүйлс нь өөр өөрсдийн гэсэн давтагдашгүй өвөрмөц хийцтэй болохыг!
[+] Гайхалтай уян хатан тоглолт. Энэ тоглоомыг тоглож байх явцад танд яг л торгоор хийсэн хөнжлийг алгаараа илж байгаа ч юм уу, аль эсвэл хоёр гараа бүлээн усанд дүрээд хооронд нь савандаж байгаа юм шиг л мэдрэмж төрөх болно.
[+] Хэрэглэх олон арван шид болон тусгай чадварууд!
[+] Даалгавруудыг өөрийн хүссэнээр биелүүлэх боломж бас сонголт.
[+] Давахад хүнд хэцүү саад бэрхшээлүүд.
[+] Тоглогчдыг өөрт уусгах уур амьсгал. Тоглоом болгонд ийм зүйлс байдаггүй гэдгийг дурьдах хэрэгтэй.
[+] Сонирхолтой DLC нэмэлтүүд. Бүрэн үнээр нь худалдаж авсан ч та харамсахгүй.

Сөрөг талууд:

Уг тоглоомноос өөлөх зүйл үнэндээ алга даа.

Ингээд, миний зүгээс уг тоглоомд 10/10 оноог өгч байна!

reviewText:
Dishonored - an epic fantasy title by Arkane Studios... can it counter a game like Skyrim? Let's find out!
Imagine a pretty solid guard who gets magical powers by a supernatural guy known as The Outsider, being falsely accused of murdering the queen... doesn't that sound pretty cool? Well, it actually is!

Dishonored takes place in the industrial city of Dunwall, where technology and otherwordly forces coexist. The city design is modeled on London and Edinburgh in the 18th century. With a very dark and foggy atmosphere and an interesting art style, aesthetically it serves very well as eye-candy. But not only the graphical aspects make this game a masterpiece - the concept designs, story lore and mechanics are solid and complex. Since it's sadly not a sandbox game, you are relatively limited to exploring, freedom of roaming etc - but the points above completely compensate to that.


The storyline is a masterpiece, aesthetics are eye candy and an engine that is actually working. Sounds satisfying, right? Besides the awesome visuals provided by the dark themed style - you also get supercool abilities which give you tons of possibilites how to defeat your enemies - or sneak past them without anyone noticing. Different playstyles are definetely possible in this game, and give even the sneakiest rogue-players a good challenge and satisfaction. I would buy, and recommend the game again!

10/10

120GB SSD + 3TB ext.

reviewText:
If you are a fan of stealth games, then you are in for a treat in Dishonored - a first-person stealth game heavily inspired by the Thief franchise (and a few others).

Going straight to its selling point, mechanically, Dishonored is near flawless as far as stealth games are concerned, no doubt about that. It has been more than long due to finally see a stealth game which provides such vast possibilities for approaching your objectives. Want to use the rooftop to get in? Go ahead. Prefer getting in through the sewers? No problem. Want to become a fish? Sure, why not. The things I wished Mark Of The Ninja (a brilliant 2D stealth game) could have done better were granted in Dishonored. Aside from common mechanics seen in almost any other stealth game such as hiding in shadows and sneaking past guards, the addition of magic abilities such as Blink, Possession and Time Bending provide a new layer of depth in the gameplay. Although these abilities do make the game fundamentally easier than the old-fashioned stealth games like Thief, with some a bit too overpowered, it is remarkable how creative you can be with them. This makes a playthrough totally different than the next one and increases replayability. Even without its new mechanics added in, the fundamental ones which define a stealth game are up to par in Dishonored. The only time when immersion seems to break is when you hide underneath something, like a table or inside a fireplace, after you have been spotted and the alerted guards stand idiotically in front of you doing almost nothing to you. Sometimes they throw objects at you, but otherwise you can stay there and cheaply kill everyone else near you, one by one. This is something which I experienced not once, but a couple of times in the game. So yes, there are a few AI issues, but these are mostly encountered rarely.

Funnily enough, Dishonered unashamedly took evident inspiration from games such as Bioshock, Half-Life and, unsurprisingly, Thief in its visual presentation, narration and level design. As a result, while its setting may look all cool with its blend of steampunk and Victorian London, it is hard not to feel like it borrowed too heavily from the aforementioned titles. “A City Unlike Any Other” is written in its description on the its Steam page which is a bit “dishonest” – it is nothing more than a modernised City 17 from Half-Life 2. Obviously, this aspect is just me nitpicking it and does not retract how beautiful and well-designed the world in Dishonored is, although you would have expected the person who once worked at Valve and envisioned City 17 in the first place would at least attempt to create something actually new rather than a rehash of his previous work when he moved to Arkane Studios. The point which is being made here is that there is nothing to praise about in terms of originality, but again, that does not make its setting any less enthralling. Graphically, it looks pretty good despite some textures feeling noticeably washed out. Whether this was an artistic decision, I cannot say. Its soundtrack is also good, but nothing too memorable though.

With an interesting premise, the story in Dishonored is perhaps its weakest aspect. You take the role of Corvo, a bodyguard of the Empress who eventually gets framed for her murder and gets thrown in jail. With the aid of underground allies from the outside fighting for the same cause (finding the real murderer), Corvo manages to escape his prison cell and begins his long quest in avenging his Empress’s death and protecting her heir to the throne. All-around, the story feels only slightly above average – it honestly is neither great nor bad. In fact, what puts it above average is how your actions in missions do actually affect the narrative of the game in some form or another; even when you start questioning how the moral system implemented actually works when the game punishes you for things you might not have done (or was forced to) if you are aiming for the good ending. Annoyingly, the game offers plenty of cool gadgets to use in your missions and you just cannot resist using some when the occasion arises, but indirectly lets you know that you are a bad person if you kill someone. At the end of the day though, if you are someone who does not care about which ending they get or can pretend that is the ending they got, then you are free to approach things whichever way you want, blazing through or sneaky peeky. Anyway, the story is by and large pretty forgettable with its only major plot twist also getting somewhat predictable halfway through the game. Sadly, most of the characters in Dishonored tend to end up feeling not fleshed out enough. “Why should I care?” was a frequent question running through my mind all the time. “Because you’re the great Corvo and we believe in your skills!” said someone amongst those lines in the game, more than once. Well, okey, thanks bud. Heck, even Corvo becomes a pretty uninteresting protagonist due to a lack of personality and the charms of someone like Garrett from the Thief games. Corvo’s only motive is to simply avenge his Emperor’s death and protect her heir to the throne, Emily, a young girl who I personally had no attachment whatsoever throughout the entire time, even when the game forces her on me. Muted protagonists have been done better before, and Corvo is not a great example. Take away all of its story, then you come to realise that what you are playing are nine missions with relatively large environments to play around, which alone I am personally more than satisfied with. Then, does its weak story affect the enjoyment of the game? Absolutely not. In actual fact, the entire game can practically be played without paying too much attention to the story as long as you complete your objectives successfully, thanks to Dishonored's gameplay.

Conclusively, Dishonered is a mechanically brilliant stealth game, if not the best in recent years, and a true modern homage to the classic Thief games. It hits that sweet spot in its gameplay. With new interesting mechanics added on top of staple elements from the stealth genre to keep things fresh and a myriad of possibilities to approach the mission objectives, Dishonered is a blast. Where it lacks in story and characters to care about, it compensates in one of the most satisfyingly fluent gameplays and level designs in a stealth game. It really is the type of game where its gameplay outshines everything else, even with its small issues. So if you like stealth games, then Dishonored is for you.

reviewText:
One of the best games I've ever played.

I came to it late, having only seen screenshots with a lot of sword-fighting and shooting, but as usual the major reviews did the game a disservice, because Dishonored is so much more than that.

Firstly, you don't have to harm anyone.  You don't even have to be SEEN by anyone.  Play as the good guy who is out to right the wrongs done against him and the people of Dunwall, and the game will pan out differently to playing as the angry guy out for vengeance - with a totally different ending to go with it (incidentally, I recommend playing BOTH styles to experience two different games).  As a result, there can be a lot of stealth-play (if you choose that play-style) and it's all very well done (though the stealth mechanics are not quite up to the stealth mechanics of Thief).

Secondly, the art style is incredible - one of those games where you just want to take stock and look around.  It's a very atmospheric game, though as usual the story revolves around white male trying to rescue young female" (like we haven't seen that done to death already) and all the female NPCs are in some kind of servitude role or p♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s (Arkane loses some Brownie points for that).  But the story is incredibly well executed

reviewText:
Dishonored.All i have to say is,this is my favorite stealth-action game.A game themed with steampunk ''culture''
You are Corvo Attano,a protector of the Empress.After a trip,you go back to the tower of Dunwall,a place located in Dunwall,a city corrupted by a rat plague.So,you go to the Tower,to see the empress,and her daughter,Emily.Suddenly,you get attacked by assassins,and as a result,the Empress dies and they kidnap the young lady.The guards believe that you are the killer,and they lead you inside the prison.Your only option is to escape.Escape to save Emily,and take revenge.
This game gives you the freedom of choice.There are multiple endings depending on your actions.You want to go loud?Go,but there will be disadvantages.More enemies in the future.You go silently?less enemies for you.You prefer making the enemies go back to bed or kill them?You want to assassinate your targets,or let them live a different life?How do you want to go that place?From the sewres,from the main door,from the window?FREEDOM.
You have different abilities,from teleporting to summon rats as your minions.You've got 3 different weapons,a sword,a gun,and a crossbow.You can upgrade your weapons,give them different bullets to use.You can also use grenades.
I loved every single moment of this game.the way it gives you the option to deal with your quests exactly as you want.I would love to see a prequel,yes,a prequel.a background story of Corvo.

Story : 8/10
Gameplay : 10/10
Graphics : 8/10
Sound :9/10
Conclusion : 8,75/10

reviewText:
It's disheartening to see how Arkane Studios appears to be the only developer still around which has the necessary skills to take usually overlooked vertical exploration and rich level design to such a, pardon the pun, high degree. So much so they can rightfully be placed at the very essence of Dishonored which revels and is at its best when it lets you explore the extremely well designed world of Dunwall which absolutely oozes atmosphere and character at every corner, but is sadly diminished by its poorly constructed and even worse, poorly executed narrative of the main story which leads to unsatisfying revelations and tacked on abrupt ending not redeemed in the least by an epilogue. This carries over to characters and their own stories which end up being very forgettable and merely serving a purpose.

Things are just as conflicted in the gameplay department where game offers multiple ways to go about your bloody business, but then proceeds to hamstring your stealth approach with very limited arsenal of tools at your disposal, at least compared to a more violent route which gives you much more freedom and utility. There are also customary problems associated with stealth AI detection and rats getting in the way of devouring your unconscious enemies which leads to some no kill failure states. Some of the non-violent target solutions could've also used a bit more challenge and less contrivance in some cases, but it's nothing worth writing a paragraph about and can be waved away.

In the end Dishonored is a widely uneven game, but one who's faults fail to overshadow the positives in the grand scheme of things. Shame I didn't get to tackle the DLC, but it's something for the future because Dishonored is most certainly worthy of replaying.

reviewText:
Although it's advertised under the stealth genre, Dishonored is, more or less, what you make of it. Dunwall, the game's focal city and capital of the empire, is in the midst of crisis. Its beloved empress has been assassinated, and you - her bodyguard Corvo - have the blame thrust upon you simply for being in the wrong place at the wrong time. Her daughter, and proper heir to the throne, is kidnapped by those truly responsible for her mother's death. Meanwhile, the destabilized empire struggles to contain an outbreak of plague, which has been spreading throughout the city at unprecedented speeds.

Armed with an arsenal of gadgets and powers, Corvo must traverse his way through the rapidly dilapidating urban center of Dunwall. Your mission is to rescue heir Emily and clear your name: the mastermind of the assassination has seized power and appointed his fellow conspirators to key positions in the government. It is here where the game begins, freed from prison by unexpected benefactors. How you choose to accomplish your goals will greatly affect the city, others' opinions of you, and the game's outcome; should Corvo indiscriminately slaughter the innocent and guilty along the way, Dunwall will visibly deteriorate throughout the course of the game. Conversely, it's possible to complete the game through entirely nonlethal means - and young Emily will be watching, influenced by her role model's moral compass.

Dishonored is unique in that two different people can approach the game with two separate playstyles and come away with two different impressions. There is a lot more depth to the game's story than meets the eye and while the nonlethal ending is far more fulfilling, the lethal and nonlethal routes will yield two very different games.

If you are a fan of stealth-based gameplay, adapting your movements carefully to avoid detection, you should be delighted with Dishonored. If you prefer to steamroll your way through haphazardly, you may be less impressed.

I deleted my old review for the sake of writing a new one. This is the first game I reviewed and I don't think my old one did this title any justice.

First of all, let me preface this by saying that this is, hands down, no holds barred, my favorite game. Ever. Of all time. Everything from the atmosphere to the gameplay to the replayability is just... It's flawless.

reviewText:
If Bioshock, Thief, and Deus Ex had a weird three way relationship and then somehow had a kid, this game would be it. In short, Dishonored gives gameplay choice with style.

I am a fan of both Deus Ex and Bioshock, however dislike Thief a lot. When I first started playing Dishonored, I was hesitant to play it due to it's familiarity to Thief. Nevertheless, Dishonored didn't give me some boring experience I haven't tried yet. Ground breaking, not quite. Different? Definitely.

You start out as the main character Corvo who is framed for killing an empress and for kidnapping her daughter. The character gets convicted then thrown into jail. There is an underground revolution at work nonetheless and manage to break Corvo out. It's the revolutionaries versus the order, with some random mix of weirdos in between (zombie like people who will bite you in the lower levels of the streets or sewers).

The game play is inclusive in inviting Bioshock's special abilities (like teleporting or summoning a heard of rats to attack someone) and mimics it's ability to pick up items/ammo. This I'm not a big fan of as you'll have to point specifically to the item and press X. Ideally, pressing X should just pick up everything. Moving on; the game follows Deus Ex in a sense where you can pick up a few objects to cause distractions (throwing bottles and the sort). Stealth seems similar to DE, but the indicators that are given in-game to notify the player of the enemies awareness level is fantastic. The meter can fill up pretty quick, but none the less is an appreciated addition to the game. The stealth seems fairly accurate when moving around, and getting caught can suck as enemies won't be afraid to flank you from behind. When playing, the player can choose to wield a gun and a sword, or a special power and a sword. Don't expect to get loads of ammo to blow everyone's head off as choosing when to use it can get you out of tight scenarios. There are variances such as crossbows in lieu of a gun. The sword is a neat feature and plays a vital role in sneaking up behind opponents to deliver their execution. Additionally, you could choose to choke them out rather than killing them. Either way, the player grabs the body and there is a chance to press x to quick carry. You are also able to block with sword with RB, and when timed right, the player can do a quick counter attack. Taking massive amounts of enemies head on is not recommended in this game as it can lead to death very quickly. Dodging and blocking at this point becomes funny as swords begin to fly from every which angle. Another neat feature (which sort of showed the Wolfenstein part of this game) is when you press Y to lean, you can lean left and right to peek around corners. I have to mention jumping from platform to platform (or even climbing them) is extremely smooth and forgiving. This is probably one of the best features of the game; you can use your special instant teleport power to get to a higher ground, but even if you come short, you can teleport and then by holding forward you can still climb up. Quite neat if you ask me and an excellent feature of the game!

Visuals are comparable to Bioshock art style. Some of the views are awesome and the characters designs and dynamic. The dialogue can be slow for some but can be worth the listen to others. Sounds are all appropriate and the sound of the blunderbuss going boom is nice.

The saving scheme is awesome. Auto save is featured as well as the ability to save at your disposal (not when in trouble though).

Overall, the game delivers an enjoyable single player experience. If there was a local co-op feature or even multiplayer I'm sure there would have been a lot of added re playability here. I would recommend this game to people who look for single player games that give a bit of a challenge, or to Bioshock fans. I like this game, but not to the point of drooling over it. It's a good game, I'll give it that. What I would like to see in a sequel (maybe), is more control over the sword. Have the player press LT then swing with the joystick or the sort, so it doesn't feel like I'm simply pressing a button.

Rating : 7.8/10

I'm on the fence for buying it full price, on a sale price if you like single player games, I would say go nuts.

ScreenShots :
The movement system tries to incorporate all basic locomotion including jumps

Carrying corpses is relatively easy in the game

Objects can be thrown at people or as distractions. You cannot pick up anything in abundance such as Deux Ex

Stats are also shown at the end of each level

Neat gimmicks such as climbing down a chain, add a bit more fun to what you can do

In-game scenery visual

reviewText:
Chaos
Dishonored stealth has a chaos element in it which provides the game with an interesting slate compared to other stealth games. When people get eaten by rats or killed by you they are marked as dead and increases chaos. Which will in turn make guards more alert and make it harder to stealth future segments. It also affects the population more and more as you go through the game.

Stealth
The stealth is pretty good but what makes it great is the abilities that help you out. Being able to quickly move up and down floors so you can get into a good position to stalk guards to either knock out or kill is fun. Though usually you have to make sure that you do it in a way that allows you time to prevent his friends from seeing him knocked out or his body just resting there.

Skills
Well there is two types of skills really, nonlethal and lethal. If you are trying to avoid killing there is some skills you will not even want to bother to invest in at all. This could have been structured a bit clearer for people new to the game so that they can select skills that are proper for their playthroughs.

reviewText:
This is one of the best games I've played in a long time.
I love this game so much. There's so many choices too.
You can either kill your enemies, or knock 'em unconscious with either a sleep dart or a chokin'.
You can find alternative paths to get to where you need to go by either walking trough the front door and main route, or possessing rats and going through vents, or Blinking (short-range teleporting) over rooftops.
You can also choose to save or kill some people throughout the story.

I finished the main story in about 17 hours.
The DLC is great too. The DLC features two new story modes where you play as another character at the same time as the main story just from a different point of view, which is damn awesome.
If you don't have this game, buy the Game of the Year (GOTY) edition (with all the DLC included.)
If you have the game, but not the DLC, by the DLC, for God's sake!
I can't wait for the sequel! I am so excited. I'll instantly pre-order it on Steam once it's on Steam for pre-orderin'.

Edit: There's a thing that I don't like about this game. It's not anything about gameplay, voice acting, the story, graphics, et cetera. It's about the subtitles. I noticed some grammatical mistakes in the subtitles, including who's" instead of "whose
recommended:
et cetera.
For a game this amazing made by a big company, I'd expect better subtitle writers.
They should've at least got a Grammar Nazi to double-check the subtitles.
This is not a huge deal, but it's rather sad that the subtitles aren't 100% grammatically correct for a game this amazing, but hey, nobody's perfect, I got to work it, again and again 'til I get it right. Nobody's perfect, you live and you learn it, and if you mess it up sometimes, nobody's perfect.

reviewText:
A great game that has consequences based on how you play whether you're aggressive and kill everyone or a pacifist and sneak past everyone.
One of the best if not the best first person stealth games I've ever played in my life. The addition of supernatural powers just gives the game more options for the player to finish a mission which can already have many alternate ways to complete.

9/10

reviewText:
This is a wonderful game. Whether you want to hack and slash your way to victory or hide in the shadows is up to you. Whether you want to utilize the supernatural powers given to you to achieve your goals, or just stick to flesh and steel is up to you. The game will flow how you want it to flow. Your decisions and actions have consequences that you will notice later on in the story; in which is very immersive.

The simple story and lore behind this game is amazing. There's so much to borrow from this game in the event that you want to create something of your own because it is so damn unique - nothing like it. The ways of life and the general environment of Dunwall is so bizzare that it is interesting. You can't quite slap a label on it and have that label be accurate, because it's something of its own and not just something crafted after a specific category.

You have the ability to go through the storyline as many times as you like. There may be something you missed the last time, or just a new way to go about completing it that you did not do before. All up to you, bud.

Seriously, though. Buy the game and all its DLC.

reviewText:
Stealth-FPS with some little RPG Elements in it.

The atmosphere is amazing (reminded me a lot of Half Life 2/City 17 sometimes).
The art style is pretty unique, steampunk-like and totally delivers. The gameplay is also very good and i felt that both ways, stealth and action, were equally well done.

Though, the story, or at least the presentation, fell a bit short.
I didn't really cared for the characters much, nor was the story presented in a way, that i was really drawn into it.

Overall it's a pretty good game, which, for me, lacks a bit of story/presentation.

Give it a go if you like stealthy FPS.

reviewText:
Bayağı oldu inceleme yazmayalı. Bunun en büyük nedeni 1 saat 2 saat oynayıpta inceleme yazmayı sevmiyorum. Kısa bir oyunsa bitirdikten sonra yazmayı tercih ediyorum. Yok değilse en azından inceleme yazacak kadar oynama taraftarıyım. Bazen görüyorum; adam yardırmış, giydiriyor oyuna. Oynama süresine bakıyorum; 15-20 dk, oyunun vaadettiği süreye bakıyorum 50 saat 60 saat hatta bazen 100 saat. Ben bu incelemenin nesini dikkate alayım. Destan yazın demiyorum ama 50 saatlik senaryousu olan oyuna da 15 dk oynayıp inceleme yazmayın. Gerçekten komik oluyor.

İçimi döktükten sonra gelelim incelemeye. Eski pc min über berbatlığı yüzünden bir türlü oynayamadığım oyunlardan biriydi Dishonored. Düşünün şu anki pc imle 100 küsür fpslerde oynadığım Dishonored eski pc imde medium da 30 fps yi zor görüyordu. Optimizasyonun ne kadar mükemmel olduğunu burdan da anlayabilirsiniz ve tabi eski pc min über berbatlığını :) Kısmet bugünlereymiş. Neyse güç olsun da güç olmasın diyerekten devam edeyim.

En sonda söyleyeyim; oyun çok çok güzel. Özellikle oynanış kısmı mükemmel. Hele bir de gamepadiniz varsa alacağınız keyif 3-5 e katlanıyor.  Dishonored size inanılmaz bir serbestlik sunuyor. Gizlilik/aksiyon türünde bir oyun olmasına rağmen sizi hiçbir şeye zorlamıyor. İlla bu yoldan gideceksiniz" diye bişey yok oyunda. Tamamen size kalmış. İster milleti doğraya doğraya gidin. İster hiçkimseyi öldürmeyin
date:
isterseniz hiç farkedilmeden ilerleyin. Tamamen size kalmış.

Grafiklere gelecek olursak çok iyi diyemem ama çokta kötü değil oyunun temasına uygun olmuş. Açıkçası gerçekçi grafikler yakışmazmış bu oyuna. Oynadıkça onu farkettim. Zaten bi yerden sonra grafik umrunuzda olmuyor ki bu çoğu oyun için geçerli. Oyun kaliteliyse bir şekilde oynatıyor kendini.

Dishonored bir intikam hikayesi. Bi görev dönüşünde kraliçe öldürülür ve kızı kaçırılır. Suç bizim üzerimize kalır ve hapse gireriz. İdamımızı beklerken bir şekilde hapisten kaçmayı başarır ve kraliçenin kızını aramaya koyuluruz. Bir yandan da adımızı temize çıkarmak için uğraşırız. Biraz klişe bir hikaye ama ucu açık bitiyor Dishonored 2 nin duyurulduğundan hiç haberiniz bile olmasa oyunu bitirdikten sonra "bunun mutlaka devamı gelir" diyorsunuz.

Uzun lafın kısası; hala bugüne kadar oynamadıysanız ilk fırsatta mutlaka satın alın ve oynayın. Parasını sonuna kadar hak eden bir yapım olmuş. Ben oyunu yüksek kaos ta bitirdim. Gerçi son 5 bölümün 4 ünde öldürdüğüm insan sayısı 10 bile değildi ama başlarda katliam yaptım resmen ondan sanırım. Ama siz mümkün olduğunca gizli ilerlemeye çalışın böylece hem itemlerinizi fazla harcamak zorunda kalmazsınız hem de mermi/ok sıkıntısı çekmezsiniz. Ayrıca araştırmacı olun. Direkt göreve gitmeyin.

reviewText:
Eldritch whales and an equally alien brand of black magic, a deadly plague and a bloody chain of events sparked by the death of an Empress and the disappearance of her daughter.

Dishonored is dark, visceral and at times outright disgusting with how filthy the environments are. Yet at the same time this game is absolutely gorgeous, from its aesthetic design to its soundtrack.

Dishonored is absolutely rich with detail, from the technology powering the city of Dunwall to the strange world the Outsider draws you into, and the powers he grants you. A lot of love was put into building this world, and it really pays off to explore the locations you are sent to – in the literal sense as well as the figurative, for there are many bonus rewards (Runes, Whale bone charms, etc) hidden throughout each area. Hell, even eavesdropping on the NPCS and enemies has its benefits, for the characters' dialogue will change depending on your actions and how Chaotic Dunwall is because of said actions. Plus it's a handy way to learn secrets and additional information about your current objectives.

Every time I start this game over I find myself taking different routes towards my targets; from the tiny rat tunnels to the rooftops, there's always some new, alternate way to get to the sorry ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you've been assigned to kill, plus there are a dozen different ways to kill said targets. Assassinating is cinematic and satisfying, and the animations fluid. However the more enemies there are the harder it gets to fight back, so it really is better to avoid large scale confrontations. Unless of course you have the very expensive yet extremely useful Lvl 2 Time Warp ability. Then it's a walk in the park.

I could seriously sing praise to this game for paragraphs, but I will keep this review short.

Although I have been told it is not the absolute best stealth game on the market, it is my favourite one to date. 10/10!

P.S: StealthGamerBR's Dishonored videos are insane. This guy is seriously talented. Check them out!

reviewText:
Introduction
Want a game that makes you feel immersed by its colorful and peaceful atmosphere? A game where you could explore the world to its unimaginable limits? Last but not least, a game that is immensely moddable? Well, this game is not for you!

Dishonored is an underdog game developed by Arkane Studios that brings you to a new universe filled with government corruption, discrimination towards the lower-middle class, and rat plague.

You'll be able to play as the disgraced lord protector, Corvo Attano, who seeks revenge towards those who... 'dishonored' him... -along with the Outsider's powers that apparently requires you a lot of mana potions for you to do some rad killstreaks. That unless you want a stealthy approach, then prepare to load your game every single moment the enemy spots you for ridiculous reasons.

If you have the DLCs, The Knife of Dunwall and The Brigmore Witches, you'd also be playing as the master assassin, Daud, who journeys through Dunwall discovering the mystery of a powerful Witch who deems to rule the city (and soon the world). His goal is to stop her evil plan to justify the guilt trip that he had after what he did.

Review
The game is close enough to being a masterpiece if not because of the difficulty it lacks (there's a mod for that apparently), the strange bugs that haven't been fixed after 2-3 years, and the nerve wracking plot. However, it was still able to live up as one of the greatest games that came out as a first title to a new franchise. It gave us a fresh feeling to a new game by giving us a powerful yet stealthy assassin that has a mix of first-person combat and cheap parkour. It has some sort of semi-rpg aspects put into it since there are sub-quests scattered all around the area during your mission and there are choices you make that slightly affects the environment of the next mission and the game's ending.

THE PROS

As you dwell into the plot, you'd think that the whole story would be cliched. You are right. However, it won't be a linear one. The game gives you a choice or rather an opportunity that would affect the last chapter of the game. In fact, the main story is more dynamic than an Elder Scrolls game but less dynamic than a Fallout game. The books that you probably wouldn't read includes the game's lore of the city and outside of it and some journals that once you look at the corpse who wrote it, you'd feel bad for him/her. Seriously, those rotting couples who died while hugging each other and being surrounded by plague rats, and an enemy guard that has an infected friend who wanted to euthanize him; these started to hit me right in the feels after reading their last words written on a letter... It shows how cruel the plague has lead to the people of Dunwall.

In terms of gameplay, the developers were somehow able to make the game pass through that awful area that we call: repetitiveness. As mentioned a while ago, the game gives us varied ways to go through the objective. On each mission, there are sewers, open hallways, alleys, or hidden passage ways for you to decide whether you go rampage mode or go Thief style sneaking through every living obstacle. Even though the upgrades were only few, upgrading one skill already delivers an impact to the gameplay.

Other than that, the graphics are the ones that surprised me out of all the stuffs I've experienced in this game. The developers have learned that even mere textures and right lighting could make a visually compelling atmosphere without having high-poly models and applying the frame killing Ambient Occlusions. An eye trick as what it seems. What more if you add a graphic enhancer mod to it.

The audio gave a decent feel into the game's surroundings. The soundtracks were so emotional that it immersed me throughout my playthrough. They made a way to make the ambience feel lively even if the area wasn't crowded. Overall, it's decent.

THE CONS

Here's the part where it gets slightly bad. On the plot of the main story, the part where your 'allies' tell the things you do for the mission doesn't make sense for me since they themselves never tend to help you at all! Captain: Corvo
date: kill this man in order to cripple the main boss! Now if you'll excuse me
recommended: the other loyalists and I will just stay here in the pub and intensify our tea-sipping as you kill 50 men on your way." The DLC story although fixed that by giving you the power to summon your allies and fight with you
hoursPlayed: but the main story of the game apparently never had such.\n\nGoing back to gameplay
voteText: there are cases in the game where it starts to glitch out such as when you have to bring an unconscious body to someone for a non-lethal approach of the mission. Once you go near to the person who told you the objective while bringing the body
helpfulPercent: it will go to a scene where the conversation starts and your character will drop the unconscious body which somehow lead to his/her death. Thus
votesHelpful: your non-lethal objective failed. There are also some cases where you just wanted to hide the body
votesTotal: but as you gently drop them near a movable object
votesFunny: it's possible that when they hit the object
commentsCount: they'll die. It's one of those annoying things if you wanted to achieve something in the game.\n\nEven though the UI settings was well implemented (though
column16: you can't turn off the item selection UI whenever you bind them to your hotkeys)
column17: it's hard to say the same thing with the graphics options. Obviously
column18: it lacks options.\n- AA only has 3 options: Off
column19: MLAA
column20:
and FXAA
- There are no Shadow options at all
- The Rat Shadows doesn't even work even if you toggle it On!
- Level of Detail options don't exist
You may ask why are all of these mentioned when they're practically unnecessary; it's because there's actually an option for that if you look into a/an .ini file! You can even change the density of the particles
column21: turn up the textures that is beyond the in-game texture settings
column22: and increase the intensity of Anti-Aliasing and Anisotropic Filtering! Other than that
column23: there are those very VERY low-res textures even if the textures were set on high. Even a 2000s game could beat this (that would be those Source engine games).\n\nLastly on the audio
column24:
the guard dialogues were repetitive that it ended up being funny whenever you hear them; the rest of the characters however were good as it's not overly exaggerated nor dead boring.


Verdict
Concept        Rating                Main Plot        7/10 (+DLCs 9/10)
+ Dynamic story depending on your actions
+ (DLC) Plot Twists
- Main story is predictable and linear
- A couple of questionable plot holes
- cliche cliche cliche
Gameplay        8/10 (+DLCs 7.8/10)
+ Gametime of 1 to 30 hours depending on your style of gameplay
+ Lots of choices with a different experience on each
+ Each power upgrade matters
- A few bugs/glitches
- (DLC) Daud's Powers are OP!
Graphics        8/10
+ Visually stunning environments
+ Surprisingly smooth FPS while maintaining the current gen graphics
- Lacks graphic options
- Some really low-res textures on certain areas
Audio        8/10
+ Decent yet immersive soundtracks
+ Ambience? Good.
+ Upright voice acting
- "Think you'll get your own squad after what happened last night?" (10x)

OVERALL: 8/10 - Great game for a new franchise
OVERALL (+DLCs): 8.9/10 - DLCs are the ones that spiced it up"

reviewText:
I want to start out by saying this game IMO deserves a 9/10. I highly encourage you to pick this game up, upon reading this review! It's a great game, and I loved every second of it!

There really aren't many negative things to say, but I do have a one or two. Let's start with the PROS.

PROS

*Stealth- You can play this game with out much confrontation. Sneak around, sparing the lives of your enemies. (The more blood you  shed, the darker the game's outcomes will be in multiple ways.) Their are many ways to silently, and humanely dispose of your foes, with out shedding too much bodily fluid, but at the same time, you can slit their throats, and leave them choking on their own blood, or send crossbolts into their flesh, unknowingly. Maybe if you're feeling the urge to see your enemies scatter in fear, you can rewire, and turn their own defenses against them, witnessing the cool breeze taking their warm, dry ashes with it. Don't feel like a coward if you need to run away. It is a very huge part of the stealth gameplay. The best part, is that you can not only run, but jump, climb, slide your way into the shadows or roof tops, leaving your pursuers to fumble around in the gnarly, Brined Hagfish scented crop dust you left for them to choke on. Their are many ways to neutralize your enemies

reviewText: What we have here is a case of a developer who knew exactly what kind of game they wanted to make and executed that vision near flawlessly. The game is a blast to play and the ability to choose how to best exact your revenge is extremely satisfying. Even the story DLC is better than most standalone games. Plus the guy who did visual designs for Half-Life 2 worked on this so this is as close as you'll get to visiting City 17 again.\n\nThis sh*t would be worth it even if you bought it at full price.

reviewText: A well-made game where the player's choices greatly impact the outcome of not just the ending but later in the game as well, Dishonored puts you in the position of Corvo Attano, in an alternate world 1837 filled with magic, corruption, advanced technology, and a revenge-seeking dishonored assassin.\n\nI have played Dishonored's main storyline so many times I lost count long ago (but enough times to say almost all of the dialogue along with the characters), then purchased and used every single DLC for it and played them through several times as well, and now I can say that this is actually one of my favorite games. Compared to the Fallout and Elder Scrolls series, Dishonored is one of Bethesda's lesser known games, denying it of much of the fame and love it deserves.

reviewText: I played through this game only once and I felt like I missed a good amount of the content.  I was a little disappointed that I was only told that the number of people I killed influenced the state of the story and city after a couple of levels where I had already killed a number of people.  After that I Primarily used nonlethal takedowns.  Even for characters who were targets of a mission, I chose the stealthy and sneaky way to kill as few people as possible,  but everybody still reveared me as a mass murderer, so for the last few levels I just said screw it and killed everybody.  Stealthing is pretty fun, but the combat mechanics feel kind of clunky.  Perhaps they meant for it to be this way to encourage you to be sneaky.  Although, the problem I found with going full sneaky-beaky is that there would be a lot of weapons and powers that you would never be able to use since they are loud and explody and cause your enemies to be eaten by a swarm of rats as they scream in agony.  So either way It feels like you can't get the whole experience of the game in just one playthrough.  That was my main issue.  Other than that, it was entertaining.

reviewText:
Overall, it's like the stealth version of BioShock. Dishonored is heavily based on stealthy approach to complete the missions and you'll be given a lot of choices to determine the outcome of your current mission's story, the other character's dialogue and behavior, plus the ending.  Like BioShock, you'll have a weapon (unlike BioShock, sword only) on your right hand and multiple tools on your left hand, both controllable individually. The difference is, Dishonored has way less choices of supernatural powers and weapons. The combat only focuses on melee combat even you're given a flintlock-like pistol and a crossbow as a ranged weapon.
Here's the goods and the bads of the game:

Pros:
+ Another beautifully written story for a video game
+ Challenging combat. you are not extremely OP like in most other games, but also not awkwardly animated like Chivalry: Medieval Warfare's sword fight
+ Your actions and decisions will decide the outcome of the story
+ Supernatural powers, even though it's very limited (new powers for the DLC campaign) but it's still very fun to use. Just like BioShock, you hold the magic power on your left hand while your right hand will hold a weapon (in this case, sword only)
+ A lot of choices to complete your missions. Different approaches are available each with their own consequences and benefits.
+ DLC is also pretty good, telling a story that's happening on the other side with a character that will eventually meet your main character on the main story. If you like challenges, one of the DLC offers a complete set of challenges that will test your in-game combat, stealth, and agility skill.
+ Enemy types varies just like Assassin's Creed even though the enemies in Dishonored don't have any weaknesses that can be exploited.
+ Collectibles, hidden objects to power up, hidden rooms, etc. If you love those kind of things, this game's totally for you. Mostly, you'll have to sniff around and explore almost every corner of the map in order to level up your powers properly.
+ Pretty good graphics, but not great.

Cons:
- Horrible character graphics, they only have very limited models plus lack of details sometimes make it very obvious that a lot of duplicates are walking around.
- Story outcome solely based on your capability to stealth. A stealthy and merciful playstyle will save the entire kingdom while aggressive and murderous playstyle will throw the kingdom into a deeper pit of chaos since all your actions will be taken example of by the upcoming Empress.
- Kills are limited on every level (around 15 each mission if you want a good outcome) which makes this game pretty weird. An assassin who is not allowed to kill anyone, seriously? You must use non-lethal weapons if your stealth fails and stuck in inescapable conflict.
- I'm no fan of finding hidden objects which are usually very far and way too tedious to find it and I'm sure I'm not the only one. Lack of power upgrades will make stealth much harder.
- Some maps are confusing, especially the Brigmore house in the DLC
- Sword range is weird, the animation won't show the sword reaches you but you will still get hit. Sword blocks sometime fail to work during this time.

TL;DR If you like BioShock, you'll like this game. It's almost the same thing, just much more limited weaponry and choices. But if you hate stealth games, don't buy this game. It is solely based on stealth, nothing more.

reviewText: It feels like a Mixtape between Bioshock Infinite and Thief.  It's about revenge; armed with deadly weapons and supernatural powers, you seek vengeance upon all of those who orchestrated your downfall. It's about a city; the plague-ridden industrial port of Dunwall is lovely to behold, exciting to explore, and seething with secrets. It´s about rescueing a little girl the daughter of the murdered Queen.\nThe Story is very exciting and its told in a good way..not too much and not too less. So you are never bored and have to skip videos and you also know always why you do what you do. The incredible variety of ways you can engage or evade your enemies is impressively flexible and utterly captivating. The Graphics are fine. Im using an old 2 Core Computer atm..it runs perfectly smooth on it, so it got very well programmed. I didnt see any Bugs. It has easy controls and also Full Controller Support, both work perfectly fine. I cant say anything negative about this game. If you love Games like Bioshock Infinite or Thief then defenetily buy it. Its in the sales for 3,24 € and its worth minimum 20 € compared to the quality of this game, so im very pleased with it.

reviewText:
Disonored is a first person stealth game. Highly atmosperic and immersive, it tells an amazing story and puts you in control throughout it's duration.

The game starts out easy enough but soon after throws you into the lions den. As the title suggests, you are dishonored and stripped of your status and thrown into prison after a certain event transpires. It is here the game makes brilliant use of a stalking/cover mechanic as you are forced to escape your binds. You are able to peek around corners to remain unseen and you always have the option of a non violent approach. Sneak up behind and knock them out or bury your sword into their neck, the choice is yours. When combat is initiated, you have a plethora of options open to you. You hold your sword in your right hand and have the option of equiping crossbows, pistols and powers in your left. Careful timing of your block opens enemies up to counter attack and choose to put an arrow in their skull, blast a musket ball into their chest or finish them with your sword. There are options open to you even if you are in combat, to resolve the situation non violently if you choose. Options include sleep syringes shot from your crossbow or using your powers to disappear into the darkness. But be carefull, killing all in your path has a negative effect and can drastically change each mission and the world as a whole.

Some of the powers at your disposal include a blink ability to quickly teleport and (but not limited to) conjuring a swarm of rats to attack and eat your enemies. There are several other powers but I dont want to spoil the surprise. I will say there are powers to purchase and upgrade that will suit any playstyle. You purchase powers and upgrades by finding runes hidden throughout each level. Some can be bought and others found. There is an item that puts markers on runes and charms when used so you never have to leave any behind. Charms you can collect and find, offer passive bonuses like being able to choke out an enemy faster or that make a power more potent. There are tons of charms to find so the combinations are endless. Up to 6 can be equipped at a time unless you have the DLC which allows you to equip up to 10.

Between missions, you have a home base to buy equipment and upgrades. Here is where you recieve your next mission and often are given clues about side missions to complete while tackling the main. This is a large area packed with lots of goodies to find and people to talk to.

The story in Dishonored is stellar. Events always unfold in first person and there are no camera shifts the break immersion. The voice acting cast has stars like Susan Sarandon and Brad Dourif just to name a couple and they do an awesome job of fleshing out their characters.

There really is no complaint I can level against Dishonored. It is a masterpiece and multiple playthroughs using different tactics never dull the fun. From its beautiful graphics, story, characters, weapons, powers and atmosphere to its high replayability, there really is nothing wrong about the game. Anyone that enjoys first person games with emphasis on stealth and combat, with RPG elements sprinkled in, will enjoy Dishonored.

reviewText:
I honestly didn't expect to love this game so much. But it has quickly become my favorite.

The design of the city is amazing. The story is great. There are many different approaches to completing the tasks, which makes the game entertaining even if you play it over and over. You can kjill everyone in your way, or choose to kill noone. You can create chaos, or stay completely in the shadows. However the more poeple you kill, and the more chaos you make, the more rats and weepers you encounter.

One more thing: the DLCs are absolutely fantastic. I especially loved Knife of Dunwall and Brigmore Witches DLCs, which together tell Dauds story from the point in time, when he assassinated the Empress. You pretty much get a second game.

reviewText: Dishonored is a fantastic, original game with a great art style and soundtrack. I enjoyed all the missions, although The Golden Cat was my favorite. Even though the graphics are not superb, the game looks so unique that you will not care. It is fun to use the powers, sneak around, and even have shootouts with the guards, and since the main part of the game is supposed to be stealth, it has some of the best stealth gameplay on the market. The Dunwall City Trials DLC that comes with the Game of the Year edition is worth it if you can get it for $2.50, but it is nothing like The Knife of Dunwall or the Witches of Brigmore, two DLC single-player campaigns that are shorter but are just as high quality as the main game. If you enjoy Skyrim's Dark Brotherhood, Thief, or games like those, then this is the game for you. If you are going to buy Dishonored, make sure to get the Game of the Year edition.

reviewText:
Yes, I would recommend this game!
Simply because it's simple and one of the few games I had interest to finish (and actually did).

The good things:
- The game mechanics work really really smooth and execute well, meaning you don't have to try five times (to blink / teleport) to actually succeed.
- Even on my old machine, this game runs good without any problems (after setting everything to low and no shadows)
- Speaking of game mechanics, they are very easy to use, which is good for a bad gamer like me. You don't have to to precise jumping and quickloading five times because you missed that effin platform or balcony. If you can reach that platform, a symbol in the lower HUD will tell you and you just have to press the jump-button and done.
- Although many reviews state otherwise in their respective opinion, I liked the story. Good old revenge driven killing. What else do you need?
- Running, jumping and teleporting is pure FUN. Because it works. It's just the problem it's sometimes limited by the map.
- The combat feels GREAT. Your pistol has a great impact and your enemies fly like kicked by a mule. The swordfight feels very satisfying. I had nothing to complain about here.
- The steampunkish flair is great and well made.

The bad thing:
- This game would be even better if it would be a free roaming game and if you could go visit / go berzerk on a whole city. Instead of this, you have single fragments of a city / map where you are kinda very limited to which way you use. (Direct confrontation and blasting your way through or going stealth.)
- The enemies have almost no variation. There are soldiers, sometimes dogs, a few assassins sometimes walkers and some civilians. And that's it.
- It felt kinda short. I played it for a lot of hours (because I dont have any skills) but I think a good gamer will finish this game in a few hours. Atmost.
- That puking animal/vegetable things are as annoying and useless as the monsters in THIEF 1 are.

Conclusion:
It's a good game, really, well made, nice graphics, good sounds, a great lore (which can be read in books (which I didn't)) and overall. It just lacks some bigger things, like more enemies, a whole city to explore.

reviewText:
From the creators of Deus Ex and Thief, with the talents of the art director from Half-Life 2 comes Dishonored, and man, does it ever show. The streets of Dunwall are like how City 17 might have been if it was in a world where magic and steampunk technology existed, and the threat wasn't from aliens but corrupt officials who stole power after a beloved leader died.

As Corvo Attano, you get to choose just how you'll seek your revenge; with bloody brutality, subtle killings, or neither. Much like Batman (and in Fallout), you can go through the entire game not killing anyone, and also like Batman, you can still manage to unnerve your opponents by doing so. There's no leveling system, but you do gain a limited amount of runes and money, which lets you customize your character to fit your playstyle. The world is enormous and there's lots of scripted events and passageways which exclude the other, so you will not be able to see everything in one playthrough.

One of those rare recent games worth buying right now, at full price. If it ever goes on sale and you still don't have it, then you certainly MUST jump on the opportunity and do so. Highly recommended.

I have played about 27 hours and all I can say is... holy ♥♥♥♥. The gameplay is so well made, the story is exciting but easy to understand, the voice actors are brilliant and the music is great.
This game is certainly the best stealth / FPS (steampunk) game that has been made.
The sad part of this game is that the story is very short and there is not so many easy choices between killing or not killing the enemies, and the surroundings are quite limited.
But otherwise, Arkane Studios have really made an awesome game doing all the right design decisions.
- 11/10

reviewText:
The good: I thoroughly enjoyed Dishonored's story and gameplay. Betrayal and revenge always make for good motives in a game. The fighting mechanics are fun. You have several cool toys and powers with which to battle your enemies. The art style is really nice; there are some beautiful scenes in the game. Lots of screenshot material. This game is all about player choice; there are always several different ways to complete any given objective and your choices throughout the game change the NPCs' reactions to you and the final outcome of the game. It's definitely cool to play in such a responsive environment and really helps with the immersion.

The bad: The game tends to lean on you to take a pacifist/minimal chaos route (you have fewer plague victims and rats to deal with, and you get a better final outcome). The guilt-tripping can kind of take the fun away from using your powers and weapons like a mad demon of vengeance, and stealthing your way through the whole game can get somewhat repetitive, since you really only have a couple of stealth options.

The good again: The Knife of Dunwall and Brigmore Witches DLCs seemed to take the boring-ness of a low chaos run into account. You have several more options for non-lethally dealing with your enemies, which helps break the monotony and provide you with a more varied stealth experience.

General info: The game is first person. It has a mission hub you return to frequently; the actual missions take place in a more open-world environment where you can explore, pick up side quests, and choose your own route to your destination (however, you cannot return to an area to pick up any missed side quests at a later time). The main game features a silent player character; the Knife of Dunwall & Brigmore Witches feature a speaking character as the player character. There is one DLC pack that gives you a few extra in-game items; it doesn't really overpower you or give you too much of an advantage, so it's not game breaking or anything. KoD & BW are story-based expansions. The Dunwall City Trials are a series of challenges; fun stuff after the main story is completed. The game itself can be a bit sad and gruesome at times; it really sets the tone for the story, but if that sort of stuff bothers you, you might want to give it a miss.

Overall: I really enjoyed this game and strongly recommend it.

System Specs Used: Intel Core i7-3610QM, Nvidia GeForce GTX 670M / 3GB GDDR5, DDRIII 12GB RAM, Windows 7

reviewText: Put simply, this is one of the very best games I have ever played. It bests Ocarina of Time, BioShock Infinte, Deus Ex: Human Revolution, etc. This is insanely replayable (on my third run as I write this). This is a game where you have many choices. Lethal or nonlethal, stealthy or guns blazing, different points of entry to buildings, etc. It fits anyone's ideal playstyle, whether that's combat or stealth. Arkane thought of everything with the level layouts. The atmosphere, level design, and setting are excellent. Dunwall may be my favorite video game setting ever. From what I've heard the DLC is even better than the main game. This game also presents a nice challenge, but even on Very Hard (my current run), the game is relatively easy once you get used to it. Dishonored, in my opinion, is one of the best video games ever made, and is in my personal top 5. I would give this game a 10. If I was stuck on a deserted island and I could only have three games with me, this would be my first choice. It's that damn good. I bought it for $4.99 and I feel like I've cheated Arkane here. I would have happily spent 60 at release for this game, and I will whenever a sequel releases. Just scroll up and go buy this game, even at full price. You WILL not regret it.\n\ntl;dr I love this game and probably sound like a paid shill but whatever 10/10

reviewText:
It is kind of late for a review for this game, but after my second playthrough I think I should tell you guys how great this game is.

You play in first person in a medieval world with magic and science.
You will start a level with at least one goal, sometimes the goals change or you get more goals or you can decide which of the ways to reach the goals you want to use. Mostly it is the decicion: Lethal or not lethal.
Inside the level you are free to go where you want.

You can play the whole game like DARK, you try to not to be seen, your only target is the mission goal.
Even if you do so, you can still decide if you kill at all. You WILL be responsible for dead/capture, but you can make it kind of... third parties fault.

The complete different approach is the killing spree.
If you use knife, crossbow, pistol, grenades, mines and magic to the fullest extend you can do incredible cool things.
You can freeze time and put a grenade in the hand of someone, take a bullet from the air, teleport behind an enemy to strangle him, send rats to eat your enemies alive or blast them against walls.
You can take over a fish or another animal and use different routes, take over a human and walk him out of the sight of others, reprogram towers to kill your enemies and so much more.

So you can either play the I-do-not-kill-guy with a good ending or the kill-all-enemies-guys with a bad or at least dark ending.

Either way, the game is fantastic.

I really love the graphics, I love the music and the gameplay is very smooth and fun.

The only thing which is not so good: the character faces are... don't know.. kind of ugly. All of them.

This game is a must play. At least once!
I did 2012 the killer-guy playthrough, 2014 the ghost - not in all levels :( - playthrough and now I will have some fun with mindless killing again :)

reviewText:
An excellent, albeit not great, FPS game!

If I had to summarize Dishonored in one sentence, that would be: A stealth-based Bioshock.

Truly the game's mechanics (weapons in one hand, magic in the other, plus a big variety of ways to -or not to- kill the enemies), dark story with enough twists and choise-based multiple endings reminded me a lot of Bioshock, though Dishonored comes as a lot more stealth based than the former (and personally less innovative than Bioshock, in my opinion).

Nonetheless, Dishonored is an excellent stealth game, thanks to its magical powers hiding becomes a lot simplified, compared to traditional stealth games like Metal Gear Solid or Splinter Cell and I can say even fun enough. Some magic powers like Blink, Possession and Time Bend, to name a few, were really innovative and cool to use.

The rest of the weapons (a pistol and a crossbow with various types of ammunition, a variety of grenades or mines, plus your standard sword) provide very brutal kills, for the FPS players wanting action and not stealth.

Basically the game is set so that the choices you make affect the ending and your deeds catch up to you: needlessly killing many characters in the game will result in the so called High Chaos and as so a bad ending, while sparing the lives of most enemies will result in the Low Chaos ending, the good one.

I'll have to admit though that I was expecting more from the main story, based on all the good reviews I had seen of the game, while I found it just ok: it had a few twists, but nothing as shocking as, say again, Bioshock. I'll admit that the story is quite dark though and full of betrayals and brutal killings, should the player decide to go that way.

While I usually find myself liking these multiple endings in games, Dishonored and it's achievements are set to make you play the game at the very least twice, so as to see both endings and collect each one's achievements, which, if you add the fact that the game's last two DLCs demand the same treatment, makes the game very time-devouring (took me about two months to get all the endings and achievements, without playing every day of course though).

Speaking of the games DLCs, there are three in total: the first one, Dunwall City Trials, is, as its name suggests, a set of various challenges and not related to the game's story, while the two latter ones, The Knife of Dunwall and The Brigmore Witches, show the story from the perspective of another character, the assassin Daud.

As it happens with many TV series spin-offs, I found myself enjoying the Daud DLCs a lot more than the main story, their duration was shorter and just enough to make you enjoy the game (even with both endings) and the connection they made to the main game made the story a lot more enjoyable. What helped it a lot, in my opinion, was the fact that I found it a lot easier to empathize with Daud, who has the opportunity to make amends for his past deeds and get his redemption, compared to the overall good-guy" assassin of the main game

reviewText: WOW what a game. I brought this game on sale and feel like I ripped off the developer. reviewText:
You begin the game as Corvo, Lord Protector of the Empress of Dunwall, but soon find yourself stripped of that title and imprisoned for her alleged murder. You must escape, clear your name and ultimately restore her daughter, Emily, to the throne.

You'll take on a string of missions through a city riddled with plague and corruption, taking out those in power by assassination or indirect means. Each mission involves several openly designed zones, where you may freely explore to find upgrades, ammo, coin and optional objectives along the way.

Both stealth and brute-force playstyles are viable, with a wide array of weaponry and powers at your disposal.  Blink instantly from point to point; possess rats and fish to tunnel your way in, or guards to walk them to a secluded area for disposal; stop time to sneak past a group of enemies or slaughter them all undetected; or just go in guns blazing.

A lot of fun, looks amazing, well-optimized, and has great level design.  Highly recommended; my single-player GOTY.

reviewText:
MAY CONTAIN MILD SPOILERS

If I had a list of the best stealth games I have ever played, Dishonored will be high on the list. Dishonored executes the stealth aspect just like I expected and even exceeded it. Why? You have ♥♥♥♥ing powers. Want to possess a person? Do it. Want to summon a horde of flesh eating rats? Do it. Dishonored gives you a lot of choices too. Go stealth or go kill everyone in sight. Kill the target or spare his/her life? All your choices will affect the story and thus the ending too.

There is great satisfication when killing your target. Drop killing especially, feels awesome. But why not kill everyone in sight? You can do so without anyone even touching you (but that doesnt mean the game is easy, it isn't). Sound badass right? Yes it is.

There are dissapointments though. The obvious one, as you may have known already (reading the reviews), the main story is too damn short and predictable. I finished mine in about 9 or so hours, in hard difficulty. The storyline too, for me, is too weak. I don't care about the soon-to-be empress that you are saving. She may die? I don't really care. All I want to do is to kill people.

The DLCs, though, has a way way better story. Also, you get more badass powers as Daud. Who cares about summoning rats when you can summon a master assassin anytime you like? Also stopping time every few seconds is so damn awesome. Seriously, buy all the dlcs, that is how awesome it is.

If you, for some reason, decide not to buy the dlcs (buy them!), the base game itself is a memorable experience. A masterpiece. So what are you waiting for? Buy Dishonored. You will be in for a real treat.

reviewText:
Screw Assassin's Creed, this is what a stealth game should be like. Dishonored is a first-person stealth adventure game that casts you into the role of Corvo Attano, a former bodyguard, now turned supernatural assassin all because the Empress of the city of Dunwall has been murdered and he has been framed for her death.

Everything about Dishonored is fantastic.

Pros:
+Enemy AI reacts to everything the player does, whether they have been seen or not.
+A wide variety of skills and weaponry makes every playthrough unique - take the silent route focused on stealth, or be ruthless and slaughter everything in sight.
+The art style and direction is awesome.
+Actions have consequences, and some of them can be quite significant...
+Excellent level design. If you can see a door in front of you, you most likely can open it. If you see a rooftop, you can climb to it. The possibilities when it comes to navigating levels are nearly endless!
+Likeable cast and characters.

Cons:
+Some of the textures look a little outdated when viewed close up, considering how this was released in 2012.
+A couple of characters exist merely as plot devices.

Overall, Dishonored is a fantastic game if you can overlook what it doesn't do quite right, and maximises what it does do right. The Knife of Dunwall and The Brigmore Witches DLC only adds to the sheer awesome that is this game, so I highly reccomend those too.

reviewText:
Dishonored is set in a dark Victorian Steam Punk world. You play as Corvo an assassin in service of the local empress. After her assassination a dark and gripping story begins. The world is a sort of decaying city where the economy thrives on whale oil and the strange technology is fuelled by the same oil.

The game is a FPS-style stealth game but you can choose to play more action oriented. However, this is not an action shooter! So no machine guns, rocket launchers, …

Your primary weapon is a sword and secondary a pistol and crossbow (for silent kills). Next to that you have grenades, mines and that’s it. Ammo is limited. You also dispose of several magic (super natural) abilities. By playing the game you will find objects (runes, coins…) to buy new abilities.

When you play you can choose different ways to complete the levels. Go stealth mode and try to kill no one or as little as possible or choose to play more action style.

I find the level design impressive, with a nice and original graphic style. The acting is also quite good. It took me 19 hours to complete the game.

I can also confirm that the game runs perfectly on ultra-wide displays in 21/9 aspect ratio. I tested it on a 2560*1080 resolution.

I highly recommend this game!

reviewText: This is a great game. It combines the multiple paths of classic games like Hitman, Deus Ex, and Thief with fantastic stealth and combat systems. You can be a total pacifist if you want, but if you do choose to kill, there are plenty of great ways to do it: stealthy assassinations, epic swordfights, carefully placed traps, crossbows and guns, or even just summon a huge swarm of rats to eat your enemies alive. Levels are huge. There's plenty of gold to find and safes to open. You are rewarded for exploring your environment instead of just focusing on the end goal. The game is quick to learn but hard to master. Easy enough that you won't have any trouble beating the game, but deep and difficult enough that there's always a new challenge offered. The plot isn't terribly great, but it's still pretty good. Enemy design is fantastic. Graphics won't have you gasping in awe, but they get the job done.\n\nThe game's only flaw is that it doesn't really do anything new. There are plenty of games similar to Dishonored. But what it does do, it does really well. It may not be groundbreaking, but it's still a solid game with tons of replayability. Perfect for the gamer who likes to set challenges for themselves, as well as players who found the original Hitman/Thief/Deus Ex games inaccessible. Definitely buy it.

reviewText:
Dishonored: A surprising smash-hit by relatively unknown developers at Arkane Studios. This game is easily one of my top ten favorite games of all time.
Dishonored is one of those games whose playstyle is respective to the individual playing it, it can either be a stealth game or an action game depending on your preferences with an ending that changes depending on how you played it.
The story I hate to admit isn't entirely grand in it's simplest form, the player takes on the perspective of Corvo Attano, a silent protagonist through which the player can more fully take on the role and suits the game's approach just fine. Corvo was the bodygaurd of the Empress who was falsely framed for her assassination by corrupt members of government, on the eve of his execution Corvo escapes prison with the help of unknown allies and begins his mission to either restore the city of Dunwall to it's former glory, or spiral down a path of bloodlust. Again, how the game is played is completely up to the player.
Gameplay can generally be summed up in two different playstyles, and the mechanics for both action and stealth are well polished and astounding. Action game fans will love Dishonored's dynamic combat systems, with highly reactive sword fighting and blocks that are intense and satisfying all together, this coupled with a combination of offhand weapons, gadgets and supernatural powers can lead to very creative methods of eliminating threats. The stealth mechanics are also well versed, encouraging the player to think logically and scout ahead to learn the best possible routes to your target, also encouraging exploration of this amazingly thought-out and unique setting to uncover hints and clues for your mission.
The setting of Dishonored is without a doubt one of the most amazing experiences to date, Dishonored takes place in Dunwall, a fictional city akin to London that is undergoing an industrial revolution, with advancements in steampunk technology and enhancing the quality of life, all would be going well for Dunwall if not for the recent disaster that has struck the populace: An aggressively spreading plague carried by rats is devastating the city and forcing extreme measures of quarantine which encourages brutality and corruption, creating a significant social bar among the uninfected.
If you're playing through a with a stealth approach then the enemies wont exactly matter, but for action types the player will find a large spectrum of enemies each offering different challenges that must be hurdled, from the flesh-consuming swarms of rats to the stilt-walking armored soldiers the action keeps a steady pace throughout, without being overly overwhelming (and even then, you're a supernatural-bloody-assassin, you can escape from combat incredibly easily).
A sour point on the experience with Dishonored is the occasional bug or glitch that may cause some errors with stats and gameplay. Sometimes for no reason, even if you were completely stealthy a guard may start acting like he's spotted you, patrolling around looking for you, and other times a bug may occur where the game will think you've killed someone when you were particularily careful not to kill.
As well, an unsettling flaw with the dialogue means that guards will repeat the same 3-4 lines while looking for you, removing a chunk of the immersion and making the enemies feel like single-minded machines.
Finally, and this will probably be a nut-punch for plenty of you: Dishonored is a very short game, maxing out at 15 levels with DLC. It is not uncommon for a player to plow through the game in less than five hours. However this is offset by the games very high replay factor, including a summary of mission stats at the end of each level which encourages the player to push towards that perfect score.
Still in the end, Dishonored is without any doubt one of the greatest games I've played, and despite it's short length and strange scripting habits I have spent disproportionate sums of hours in this game. I recommend Dishonored without any hesitation and I praise the developers on this gem of a game.

Why does Dishonored not have Steam cards yet?

reviewText:
Welcome to the city of Dunwall, the capital of a civilization that's slowly dying from a murderous plague that has an infinite hunger for the inhabitants of Dunwall, you play as the Royal Bodyguard by the name of Corvo Attano who's job is to protect the Empress but this all changes when the Royal Spymaster has other plans for you.

This game is a beautiful gallery of characters, mechanics and storylines with the ability to free roam during missions and choose how you want to play the game to take your target out.

Will you assassinate your target with a loud and dark outcome? Or will you be a stealthed and passive loyalist who brings justice to the city of Dunwall without causing chaos? The choice is yours.


I rate this game thumbs up for it's sheer beauty and amazing mechanics.

reviewText:
Ok let's make a generic category - point system for once.

Gameplay: 8/10
Both stealthy and rambo gameplay are possible, while perfect stealth + non-lethal or rambo w/o magic are the hardest and silent killer is the easiest. Being stealthy is much more fun though!
There is character skilling but it doesn't go too deep, that's fine by me as the focus is really on the active gameplay.
Controls are fluid, gameplay is diverse, multiple ways to succeed at your task.But the possibilities you have are all predefined by the dev's, there aren't any completely new ways you can discover.

Graphics & Sound: 7/10
The Artstyle is nice but there are textures which aren't really beautiful. The proportions of the characters look a bit weird, they have those huge hands and the characters don't really look unique.
Sound is good, music is fine, too.

Story & Atmosphere: 6/10
You arrive somewhere don't know anything but you being the empress' bodyguard and BOOM she's dead. You don't know why you have to do things and unfortunately you don't really care, as you stay a character without personality just like everyone else. Could be worse though, you never feel like being completely useless and the story isn't crazy.
The Atmosphere in the Game is awesome though! I really think I'm in 18th -19 th century England. They should have done more about the Steampunk part making the different between reality and this bigger, but that's personal preference. There are some books you find all over the places, not too bad, but you can't compare them to TES books.

After all, is it fun? (There are good games which for some reason just don't entertain you)
Yes. So let's give it 1 bonus point and finish with an 8/10.

reviewText:
One of my favorite games for the year. The game itself took about 10-11 hours to complete at a leisurely play through.

There have been some complaints that it is repetitive, and I think there is some merit to this, but it doesn't happen enough to be a concern to me.
What major complaint I have is that you cannot go back and do individual missions once you have acquired your powers. It would be quite fun to do the originals when you are powerful, sadly, this is lacking.

Overall, the graphics are nice and the story is excellent and keeps you interested. The world is also a nice one to explore.
