reviewText:
You can play this game like a mad men, relishing in the superb feel of the controls as you obliterate every living soul you come across by unleashing a storm of flesh eating piranha-rats, throwing baddies off cliffs or, if you’re a traditional kind of guy/gal, shooting them in the face.

But here’s the best part - You can also play the game, from start to finish, without killing ANYONE or even letting your enemies know you were there. This thanks in large part to some of the best level design in recent history.

However, there is no excuse for this game to feature a conveniently silent protagonist where you play a supposedly influential character with deep relationships and where major plot points could be averted with a simple “Nope”.

reviewText: I just LOVE this game. It's like a stealth Bioshock Infinite, could match, or even be better than Deus Ex - Human Revolution. Great story, great lore (and I usually just skip through all the books), interesting powers and decisions that actually make difference in darkness of the world you're in.\nThat said, I also must mention some cons. First of all, game is too easy, even on highest difficulty. It felt like there was same number of guards on normal and on very hard, just the amount of damage and their ability to spot you differ. Secondly, during the game you're giving decent amount of weapons and upgrades for them. But the game encourages you to try not to just go running and killing, which prevents you from using those weapons. Furthermore, sleeping darts and mana potions are far less found throughout the world, especially in last 2 missions, so if you didn't buy them before endgame and you run out...tough luck. reviewText:
The Game: Dishonored is a very fun stealth-based first-person objective-based game; with the option to explore other areas on most maps. You play as Corvo, a man framed for the murder of the Empress. You escape prison with an unknown person’s help and meet them at their bar. After this you begin to do missions for these people; to help destabilize the current and corrupt government.

There are two ways of doing any of the missions, either in High Chaos mode, in this mode you are not concerned about Stealth at all and engage in combat with anyone (who is marked as an enemy). Keep in mind if you get enough of the enemy onto you, you’ll either need to “Blink” (a magical ability Corvo has) away at a higher level (like on top of a ledge or building) and keep hidden; or you can die (quite quickly) trying to kill them all, since the men without blades will use flintlock pistols to shoot you and the men with blades want to remove your head.

You can also do missions in Low Chaos mode, which may be a little “harder” and it does take a bit longer and require more patience, however in this mode you do not get detected (you must try not to anyways, otherwise it can go to High Chaos if you’re detected and decide to engage in combat). I honestly recommend playing the game while trying to achieve “Low Chaos” since this mode is the most fun (in my honest opinion).

Other than those few things there is Corvo’s signature blade, which is equipped in your right hand – in Corvo’s left hand you can equip various things from magical abilities (like the previously mentioned “Blink” ability), various types of grenades, and finally, Corvo's crossbow (with various types of darts including ones that only put the enemy to sleep, helping your “Low Chaos” Score as that doesn’t count as a death (they’re only asleep)).

Overall: All-in-all I believe Dishonored is a great game with an amazing story and characters. It surprised me that Arkane Studios (the developers behind Dishonored) were able to pull off such an amazing game, especially since before this game I’d never heard of Arkane Studios in my life. Either way, the game runs very well as it utilizes the Unreal Engine 3, so most PC’s that were made in the past five years (as of 2015) should be able to run this game with no real issues. To be safe, make sure your PC is a 2012-2015 model; this way you can play anything that is out, including the newer more graphical games (W3, GTAV, UE4 Games, etc.) I believe that anyone with either patience or the skill to kill several enemies before disappearing and reappearing to finish them off, then Dishonored is for you!

Score: 4/5 – An amazing game with a very fun and interesting Story and Stealth Mode.

reviewText:
Lovely game. It was one of the more interesting stealth games when it game out.

There are some interesting aspects to this game that makes it good. The fact that the same guy who designed City 17 in HL2 made Dunwall (the city in Dishonored). The fact that the whole city runs on whale oil opposed to electricity, therefore all the textures are very water colored and desaturated, this results in an amazing overall aesthetic. The fact that every single character in this game is hideous on purpose.

The gameplay is good but not amazing. It does a great job in making you feel like you are cheating by using your blink ability and high agility. The levels are quite big and there is a fair amount of exploration (also the loading screens are incredibly fast, so transitioning from an area to another is blinking fast :D).

I wasn't a big fan of the binary good\evil ending, however the journey impressed me. Every single area you find yourself in has it's own personality and is highly memorable.

And on top of all that, it allows you to play non lethal, finishing the game without killing a single living thing (except rats, ♥♥♥♥ rats).

It's a nice stylized experience and I recommend it!

reviewText:
Dishonored is a great stealth game that also allows a non-stealth approach to completing missions. The addition of supernatural powers enables different playstyles and the outstanding level design enables a lot of exploration and provides different paths to reaching objectives.

The chaos mechanic is an interesting one: it makes the game respond to how you act. If you choose a more violent approach (killing lots of enemies) the chaos level in the city will be high and the environment will change accordingly (there will be more enemies and rats), as will the outcome of the story. A less lethal playstyle will have a more positive outcome. This contributes to the game's replay value. Some have criticized this aspect of the game, claiming that going for a non-lethal approach makes the game boring, because there are only two ways of dealing with enemies: knocking them out or using sleep darts. I turned the non-lethal approach into a challenge to completely avoid enemies as much as possible, without knocking them out or alerting them, and see how far I can progress in that manner, which made it an interesting challenge. However, it is true that there are far more ways to deal with enemies in a violent manner.

The two story DLCs (Knife of Dunwall and Witches of Brigmore) are not continuations of the main story but provide an interesting addition. They have three missions each and introduce a couple of new abilities.

Dunwall City Trials DLC is not story-based, instead it comes with 10 different challenges that test the player's skill in stealth, agility, ability to quickly perform assassinations etc. The achievements are pretty difficult to get.

Overall I would strongly recommend the game: it has a great level design and a great story with multiple endings, and it allows the player to approach it as a stealth game or as a more action-oriented game.

reviewText: Linear, open-level design done right. It reminds me a lot of Deus Ex where you're given a choice of a stealth or a lethal approach, and you're also given so much freedom in how you tranverse through each level. The world is dark, engaging, and full of intrigue. The watercolor-like art style is unique, and gives a lot of character to the world. The supernatural powers are mechanics seen nowhere else, as you're able to scale buildings with ease and navigate through levels unconventionally (taking control of animals and going through sewer pipes). The developers managed to create a tightly-designed game that avoids needless pandering or padding while giving the player so much freedom to tackle objectives.

reviewText:
It is an amazing game which lets you choose several ways to solve a problem. It is great that you can do it in so many ways and that it also  affects the story , For example: I took away a bottle whilst someone was painting another person, when I later found the painting I noticed that the bottle was not in the painting anymore. Eventhough in my first playthrough I killed almost everybody in the city (because it is the most obvious way to dispose of an enemy) I had more fun playing it through for the second time and trying not to get detected. Another great feature is that you can get information on how to complete a challenge and a sidequest by just listening to plain conversations between citizens and guards. Last but not least I adored how there are 3 different endings, for some reason I really felt that I played the game better when I actually had the best outcome.

Conclusion: It is an amazing game and I would definetly recommend buying it if you like using amazing powers to sneak past or assassinate people. You can choose very distinct playstyles and therefore it feels like you are more involved in the story.
9/10

reviewText:
I originally thought that Dishonored was an open world RPG similar to Skyrim or Fallout, but it turns out that it’s actually closer to Deus Ex Human Revolution (action/stealth). Since I only had the free weekend to finish the game I didn’t try to go for all the achievements that I normally would. However, the game lets you know right from the start that the fewer people you kill, the better the outcome will be. That means no hacking and slashing like I was planning to.

In the game you play Corvo, the chief bodyguard of the empress. When the empress is killed and her daughter kidnapped, you get framed for the crime and sentenced to death. Your main goal in the game is to rescue the daughter and bring the actual murderers to justice.  Since the bad guys are high up in the government, this means you’ll mostly be fighting government soldiers and religious zealots. You’re not alone in your quest since a magical being called the Outsider gives you powers that you can use to complete your objectives. The game does a lot of its background storytelling through notes and books that you run across all over the place. The Dishonored world seems to be roughly 1800’s technology with magic thrown in, resulting in a steampunk environment. The graphics are very similar to the Bioshock games (including that annoying blur effect when you walk through falling water).

As I alluded to earlier, Dishonored is not really an RPG. You don’t gain experience or level up. There’s no big reason to kill or knock out enemies if you can just sneak around them (unless you want them out of the way for exploration). Your magic powers are upgraded by finding “runes” throughout the game world. Each rune acts like a skill point that you can use to gain or improve your magic powers. The main power you’ll be using is Blink, which is a short range teleport, which is great for getting around and avoiding enemies. The magic powers are generally not “offensive” meaning you’re not throwing fireballs or shooting lighting. Generally they’re for supporting your stealth (see through walls, killed enemies disintegrate, turn into a rat). Almost all your objectives have multiple solutions. You can run through fighting (not recommended) or find various hidden paths like climbing roofs or going through small tunnels. Similar to Deus Ex, when you sneak up on an enemy you can choose a non-lethal takedown or assassinate. Then you need to hide the body since enemies will raise alarm if they find dead or unconscious buddies lying out in the open. There is also a combat system which includes guns and the sword (you can block enemy sword swings). Since I played stealth, I didn’t engage in very much combat. And since I didn’t do a lot of fighting, my ammunition filled up really fast. You can hold a small number of healing/mana potions and arrows/bullets for your weapons.

Overall Dishonored is great and well worth your time. However I wouldn’t say it’s “must play” like some others (Bioshock Infinite, Tomb Raider 2013, etc.). If you’re not into stealth games you will probably get annoyed at times when the enemy random patrols just don’t give you a chance to sneak past. I’ve read online that some people thought the game’s story was weak. It’s not amazing but not bad either. The story mostly just drives the gameplay and tells you where to go. I managed to finish the game during the free weekend a few days ago and it took roughly 16 hours, probably because I was going for no-kills and no-detection. Failed both by the way :(

reviewText:
Hither came Corvo… A reaver, a slayer and a thief.

Lord protector was his title, stripped of all dignity and denied all fair justice, it is now up to you to clear his name or go down with those who were the cause to all of this.The world before you is a harsh one, a plague-ridden, rat infested dump of a city. Without spoiling, one mission that often comes to mind when I think of this game is “the ball”.
Sneak around disguised among other masked high-class and try to talk and lure your way into the secluded areas, make new friends and find out the latest gossips amongst nobles.

Dishonored is truly a game worth mentioning, it takes the stealth-genre into a new era with more fast pace combat and a replayability never seen before. Emerge into a world that is very much convincing and chose a path that you decide.

reviewText:
Here are the essentials that you should know about the game: It is a first-person stealth action game set in a steampunk industrial city infested with a plague (except that everything runs on whale oil instead of steam. The city inherits the city-on-a-coast that is slowly falling apart while a ruling class harasses the citizens vibe from City 17 (Half-Life 2) mixed with the steady unveiling of stories and details through books and audio recordings from Rapture (Bioshock). So the setting is already off to a good start, as I enjoyed both of those games immensely.

As was revealed to us before the game came out, you play as Corvo Attano, the Empress' body guard. In the first scene the empress is assassinated, her daughter is kidnapped, and you are framed for it. Not the most original plot, I know, but you really do get caught up in it. Before they can execute you of course you escape with the help of a group loyal to the true heir and the rest of the game is the story of your revenge.

Of course, the way that you go about exacting your revenge is entirely up to you. It is entirely possible for you to go in guns blazing and murder everyone in your path; it is also possible for you to kill almost no one throughout the whole game. You can even deal with most of the main targets in a nonlethal manner. The way you play affects several things in the game: the more people you kill, the more rats and plague victims there will be, and the ending of the game will be darker. This concept of giving you a moral choice within a linear framework reminds me once again of Bioshock.
I opted to try to kill as few people as I could, partly because it is a refreshing change of pace from most video games, and partly because I knew that the guards that I was encountering didn't know the truth and were just following orders.

Corvo has some pretty nifty gadgets at his disposal, including a folding blade, a crossbow, a pistol, rewiring tools, razor mines, and grenades. Oh, and of course his mask.

The guards in this game aren't completely clueless, so sneaking around them undetected is actually pretty challenging until you start getting awesome supernatural powers from The Outsider. This guy lives in The Void, which is the otherworldly realm where everything magical comes from. He apparently seeks out interesting people to give powers to in order to see what they will do with their powers.  He kind of reminds me of the G-Man (Half-Life) but he manages to be creepy in a whole different way.
The powers he gives you include things like short-range teleportation, seeing things through walls, stopping time, possessing animals, and creating a giant swarm of rats that will devour people.

Both your gear and powers are upgradeable; for gear you collect money and supplies during your missions and bring them back to Piero to have him give you new goodies; for powers you collect whale bone runes and you can select a power to acquire as soon as you have enough runes.

Being that you are the Empress' body guard and her daughter was abducted, one of your main goals is to ensure Emily's safety. I am noticing that this is a rapidly emerging theme in video games: The Walking Dead, Dishonored, Bioshock Infinite, and The Last of Us all have grown men as the player character with a young girl they must protect.

There are a few things that I have to complain about, but they are relatively minor notes:
The game isn't quite as long as I was expecting. I was almost expecting another plot twist that would keep the game going, but it really was the end.
It isn't the most graphically impressive game I've seen. It makes up for it with a unique art style.
Player choice" and "many routes to your goal" doesn't mean open world.
$60 seems like too much. $40 would be a much more reasonable price."
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A game of love, hate and betrayal, Dishonored's storyline and dialogue are a cut above and the art style - while naturally a matter of taste - is strong, consistent and I think beautiful in its exagerrated, oil-paint fashion. The time you spent in Dunwall fighting for the future of the empire and her empress will stick with you, long after the game is complete. This city has personality and flavour - it feels like a place, not a set of repeating assets.

You can take three paths in dishonoured. After your downfall you can remain a righteous fellow, trying to stick to your principles, or you can turn into a crazed maniac, wrecking vengeance on all who stand between you and your goal or you can tread the muddly ground inbetween. Whichever route your nature takes you, the city reflects your heart and so do some of the people closest to you - heartbreakingly, in some circumstances.

The stealth, magic and combat mechanisms in Dishonoured are a joy to play with once you get comfortable with the controls. I've dabbled heavily in all three (particularly in the Dunwall City Trials DLC) and found them all to a pleasure to work with. This is quite rare - usually in stealth games the combat is a nightmare, or in combat games the stealth is a series of awkward wall-hugging moves - none of that here. The magic is straightforward, but if you don't like magic, that's okay - there's an achievement for you too, going through the game with no magical upgrades at all.

Dishonoured is a love letter to the original Thief as well as being a great game in its own right. If you enjoyed Thief: The Dark Project, you'll probably enjoy this. It's easy to imagine Dunwall lying across the sea from Garrett's city - minus the burricks.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Dishonored is a rarity in today's AAA video game industry. It does not treat the player as if he/she is stupid and it gives you the freedom to make the experience your own. Launching Dishonored for the first time and going through the options menu already tells the player what they can expect out of the game; the ability to shape it into what you want it to be.

Are you tired of the constant nagging to get to your objective in games? *Click* Gone. Are you sick of obnoxious objective markers ruining any sense of exploration and the joy that comes with figuring things out on your own? *Click* Gone. Sick of glowing objects telling you THIS IS IMPORTANT AND USEFUL!" *Click* Gone.

The game itself is very good and encourages multiple playstyles. You can fight your way through the open levels or play it sneaky. You can kill everyone you see or go through the entire game without killing a single person. The game gives you a variety of tools to accomplish your goals. You can teleport short distances
date: possess other NPC's or small animals
recommended: summon a group of man eating rats
hoursPlayed: slow or stop time
voteText: etc. In terms of weapons you have a crossbow with various ammo types such as sleeping and incendianary darts
helpfulPercent: grenades
votesHelpful: traps
votesTotal: a pistol
votesFunny:
and more. The levels are expertly crafted and offer multiple paths and enough mass to make use of your weapons and powers.

Your choices do have consequences so you need to be aware of that. My original intention was to play through the entire game without killing a soul but that changed later on in the game.  I went after a character that had nothing to do with the mission itself. I wanted that character dead because I overheard what they do for a living and it made me angry so I went out of my way to hunt them down. That piece of gameplay was one of the standout moments for me because of how unexpected it was and the attachment it made me feel towards the game world.

There are 4 difficulty modes; Easy
commentsCount: Normal
column16: Hard
column17: and Very Hard. If you want a challenge I recommend playing on one of the latter two difficulties. The AI can be very stupid under Normal  and it took away from the immersion and challenge. You are allowed to change the difficulty mid game so if you feel it's too easy or too hard you don't have to start over.\n\nI enjoyed my time with Dishonored and will be giving it another playthrough switching up my tactics and making different moral choices. I was engaged from start to finish and not once did I feel the need to just rush through it and get it over with. Its length was perfect and the entire game feels consistent and very well made."

reviewText:
Dishonored is stealth action game with great gameplay and a really nice world for you to explore.

STORY: You play as corvo who is the main character of the game. Corvo is a bodyguard and is protecting the empress of the city dunwall. but when Corvo comes to see the empress at the very beginning of the game, the empress gets killed by assassin's and corvo is the one they blame for the murder.
Then some bad people take control over dunwall and you need to make things right.
The characters are also good but nothing that special.

GAMEPLAY: Dishonred focuses mostly on stealth gameplay. with every mission you need to kill or neutralize a target so the good people regain something. The good thing about the gameplay of dishonored is that you can complete the missions in so many different ways. You can fire a sleepdart to make your target go to sleep for an example. or you can slice him into bits with your sword, or you can avoid all enemies and only neutralize the target. These are one of the many ways you can complete your mission. if your looking for a game with good stealth gameplay then dishonored will not disappoint.

THE ENVIRONMENT: When you look at the graphics of dishonored you might think that the graphics are bad,
but thats not the case. When i walk around in the world of dishonored i feel like im playing in a painting.
This gives the game a really good and unique feel. The world also feels like there is really something going on.
dishonored's world feels alive and is really nice to look at.

CONCLUSION:  Dishonored gives you fun missions that you can complete in all kinds of ways. combine this with a good story and great gameplay and you get a really good stealth game. The missions also have a ton of replay value, so you might want to play this game for a long time if you want to get the most out of it.
If your looking for a game with good stealth gameplay and a nice world for you to discover then dishonored might be the game your looking for.

reviewText:
Dishonored is a rarity in today's AAA video game industry. It does not treat the player as if he/she is stupid and it gives you the freedom to make the experience your own. Launching Dishonored for the first time and going through the options menu already tells the player what they can expect out of the game; the ability to shape it into what you want it to be.

Are you tired of the constant nagging to get to your objective in games? *Click* Gone. Are you sick of obnoxious objective markers ruining any sense of exploration and the joy that comes with figuring things out on your own? *Click* Gone. Sick of glowing objects telling you THIS IS IMPORTANT AND USEFUL!" *Click* Gone.

The game itself is very good and encourages multiple playstyles. You can fight your way through the open levels or play it sneaky. You can kill everyone you see or go through the entire game without killing a single person. The game gives you a variety of tools to accomplish your goals. You can teleport short distances

reviewText:
Hither came Corvo… A reaver, a slayer and a thief.

Lord protector was his title, stripped of all dignity and denied all fair justice, it is now up to you to clear his name or go down with those who were the cause to all of this.The world before you is a harsh one, a plague-ridden, rat infested dump of a city. Filled with lush-consuming nobles, bribed officials, honourless assassins and a lush for greed.
With the training of a bodyguard and an assassin you must fight your way up to the top of the food-chain to be free your accusations and to save the people you care about.

Without spoiling, one mission that often comes to mind when I think of this game is “the ball”.
Sneak around disguised among other masked high-class and try to talk and lure your way into the secluded areas, make new friends and find out the latest gossips amongst nobles.

Dishonored is truly a game worth mentioning, it takes the stealth-genre into a new era with more fast pace combat and a replayability never seen before. Emerge into a world that is very much convincing and chose a path that you decide.

reviewText: Dishonored is one of those very rare few games that comes along and is very polarizing depending on how you play it. For instance, I went through on a completely non-lethal playthrough and found it to be a slow-paced, often difficult, yet immensely satisfying experience... then went on a lethal playthrough and found it to be a short, easy, wisp of a game. Suffice to say the stealth mechanics usually work well, and the game gives you many, many ways to complete various objectives, with lots of clever ways to dispatch foes... but just as it encourages using all these, it discourages combat altogether with the chaos system. Ultimately despite its faults (which are few), Dishonored is a unique, extremely enjoyable game that I whole-heartedly recommend to any fan of stealth-action games, or anyone who's looking for something outside the current norm of gaming.

reviewText: This game has a little something for everyone I think.  A seemingly easy game that just wants to show you beautiful yet dark vistas that lead you back to play again... then you find you havent even met half of the challenges and must play extremely well to get the gold (ghost acheivement etc).  This one is so hard most of the challengers think they have a bug but then realize the game wont let you cheat by using multiple save technique (auto saves only folks) and doesnt care if you have to go through the game 50 times to find out ha.\n\nThe genre and atmosphere of the world make you want to live there despite the plague with its old fashioned feel amongst major social unrest and revolution.  Conspiracies to make the world shake but we of course were privy and at the leading edge of this change.... ME??? I am going to rent an appartment at the top of Dunwall tower and employ sexy maids who say... 'can I get you anything sir?', lol.  The reality of the whaling ships design would inspire (and has) some shipwrights to question current thinking.  There is nothing that cannot be improved but it's a bloody good game :)

reviewText: I was waiting for Dishonored to come out. Waiting and hoping. It had so much potential. A pseudo-victorian steampunk dystopia, a supernatural menace, a tale of revenge. The animated Tales of Dunwall shorts caught my breath. They were making a game for me. And then it came out. And I wasn't disappointed. I'm terrible at stealth games, but they knew that so they gave me magic powers to solve that conundrum. My computer was broken, so they used a cartoony but subdued visual style which didn't cause my hardware to explode. They knew I loved complex supernatural mysteries, so they gave me just enough Lore to digest that I could piece together a searing cosmic revelation. And they gave me a little girl to save, whose unshaped persona showed me how my actions were effecting the world. As I moved from inspired setpiece to inspired setpiece and nonlethally punished insidious villain after insidious villain, I knew I'd be coming back with a sack full of grenades to try it again, once more with feeling.\n\nPlay this game, and don't forget the DLC which serves as an excellent accompaniment to the original story.

reviewText:
An excellent game with a mix of stealth and action gameplay, Dishonored is set in a steampunk world with some magic thrown it it. The story is set in the Empire of the Isles, and follows Corvo, Royal Protector of the Empress, who's wrongly accused of murdering the empress and kidnapping her daugther. However, the day before his execution, he's freed from prison by a group of loyalists who seek to stop the real conspirators.

The game is filled with many interesting characters, including the aforementioned loyalists, and the members of the conspiracy. There's also some mysterious characters, most notably the Outsider, who gives his mark to Corvo, granting him supernatural powers, all of which are really fun to use, and offer a nice variety, whether you go for a stealth-based approach, or want to kill everything in your path; which, by the way, are both perfectly valid ways to play this game.

A great thing of the game is, like I mentioned above, the different paths it offers. And it's not as simple as two paths, you can actually approach your targets in several ways; you can even get through the whole game using only your weapons, without ever touching the powers; you can kill everybody in front of you, or you can finish the game without killing anybody, including your targets, as the game offers different ways of dealing with them. Something to keep in mind, though, is that your actions affect the world; the city in which the game takes place, Dunwall (capital of the Empire of the Isles), is afflicted by a strange plague, carried by rats, and the more chaos you cause, the more rats there are, and the more dangerous the city gets, leading to different endings depending on the overall chaos.

As far as environments go, they're really good. The city is somewhat reminiscent of Half-Life's City 17, which should come as no surprise, considering that Viktor Antonov, who designed the environments for Half-Life 2, worked in this game as well. Even some of the enemies might remind you of ones encountered through Half-Life 2. However, don't think this is a bad thing; even though there are similarities, the overall tone of the game, of a steampunk nature, makes the city feel pretty unique. There's also many pathways to get through the different levels, depending, once again, on the approach you wish to take; and also many areas that you can explore, even when they're not directly related to your mission.

As for gameplay, I've already talked about it in the above paragraphs. Something I haven't mentioned is that you always dual-wield your sword (on the right hand) along another weapon (or power). This leads to a very dynamic combat system, where you can attack enemies at a distance, while defending yourself in close combat. There's also several powers that allow for easier movement across the levels (from teleportation, to possessing animals, or even human NPCs), and others that give new combat options (like summoning rats to attack your enemies). Then there's the bone charms, which grant you passive effects as long as you have them equipped, enhancing your abilities.

The story is excellent; as I mentioned, it starts with the death of the Empress. After Corvo escapes from prison, he joins the loyalists, and starts going against the conspirators, weakening the power of the Lord Regent, who was behind it all. Depending on what you do, you can even learn more about the plague that's destroying the city, or you can simply get your revenge on those that wronged you.

So, to conclude this review, Dishonored is an excellent game. Great story, great visuals, great characters. It's become one of my favourite games, and I'm eagerly waiting for the sequel. It should be more than obvious that I recommend this game.

reviewText:
It has been two days since you were without
Summer-Rain, after that excursion with her,
the one with the milkshakes. You think about
her as you run along rain-slicked marble walls
and drab stone architecture, with the magical
tattoo on your hand's exterior glowing yellow
and blue.

DISHONORED.

Framed for the murder of the beloved Ruler
of the City of Dunwall, Empress Jessamine
Kaldwin, you take the role of Corvo Attano,
disgraced Royal Bodyguard-turned-deadly,
supernaturally-powered-assassin.

Granted a vast array of paranormally-charged
powers by the strange, ever-watchful Outsider,
the world is yours to either silently navigate to
save the city from an all-consuming plague and
government corruption, or for you to unleash
mayhem and wreak bloody havoc upon those
who have wronged you.

Dishonored's world draws you in with its rich,
meticulously-crafted nuances and mythology
scattered from minute notes to unspoken
baroque and gothic-styled overtones from
atmosphere to architecture.

Dishonored's mission and level design rank
highly in terms of effort put in and time spent
making these levels become a reality. Each
choice made, whether you choose to spare or
kill whoever stands in your wayhas lasting
consequences upon the outcome of the story,
in what the game explains as 'Chaos.'

Complete the game in High Chaos, and you see
the city of Dunwall plunged into a new Dark Age,
based on your choices and a playthrough of a
violent killer. Complete the game in Low Chaos,
and Dunwall is spared a grim fate, and the new
Empress, Emily Kaldwin- daughter of Jessamine
Kaldwin- will reign in a new Golden Age, in part
due to your efforts in a non-lethal, stealth-based
playthrough.

You realize then, after playing the mission to
retrieve Emily from a posh brothel called the
Golden Cat, that the game's model of Emily in
her white dress looks eerily similar, as if you
have seen it on someone before, in the past.

It hits you then. This is not the first time that
you have seen the girl in white. There was the
school dance and there was this bombshell in
the form-fitting white dress, golden bangs and
her black bob-cut. She was alone and at the
time, Ms. Novocaine was running an hour late,
but there were rumours that your girlfriend was
doing improper things with the sports jocks.

You invited her to dance, the girl in white.

You danced with Summer-Rain, once upon a time.

A thread of drool drips unconsciously from your
half-open mouth as your mind wandered. Your
eyes snap back to reality, wiping your mouth
with whatever time you can muster before the
guards are upon you in one of the greatest
Dishonored missions, Lady Boyle's Last Party.

You infiltrated the mansion, mingled with the
guests. You had to identify which of the three
Boyle triplets she was, and choose a method
to eliminate the target. You went for your
folding sword and stabbed the Boyle sister in
white while you had your flashback epiphany.

You save and exit Dishonored before sitting at
the foot of your bed, dialling her number and
waiting with baited breath. Hello?" The line
picks up
date:
and Summer-Rain's sweet voice
washes over your shaken form. "Hey. You
alright there?" She chimes.

"I remember. That night
recommended: when Ms. Novocaine\ndidn't turn up. We danced the night away
hoursPlayed: but\nin the morning
voteText: you were gone. I woke up on\nthat hill overlooking town alone." Silence from\nacross the line

then you can almost feel her
smile from the receiver.

"You knew
votesHelpful:
didn't you? About Ms. Novocaine."

Summer-Rain's tears fall freely now. Her sobs
echo in your ear and through your heart

both you and Summer-Rain.

reviewText:
An excellent first person stealth action game.

As a huge fan of Arkane Studios previous games, Dishonored couldn't have been better. Giving you the ability to play as you want, whether it be a combat centric character or one that sticks to the shadows and avoids conflict. Along with massive replayability with alternate endings and various different outcomes to side quests, it'll keep you busy for a long time.

Definitely worth a buy, it won't dissapoint.

reviewText:
While I don't find as good as other people say, I still find it as a great game and I do have my reasons

First of all the good:

+ I love the Steampunk setting
+ All of the weapons are useful and are fun to use, my fav being the Crossbow
+ Lots of powers
+ Fantastic weather effects
+ Chaos system is a good idea
+ Some fun levels
+ Runes and Bones are fun to find
+ Dat mask
+ REALLY FAST LOAD TIMES AND I MEAN FAST!

Downsides:

- Stealth has been glitchty for me, before you say your doing it wrong, I compeleted MGS 1,2 3, 3DS, 4, twin snakes and Peacewalker all on Euro extreme/hardest setting stealth, no alerts and no kills, so I know stealth. But here, guards keep popping out of no where, and dark vision does f*ck all to see them, I know it has a range, BUT WHEN THE RANGE IS 2CM, THEN WE HAVE AN ISSUE, other then that, Stealth CAN work sometimes, most of the time guards just insta spot me while I'm hiding in the shadows, so I'm forced to go in guns blazing 75% of the time.

Also smashing glasses does f*ck all, not joking, I smashed a glass in a guards face and he did nothing, didn't move, didn't attack until I walked infront of him....

- The Story is unintresting, while in the beginning it plays the obvious parent is gonna die and the child is gonna be kidnapped card, thats the only intresting thing, rest of it is boring and I keep finding myself skipping them.

- Some powers are no where as good as the others, like I mentioned Dark vision works whenever it feels like it, Blink is broken and is the only power you should use, freezing time while fun, is only good for escapes or quick kills, Devoring Storm is nearly useless, and the Wind Power is decent.

- Some cutscenes can't be skipped, while others can..... why?

- All company logos can't be skipped.... why?

Other then that, this game is a lot fun.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
What I mostly like about this game are the choices. While they may not always have real consequences (mostly affecting the chaos rating of the city), they give the player the feeling of freedom.

I'm almost done with my second playthrough. The first one was magic-using sneaker, where I only killed people if they caught me by surprise. While it was quite nice, finding alternative routes and hiding all the sleeping bodies, the second playthrough has been so much better.

For a game that rewards you for being a good guy (sneaking, not killing), being a badass warrior is too damn fun. While I don't use any magic on this run, the feeling of battling half a dozen guards at once is amazing. Blink behind, stab, shoot another one to the face, lob a sticky grenade on one, blink away from explosion, lock your sword with the last one and remove his head. It is frankly quite intoxicating.

Also, seeing all the differences between different runs make you appreciate the game much more, even if the differences are small.

The fact that you can be shot or stabbed in the back while swordfighting another guard, is really good compared to Batman / Assassin's Creed type of combo-counter brawl. You have to think ahead or be ready to use your weapons, you can't just jump in the middle of a group of hostiles.

10/10 would play again (almost did already)

reviewText: I absolutely loved it. This is a great stealth combat game. It has a detailed and well constructed world, a great story (or stories, as the expansions give you another great storyline running concurrent with the original), memorable characters, and interesting challenges and achievements. Also, if you aren't turned off by binary moral choice systems you can play through each story multiple times. You should also definitely get the game of the year addition 'cause the expansions are absolutely worth it.\nA word to the wise, you should probably decide before you start whether you plan to be good or to do some of the longer achievements like Ghost cause you can't start after the fact.

reviewText:
A very fun game with some moral choices. You can go one of four ways:
1) Complete stealth; nobody ever detects you at all and you only knock people out.
2) No kills; you may be seen but you never kill
3) Some kills; you may be seen and you try not to kill, but when it needs to happen it does
4) Rambo; you run into any fight and kill everyone.
Depending on what you choose, the game has three different outcomes based off your chaos" level. Higher and lower chaos will affect different things as well as change the last level.
The swordfighting mechanics are great and you will never survive a fight using just the sword in a group of 3+. Using your magic powers via the Outsider's mark you can stop time
date: teleport around and generally have fun. Plot is simple but passable. Definitely a game worth multiple playthroughs
recommended: and each one may vary in time. A kill-everyone run takes only about 8 hours while a full stealth could take up to 30-40 hours. The DLC is very fun
hoursPlayed: in the Knife of Dunwall and the Brigmore Witches you get to play as an antagonist from the main game
voteText: the assassin Daud. The only other DLC currently is the Dunwall City Trials
helpfulPercent: which are very fun for everyone."

reviewText: This game...i have mixed feeling towards it. On one side I loved the graphics, the style and voice actors and the music. I also loved the level design and overall the great freedom it was given to the player.....BUT this freedom was taken back due to the STUPID Chaos system present in the game. Which chaos you get influence the endings, problem is that chaos level is not affected by how stealthy you play but how many people you kill. I did a lethal stealth gameplay (never discovered/killed all the guards) and got the bad ending. Basically the story forced my gameplay, if you want a good ending you should not kill anyone which is bad. Non-lethal gamplay is boring and made a lot of powers and gadgets useless and restrict your options. This thing really ruined the game for me.\n\nHowever if we put this thing apart you get a solid game, with good levels and lots of fun. DLCs are a must have in this game. If what I mentioned earlier is not a problem then go for it, it's really a satisfying game to play. Personally I enjoyed Daud story more over Corvo's so I highly recommend all DLCs (except the trials of Dunwall that are useless).

reviewText:
Take Deus Ex (the first one, not Human Revolution), Thief (again, the old one by Looking Glass) and Half-Life 2 and mix them together; what you obtain as a result is Dishonored.

Great background story, multiple paths and decisions that affect the final outcome, the freedom of either choosing a more stealth approach or going ballistic, and *huge* levels that reward you for taking your time to explore them thoroughly. Oh, and you can finish the game without ever hurting any character, which is always something nice in an action game. :)

9.5/10

reviewText:
Finally I got my hands on this game..
As a stealth game it's a bit too easy even on the hardest difficulty, and the AI could use some improvement, but this game shines in all other aspects.
Great story, great characters, great game.
You are given a choice to completely sneak your way through or just rush in and slaughter everyone. - all up to you. Whatever you do, it will change the way some characters talk to you.
Dishonored is one of my favourite games and still might be the best stealth game ever released. It's really worth your money so go ahead and give it a try.

reviewText: This game...i have mixed feeling towards it. On one side I loved the graphics, the style and voice actors and the music. I also loved the level design and overall the great freedom it was given to the player.....BUT this freedom was taken back due to the STUPID Chaos system present in the game. Which chaos you get influence the endings, problem is that chaos level is not affected by how stealthy you play but how many people you kill. I did a lethal stealth gameplay (never discovered/killed all the guards) and got the bad ending. Basically the story forced my gameplay, if you want a good ending you should not kill anyone which is bad. Non-lethal gamplay is boring and made a lot of powers and gadgets useless and restrict your options. This thing really ruined the game for me.\n\nHowever if we put this thing apart you get a solid game, with good levels and lots of fun. DLCs are a must have in this game. If what I mentioned earlier is not a problem then go for it, it's really a satisfying game to play. Personally I enjoyed Daud story more over Corvo's so I highly recommend all DLCs (except the trials of Dunwall that are useless).

reviewText:
For me, this is tied with Far Cry 3 for GOTY 2012. It's such a unique and refreshing game.
Very hard to stop playing. The world they created is amazing and has so much potential for many sequels. However, the story is very contained within this one game. Plenty of closure. It's a very intriguing story, too. I heard people calling the story weak, but it most certainly is not.

You can play the game in a variety of ways. No killing, plenty of killing, balanced, whatever. There are quite a few ways to approach every part of every mission. There are some choices you can make in the game that does effect some dialogue and some more subtle things throughout the game, depending on what it is.

It's got tons of replay value and plenty of secrets to find. You could play through it 3, 4, maybe even 5 times before you've seen everything that can happen in the game. Like I said, though, it's mostly subtle stuff, but I like that. It's not for everyone, but man, I applaud Arkane (a relatively untested studio until now) on their excellent work on this game.

If you like BioShock, you'd probably love this game. But again, it really isn't just another rehash of other games. You might could say it takes some of the best gameplay elements from a number of games and combines them to create something special and unique.

Really fun. It's also already got a little expansion to the game, and Bethesda is teasing more DLC to come. I sure hope there will be more!

reviewText:
Pros:
Tight, gory combat
Great atmosphere
Unique aesthetic
Compelling Story
Lovely Graphics
Gross victorian superpowers
Susan Sarandon plays a crazy old hag who wants to eat you
Cons:
Some of the voice acting for the minor characters is a bit stilted
The Stealth Mechanics aren't perfect
Without the DLCs, the game feels shorter than it should be
One of the two endings makes all of your progress in the game seem moot, sort of.
Conclusion: Dishonored has flaws, but they're all tiny, and they're not unexpected coming from Bethesda. I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys stealth, gore, revenge, and rats.

The verdict: 9/10: A near-masterpiece.

reviewText:
Do you like stealing everything not nailed down in Skyrim? Do you enjoy the sneaking around like a ninja like in Metal Gear Solid or Thief? Are you a fan of the unique atmosphere of Bioshock - with it's art deco and it's magic?

You will LOVE Dishonored! It takes all the best parts of those games mentioned above, greases you up with some whale oil and shadow magic, and sends you out as a steampunk assassin! The game is similar to Bioshock and Deus Ex where you're given a task, and you have multiple ways of accomplishing it. Do you sneak through the shadows? Do you take over a rat and run through the vents? Maybe you rather leave bodies placed in sexual positions for guards to find.

Either way, Dishonored is fantastic! I'm excited to get the DLC to continue more Dishonored.

reviewText: This is an amazingly atmospheric game that supports a number of different play styles--you can be a sneaky pacifist, you can charge straight into combat, you can leave nothing in your wake but a trail of bodies (or dust)... you're set for choices. The storyline also changes subtly based on how you behave--not in an overt Mass Effect-y way, but more subtly. If you kill everyone you meet in your missions rather than sneaking by, people will begin to trust you less and be less friendly. It's a great game, and totally recommended.

reviewText:
Take Deus Ex (the first one, not Human Revolution), Thief (again, the old one by Looking Glass) and Half-Life 2 and mix them together; what you obtain as a result is Dishonored.

Great background story, multiple paths and decisions that affect the final outcome, the freedom of either choosing a more stealth approach or going ballistic, and *huge* levels that reward you for taking your time to explore them thoroughly. Oh, and you can finish the game without ever hurting any character, which is always something nice in an action game. :)

9.5/10

reviewText:
Dishonored is a stealth-action game with RPG elements in it and a choice system that really impacts how the ending is for you so if you are going to play this game keep that in mind.

I got Dishonored in a sale, I came in with just some knowledge of what the game was and how it was reviewed but I didn't really know alot about it.
So I didn't have any idea how I would like it, I did imagine it being like Deus Ex: Human Revolution.
I am happy to say that it has alot in common with Deus Ex: Human Revolution and since that was an excellent game, this game is also very good.

The gameplay is very good, the movement feels very natural and it is helped alot by the Blink power that you have in the game(It offers great combos, for spells or for non-lethal/lethal combat)that allows you to move fast and smooth around the game world, the sword play is pretty standard with block and hack with some extra's added like sword clashing but it is good for a game that doesn't really have a focus on swordplay.
The game offers alot of options in killing/neutralizing enemies and I am happy to say that it is a improvement over other games that are in this genre since if you want you never have to kill someone or hurt someone since you have ways to distract, choke, sleep darts and just walking by the enemies using powers like freezing time or blinking.

Dishonored also features a choice system and a karma(called Chaos) system, even though at first you might say it makes no difference but it does it in a subtle way and you really regret later down the road when there are big changes in the levels responding to your choices(and the little choices do make a difference, even killing someone makes a big difference) and I really liked this system because it felt natural and logically, not a number but a change in the enviroment.

It does have some flaws including that the game itself can be short, even if you like to explore etc. but the Dlc's are better prices for the lengths of them, I recommend getting this game at 50% off and the GOTY edition because that way you get 1 hour for every 1 euro you spend but if you have no money problems then get this game because it is an amazing game with great mechanics and a great story with a nice soundtrack.

reviewText:
After a long trip from distant lands and from returning home.  Your Empress has been slain by an unknown killer, her daughter is taken away and hidden, your trusted allies betray you and lock you up for execution, the city falls apart as the entire population is being infected by a deadly disease, hundreds of rats crawl the streets as they devour the dead bodies of the dead citizens, weepers slowly walk the streets as they cry and mourn of pain, thousands of guards trying to find your head due to a murder you did not commit, massive tallboys wander the dead streets as the rats underneath them scatter about, the rich enjoy a life of luxury as the poor slowly die off from the deadly infection.

Welcome to Dunwall

Make those b*stards pay.

reviewText: 9/10\n\nAn amazingly well-rounded game that makes you feel like an assassin while remaining a human being. Dishonored has managed to be a game with a seemingly overused theme, (being assassins and superpowers,) and still managed to craft it into a great game. Dishonored casts you as Corvo Attano, recently banished from your home by false accusations of murder. Now with you out of the picture, inner forces of Dunwall seek to break it apart from the inside. It is your job to uncover the true murderer... How far will you go to prove your innocence, and will you become a monster trying to? Dishonored has a unique and thrilling storyline, with a conjoined weapon and power system. Even just following a simple story mission can be nothing but good fun if you use the powers and tools given to you correctly. Dishonored is easily one of my favorite games, and you can count on it for hours of good fun and thrilling action.

reviewText:
Grades:

Longevity: 8/10
Story: 9/10
Gameplay: 8.5 / 10
Graphics: 9/10
Sound: 9/10

The main story of Dishonored portrays the journey of Corvo Attano, protector of the Empress. This is murdered by other assassins in front of Corvo and his daughter Emily, at the behest of Lord Regent, which is a corrupt and unscrupulous governor. Emily in the aftermath of these events is kidnapped by the assassins, and Raven then has to go save her and kill the Lord Regent, and other strategic targets, so Dunwall can return to normalcy.

DLC in The Knife of Dunwall, we follow the demand of Daud, the assassin who killed the Empress, in search of Delilah, the name that was pointed out by The Outsider.

The DLC in Brigmore Witches, continue to demand Daud, in search of Delilah.

Starting with longevity, this editon took me 23 hours to complete, main story + DLC's, so longevity is not a strong point, but for the type of game it is, and how it's done, is an acceptable longevity .

The story is the strongest point of the game, I enjoyed the story has moments that make us think hard in our decisions that affect its development, and has plenty of moral issues with parallels to real life.

The gameplay is also one of the strengths of the game, has many similarities to Bioshock, where we have a weapon or power in his left hand and a sword in his right hand. We have two approaches to the game, the stealth approach or more careless" approach and kill everything in front. The game also offers several ways to reach the destination
recommended: passes through the tops of buildings or even at street level
hoursPlayed: yet even possessar rats and get in on the ground pipelines. The combat is also well done and sometimes presents some challenge.\n\nThe game's graphics are very good also

In short:

Positives:

Minuses:

- Repetition of lines of guards

FINAL GRADE: 8.7 / 10"

reviewText:
One of the best signs that mean you've played a really good game, is that you get separation anxiety from its world—once you've finished it, you have an hard time starting another game because you were that immersed and engrossed by its lore, its characters and its ambience.

Dishonored, for me, was one of these games.

I've just finished the last DLC and I feel really bad in starting up something else.
Please, Steam, I don't wanna do it. Just give me some more Daud and Corvo and Emily and Piero and Sokolov.

But, alas, the backlog is calling and I have to soldier on and click on delete local content" to save up some space on disk for newly-new games."

reviewText: Despite all the recent Big-Hit-Flops, Dishonoured turned out to be a brilliantly designed game with exactly the right pace to play by. The story is genuinely interesting and keeps you coming back for more, as well as provide you with a much-needed context for your Hitman-style missions. Speaking about Hitman, levels are designed as an open playground, providing you with basic information and then sending you on your way, how you finish each one is completely up to you. There are different endings not just for the game, but for all the missions themselves, adding a whole lot of replay-value. I know I will play through it a second time. Well worth the purchase and possible candidate for GOTY.

reviewText:
The world of Dishonored is fantastic; it is so rich and well-established by way of in-game books, notes, overheard dialogue and even just little scenes upon which you can stumble. Some people call Corvo, the protagonist, boring and characterless, but what's facinating is the effect that your actions  - and by extension, Corvo - has on those around him.
People treat you differently by way of subtle changes in speech or tone and the lasting effect on one particular character is nothing short of brilliant.

As far as gameplay goes, Dishonored isn't perfect. The stealth mechanics are pretty close to perfect, with leaning around corners, clearly visible alert warnings and a multitude of clever ways to get around without being seen, but it falls apart a bit in the combat. Corvo is heralded as a master of arms, able to 'beat three men at once', as a guard can be heard saying. Ironically, fighting more than one person at a time can be infuriatingly difficult. And that's on moderate settings.
Because almost all NPCs use a combination of sword and pistol, you can cross swords only to be shot at point blank range by someone you can't stop, they can kick you; an unblockable attack that deals as much damage as a bullet, or they can just swing their sword as you jump backwards out of range and hit you anyway. Their sword range is about three times the length of their sword and you must block every single hit.

The killy death tools are nicely varied, allowing for very stylish kills with grenades, crossbow bolts and shrapnel mines, and that's not even touching on the supernatural powers. Adding them, the game becomes a flowing action of combat adding a clever third dimension to swordplay (at least the way I fight). Aside from just jumping and teleporting high, time manipulation, rat control and blasts of wind are just some of the tricks you can use.
Admittedly, you'll probably find one or two powers that you use more than the others, but the options are there to experiment.

While the story can be a bit predictable, it serves as a good framing device to take you across the breadth of Dunwall, killing and stalking people of all kinds. Also all of the cutscenes are skippable for those who want to try speedruns.

The DLC is an interesting topic, allowing a new perspective on the story as well as some different powers and amazing sprawling levels.

The downside of these slow, stealth-based games is they can be lacking in F**k Yeah moments, but Dishonored makes up for that in lasting enjoyment, replayability and a world that you can be lost in for days.

reviewText:
This game is honestly a lot of fun! My advice is to get it with the DLCs since it brings you several more hours of fun gameplay! The game is short, but the way I got 120 hours into it is pretty awesome. I completed the game without killing anyone or being seen :D some people say it's impossible, but try it!

If you're wondering if you should get this game, then get it! It's the best first person action stealth game I've ever played!
Here's my opinion of the game:
Gameplay: 11/10 ( it's really fun and you can play however you want! )
Story: 9.5/10 ( it's a pretty basic story )
Visuals: 10/10 ( I've seen very few games that look so... beautiful! )
Sound/Audio: 8/10 ( it's pretty good, but could be better )
Stealth/Action: 10/10 ( it's awesome )

Overall: 10/10 game

reviewText:
After all the media hype for this game I wasn't expecting much after the Diablo 3 stinker.   But boy, does this game deliver!

The art style is one of the best I have seen in a game, even surpassing the beautiful Guild wars 2 art direction. The stealth gameplay is a blast and with the blink teleport you feel like a badass, kinda like how the recent Batman games did that too.

reviewText:
Arkane Studios did a great job with Dishonored. Although the game itself is a bit short, i think the story was extremely enjoyable, either you play only as Corvo in the main story or you purchase the DLC and play through Daud's perspective, it was an absolute pleasure playing as any of them.

The campaign is packed with emotion, conflict, conspiracies, action and interesting characters. And the DLC add alot more content storywise, the game has some great potential for a sequel.

The gameplay was nothing short of amazing, from the assassin weaponry to the magical skills, it gives the player numerous ways in which to play the game. Most missions even gave options on how to approach and finish your objectives and some characters even react and reward you for completing non lethal" missions.

Even if the graphics aren't the best for it's time
date: they worked nicely with the game's environment.\n\nI liked the game so much that i would love to see a sequel in the same world
recommended: overall the game is a bargain if you find it on sale and gives you tons of fun and content."

reviewText:
Great story.

The game suffers from a few bugs (invisible walls here and there) but if you're willing to overlook this, the beautiful graphics, gripping story and fun gameplay system make up a great game.

Plus the story... It's so depressing that you really want to guide the hero to his justice! He has basically two people he loves, one's killed and the other's kidnapped, and his betrayers even go so far as to rub it in his face, the game does a very good job of making it personal as your betrayers sneer down at you. Revenge is all you think of.

Top play.

reviewText:
There are a few things that make Dishonored quite compelling:
The story is unique and interesting, and can have different endings, depending on your play style.
You can complete your objectives however you want, whether you like moving through the shadows or charging in, whether you want to kill your enemies, render them unconscious or simply sneak past them, whether you want to use your arsenal, or your supernatural powers, or none.
Besides the many missions in the main story, the DLC also provide quite a lot of new content.

Other things to be noted:
The interface is nice, the keybinds are customizable.
The graphics are good, and the game does not require a fancy PC to run on.
The AI is pretty smart, although, guards have fixed patrolling routes.
Most achievements are unlocking without issues.

As for bad aspects:
Your character interacts awfully with the environment and does not actually talk; you communicate with the other characters via text only.

Overall: 8.5/10

reviewText: There’s a rat in the kitchen -- and everywhere else\n\nI loved this game and can find only one fault with it (more about that later). Arkane Studios have created a compelling game that ticks just about all the right boxes for me. It looks great, with very striking design and a unique painterly style. The city of Dunwall is beautifully realised and is a joy to explore. The gameplay successfully fuses the use of powers and weapons and the choice between stealth and combat is nicely balanced. The mission design is quite varied and allows for a number of ways to complete each one, thus offering decent replay value. The voice acting is always convincing, thanks to a star-studded cast, and the story is reasonable, although not strikingly original. Where it falls short is in the level of humour. Aside from one amusing line about someone not wearing pants I don’t recall there being many laughs along the way. And that’s a shame, because if not for the lack of humour I would have given DISHONORED a full score. 4.5/5

reviewText: Dishonored is arguably one of the best games of all time. What makes me say that? Well it's like Bioshock except it's much darker (I meant that literally) and it changes up the way you think about stealth games. Despite its different style, the game isn't complicated at all. In fact, it's pretty easy to get used to and it isn't hard to pull off your first stealth kill. Art style is phenomenal, music is great, graphics are beautiful, and the story is what makes the game what it is mainly because it gives you choices that affect the ending. Great concept overall!

reviewText:
Single-player assassination game with a unique twist. A story that is well executed and that changes depending of the style of play you'll have throughout the game, lethal or non-lethal. You're choosing your skills freely and you can tailor them to fit your own playstyle. Slide through shadows, sneak past guard and get your way in, or go head-on with your blade and slash your way, or combine the two. All at your hands.

Improvisation and adaptation is the key. Dishonored is a vicious, raw, and incredibly good stealth-action game.

Feed him to the hungry rats for dinner. Early in the morning.""

reviewText:
Dishonored is a very fun game and has a great story. It has a lot of replay value because you can do every level in so many different ways. I've spent atleast 10 hours on the Lady Boyle mission because it's fun trying to complete it in different ways. The executions are brutal so you may want to complete it atleast 2 times to see them (If you want to play stealthy aswell).  The DLC adds 2 short stories to the game where you get to play as Daud. Daud is a great character and has a few more spells than Corvo. He can summon allies and his blink stops time when he isn't moving. The Dunwall City Trials DLC is pretty fun and very challenging and has a horde mode which is amazing. I can't wait for the second game.

The only problem I have with this game is that the Guards are a bit stupid. They have detection issues but it doesn't happen much.

BUY IT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

reviewText:
Don't get me wrong, Dishonored IS a good game.
The gameplay in it is fantastic, the setting is really cool and interesting, and the pure number of ways you can deal with just about any scenario is nothing short of awe-inspiring. However, it does have its claws, most of which settle around the story and how it frames its characters, but it's best to try to be ignorant of them if you want to get the most out of this game.
Just play it and try not to get too invested in the story because the game won't really reward that investment.

I'll list my issues below in a spoiler, but if you are even thinking about buying this game, grab it.
Characters as a whole never really feel like people, they come off as robotic cardboard cutouts most of the time, primarily because they don't seem to ever react to anything. This is something that if you notice it, it's hard to ignore if you are trying to get into the story. The city itself is interesting, it's just that the flatness of the characters never really makes it feel alive.

The other problem that I have with the game is how it calculates how your actions impact" the rest of the story. Whether or not you get a good ending is mostly determined by how many people you have killed and how much general "chaos" you have created. However... I went through my playthrough taking mostly knock outs and only killing someone if I needed to silence them before they rang the other guards. Despite these tactics I was still getting high chaos ratings at the end of every mission because of the bodycount tha I was hitting.
None of these bodies would ever be found
date: and most of the people who ever saw me are now dead
hoursPlayed: everyone knows who I am
voteText: and the city is going to hell. I'm not dropping corpses to the rats
helpfulPercent: I'm not charging guards head on
votesHelpful: and yet the game still treats me the same way simply because of this bodycount. It's actually frustrating
votesTotal: because the moments where you'll find yourself seen and then have to fight your way are the BEST part of the game. Summoning a rat swarm at the top of a tower
votesFunny: and accidently luring all the guards in the area up the steps
commentsCount: then throwing a grenade too kill every one of them because I'm cornered shouldn't make me a saint. At the same time however
column16:
that's just one section out of four in the level and even if I don't kill a single soul after this I'll still get high chaos because I happened to kill eight people out of necessity.
It just feels like the emergent gameplay side of Dishonored conflicts with the morality system in a way that punishes the player on the story end of the game because they wanted to play Dishonored the "fun" way.

Again

reviewText: Dishonored is a great game, one of my favourite games actually. It's a stealth game that perfectly balances gameplay and story. The game gives you full control on how you handle your missions and provides you with more then enough equipment to do so. When you learn about the enviroment and about your abilities you can experiment in number of different ways. You can get through the whole game without killing anyone or you can play crazy and kill anyone you see. There are multiple different endings you can get. It all depends on how you play the game. The world is very believable but also fictional. It perfectly lets the story unfold itself in it.\nDLC's are also great and will keep you hooked even more time. I realy recommend this game. It's not just a game, it's an experience.\n-Lori

reviewText:
I just realized that I never got around to recommending this, so I'll do it now. I'm not going to try to write a review, but I want to explain why I love this game so much.

I love Dishonored because it puts me in a world filled with intricately linked systems and sets me free to experiment with them. Every item effects every other item in logical ways, producing a depth of interactivity that is incredibly deep, with combinations of systems coming naturally as you think about your environment as an actual world.

I love that Dishonored doesn't try in vain to deliver photorealistic graphics, and instead utilizes a gorgeous visual style of watercolors and caricatures combined with surrealist lighting. Where so many other games struggle for life-like detail and end up slipping into the uncanny valley, Dishonored uses a non-realistic approach that is evocative and suggestive, making every character and locale a joy to look at.

I love how Dishonored feels when I'm moving around. Every motion in the game is so beautifully smooth, from running to climbing, jumping to sliding. After playing Dishonored it's hard to go back to games where sprinting is limited and I can't jump up and grab a ledge to get over a wall. Mirror's Edge did running so well, and Dishonored surpasses it in every way.

I love playing Dishonored because of all the options I've given when approaching a situation. There are countless ways through each area and multiple solutions to each objective, making stealth and combat equally viable playstyles.

I could go on and on, but I'm going to cut this short. Simply put, it's a game that does nearly everything right. Every single aspect of the gameplay is masterfully crafted and polished to perfection. Buy this game. Buy it right now.

reviewText:
Imprisoned, in a dark; dank cell, stripped of your pride and honour, the Empress who you guarded with your life killed under your very nose, and her daughter snatched away. These thoughts press on your mind as you sit in your cell, awaiting your unfair execution. Your attention is snapped back to reality when a tray of soggy looking food is slid under the cell door, only holding your attention momentarily, except for the small piece of paper with a scrawled note on it. You pull apart the bread to find the key to your cell door hidden in it. With freedom within your grasp, and redemption close behind it, what path will you take? Will you slaughter everyone in your path, and climb your way to your goal upon a pile of corpses? Or will you slip through the shadows undetected, leaving a trace no more than the entrance guard sleeping under a bush? The choice is yours.

All in all, I really enjoyed this game, from start to finish.
The story, though predictable, was both emotionally engrossing and enjoyable.
The art style is gorgeous, the graphics breathtaking, and the effects mesmerising.
The gameplay is smooth, tactile, and well thought out.
The range of paths to a goal are almost overwhelming, whether you want to wipe a building clean, slip through undetected, or take every enemy out, one by one, like a ninja, noone aware of your presence.
And finishing an objective can be acheived through various means too. Will you slaughter your target mercilessly, staring into his eyes as his consciousness slips away, will you sabotage something so his death appears accidental, or will you bribe the local gang leader to make them disappear"
And your decisions have an effect on the outcome too. You can feel the distaste in the boatman's speech as he tells you of the screams he hears coming from the building you infiltrated
date: or his praise as he commends you on your wise course of action. Aditionally there are multiple end cutscenes
recommended: each a glimpse at the effect your endeavours have on society.\n\nI know this is a long review
hoursPlayed: but I really enjoyed this game
voteText: and I believe it's a must have
helpfulPercent: both for the stealth gamer
votesHelpful: and the action epic alike.\nI can't recommend this game more."

reviewText: Certainly one of the best games of this century. This isn't a generic stealth game like Splinter Cell or MGS. It isn't stealth only, you can also use a wide variety of gadgets or magical attacks and your trusty blade. It also includes side quests to obtain 'Runes' which are used to upgrade your magic or completing some quests may earn you 'Bone Charms' which add you a slight boost to things like Attack Speed,Health,Damage and so on. You may use non-lethal or lethal ways to eliminate your enemies it's your choice. Although being lethal/non-lethal may affect your ending. You will never get bored of this game. If you're not scavenging for supplies then you're sneaking your way past enemies or finding alternate ways to access buildings etc. Overall it's a brilliant game 10/10.

reviewText:
I know many players who have finished this game say it's a little short. And after doing a complete non-lethal stealth run through myself in one afternoon I have to agree. However keep in mind that that is just one way to play Dishonored.

Personally I feel that the game was designed so as to cater to all types of players, from those who prefer to sneak around and leave enemies unharmed to those who like to run around and dismember guards with your gadgets and blade. There are also optional quests that the player can partake in to receive runes to spend on abilities, with certain abilities further catering to specific playstyles.

The big motivating factor for me was the fact that how you play may dictate how the climax and ending plays out. I played through twice, once as a good Corvo and the other as a bad, and both times I was satisfied by the different dialogue and overall ending. Moreover, for those achievement seekers I feel that the list of achievements for this game also promotes the player to play through more than once.

One memorable chapter for me with this game was the masquerade party; I spent hours on this one level just exploring this beautifully designed area. It's like taking part in a piece of actual history, the likes of which you know does not happen anymore.

Other than that, this game isn't very graphically intensive though still looks fairly good, and the combat itself is very fluid. I wish Skyrim had a similar combat system.

reviewText:
I had extremely high hopes for Dishonored, and whilst it can be quite fun, I feel a little bit let down.

The style of the game is gorgeous, steampunk skylines and all that good stuff, very atmosphereic. I also like how you can complete the entire game without killing anyone.

Pros:

Messing around with the powers can be quite amusing.

Terrific Atmosphere.

Fun Acrobatics.

Cons:

The Story is...Pretty terrible, honestly. Incredibly predictable.

You're very encuraged to kill instead of sneak, seeing as most upgrades are for that purpose, whilst only 1 or 2 are for stealth.

I felt that I was far too powerful in the latter half of the game, it really took away from any tension.


Overall, it's a fun little game on it's own. However compared to the Thief games on merits of stealth, this pales in comparison.

reviewText:
This is a great game in almost every way. It's a stealth FPS which follows the path of Corvo, who is wrongly accused of murdering the empress. So begins your journey through a vivid, interesting steam-punk world.

Anyone into the Thief games or stealth in general will find something to like here. This game however, also features an impressive ability set of magical" powers that you can acquire through runes and bone charms throughout the game. Some of these completely change the way you approach situations and are most welcome additions.

The only thing I was not to keen on was this "choice" you have over low or high chaos (stealth and not killing anyone or slaughtering everyone in your path). The game keeps on telling you to not kill people if you want the "good" ending
