reviewText:
Dishonored has to be one of the best stealth games i have ever played.

As a person who has played through a decent amount of stealth games, Dihonored manages to shine though the croud and deliver on of the most unique experience in its genre.

Instead of being a highly cover based stealth game, Dishonored's most unique feature is its special abillities. During the game you will come across artifacts that give you points to spend on certian power ups such as the abillity to telleport, use possesion or summon rats.

Dishonored takes advantage of this with its open ended level design, there will be some places that can be difficult to get to without certian power ups, but there are usualy three or four ways to aproach each objectaive, for example in one mission you need to get to go from the start to your objectaive, to get there you could either... posses a fish and go though the gates to the sewers, have a good enough blink or jump abillity to run on top of the roofs and destroy the watch towers, walk through the back streets and go through waves of zombie like creatures  or just run through the middle of the big roads and most likly get yourself killed unless you are patient and carefull.

The world of dunwall is an amazingly crafted world, affected by a huge plage, with abbandoned streets and houses to the sewers over run by zobie-like biengs roaming around. This is a world that was made with great detail and a nice victorian style.

The story is decent, starting of with you being framed for a murder you now stride though the land, DISHONORED ;)
and the rest of the story unfolds aroud that.

The game has multable endings but I have never been abl to get the best one. I have beat the game twice and the endings were different, although i did not know what caused it to be different. In one of my endings one of your closest allies in the game was slightly hostile towards the end of the game, he was not like that in my other playthough.
There are two major endings one is the good ending" and the other is obiously the "bad ending" I have never managed to get the "good ending" but to get  it you have to apperently not kill as many people and help develop the city and not destroy it. On my second play though were I played in the hardest difficulty and  only really knocked a few people out I still got one of the bad endings so there is probably more factores into the endings but I am not fully aware.

As you go through the game the world either gets darker filled with more zombie infested lands or a brighter land filled with more guards. http://i.imgur.com/YV6gt.jpg?1
some of the side missions also affect things in the area and in future levels where you revisit certian areas.

The combat to the game is very fast in fun with many weapos to use although I didn't use it much due to me usually sneaking past everyone.

The game is around a 7.5-9 GB dowlaod and should probably work pretty well on most newish pc's.
I did not experience any crash issues.

I have not bought or played any of the DLC for this game

reviewText: Dishonored is the best game made by Arkane. It is able to balance well the action and stealth gameplay with a great level design. It is a game that allows you to play as you like without feeling to be railroaded or punished by adopting a certain play style or paths. Thus its replayability is high, even if the story feels like a fatality which you can't change much the outcome. However you can influence its morality, not by making the classical RPG two sided choices but by actually playing the game, each of your actions weights in the final result, which is quite an innovative game design standpoint that makes this game so special. On the pure artistic standpoint, it has a distinct personality that cast it apart from most productions. While a lot of the actual material and fluff of this game is purely optional, if you actually make a halt in your journey, read, watch and listen to all Dishonored has to offer you may discover it has a lot to say behind the actual game.

reviewText:
You can play this game two very different ways, or something inbetween, and each feels different. You can go a stealth approach and look for alternative pathways, and you can even go for a non-lethal solution in every mission. Or you can use all your powers and weaponry and have a good old slaughter.

What is really interesting is how the game is affected by your actions. Murder without restraint and you end up with a darker version of reality. Or keep it under wraps and keep things a little less chaotic.

The graphics of this game are something unique, in an art style that suits the somewhat Steampunk dystopian world. The level design is done well, plenty of nooks to explore but without getting lost. Alternative solutions to each mission make it replayable, and in two runs you can get all achievements if you so chose to. 'Hardcore' gamers will find joy in doing a non-lethal playthrough with no powers used, but there are also challenges for pushing certain skill combinations to the limit. And with the game being chopped into mission parts, which none the less flow into each other, you can easily sit down and play just a little bit.

The downside? It's a short game. DLC is cheap enough however, and you do get a quality experience for it which isn't dragged out because a game should be X hours long.

reviewText: Excelente jogo de Stealth. Com uma história de vingança não muito criativa mas competente e gráficos bonitos, ainda que não magníficos, mas com um gameplay diferenciado dos clássicos do gênero (e muito bom por sinal), esse jogo garante um bom tempo de diversão, especialmente pra quem curte stealth mas está um tanto cansado do combate com armas à distância e a perspectiva em terceira pessoa. A ambientação do jogo também é digna de nota, com uma boa variedade de cenários bem contruídos, ainda que não muito extensos, em sua maioria. Os locais que você visita passam competentemente a sensação de abandono e desolação que a história quer passar. Há também uma influência de RPG perceptível no gameplay do jogo, com uma boa porção de side-quests e ocasionais escolhas que não influenciam muito nem no decorrer da história, nem em seu final.

reviewText:
Dishonored, worth buying
Overall impression
It is not the most beautiful game when it comes to visuals. But the (various) storylines make it a very interesting and well-thought-out gaming experience. I have finished the main game and the DLC's now and I can honestly say that I am looking forward to my next play-through and find out more about the various options and search for all those things I have missed. The game is well-balanced. If you like to use your brain and stealth, this game offers you a nice challenge. If you prefer the more ruthless approach; go hogwild!

Player advice:
Save early, save often.

Bugs:
No major problems encountered.

Could be better:
I would have liked to see that Corvo had a little more personality. His story is 'okay' but he lacks a voice (literally) unlike Daud who does have a voice and several 'inner dialogues' that make you feel closer to the protagonist.

reviewText: The Empress has been killed and you are the scapegoat, you have been betrayed by the spymaster and his constituants to take control of Dunwall. You are set to assasinate and extract high valued targets that put you into prison and fight to overthrow the new corrupt Lord Regent. Play how you want to play in this action-stealth filled game, do you want to be a ghost who sneaks in the shadows and prefers non-lethal or do you want to go in with explosive shot pistol rounds and fight your way to your targets. The game makes great use of both with the blink power which is one of the better ideas I've seen in gaming in a while allowing you to short-distance teleport to either sneak around or counter and flank. I will say the game starts off rather slow and your more inclined to choose full frontal assault until you get your powers and learn the game a bit, but once you start it becomes very fun exploring the various routes and paths around enemies and blockades on your way to your targets. One of the few downsides is the dialogue, there arn't many recorded lines for npc's as they say will you hear about cigars and whisky, the chances are very good. 8/10

reviewText:
This is a great game in almost every way. It's a stealth FPS which follows the path of Corvo, who is wrongly accused of murdering the empress. So begins your journey through a vivid, interesting steam-punk world.

Anyone into the Thief games or stealth in general will find something to like here. This game however, also features an impressive ability set of magical" powers that you can acquire through runes and bone charms throughout the game. Some of these completely change the way you approach situations and are most welcome additions.

The only thing I was not to keen on was this "choice" you have over low or high chaos (stealth and not killing anyone or slaughtering everyone in your path). The game keeps on telling you to not kill people if you want the "good" ending
date: yet by doing so you miss out on some of the most fun powers and mechanics in the game. It's saying
recommended: here is an arsenal of cool stuff
hoursPlayed: but don't use them.\n\nAnyway
voteText: a great game in most respects that I would recommend to anyone interested in the genre.\n\nJimbo Rating: 7/10"

reviewText: Certainly one of the best games of this century. This isn't a generic stealth game like Splinter Cell or MGS. It isn't stealth only, you can also use a wide variety of gadgets or magical attacks and your trusty blade. It also includes side quests to obtain 'Runes' which are used to upgrade your magic or completing some quests may earn you 'Bone Charms' which add you a slight boost to things like Attack Speed,Health,Damage and so on. You may use non-lethal or lethal ways to eliminate your enemies it's your choice. Although being lethal/non-lethal may affect your ending. You will never get bored of this game. If you're not scavenging for supplies then you're sneaking your way past enemies or finding alternate ways to access buildings etc. Overall it's a brilliant game 10/10.

reviewText: There you are, in the shadows behind a trash bin, waiting for an enemy to walk by. It's very dark outside, only a miserable streetlight covering just a small part of the street; the gate. You know your life depends on what lies beyond the hard metal monster, you must get past it. You can't do anything but wait for now, so you decide to take a good look at it. You see sharp, steel pins on the top, so you know climbing over of it won't be an option. The door itself is toughened steel with a modern lock that you will never be able to pick. The gate is surrounded by many guards, and only one of them has the key. Then, suddenly, a guard leaves the group, probably for a small patrol round. You see him coming closer, and closer. You grab your knife and tighten your muscles. He is almost in range of the garbagecan. You wait for one more second, quickly pull him out of the enemies line of sight, and cut his throat. Blood gushes out of the open wound and your heart beats like crazy, while you search his pockets. And, nothing. God damn it, you can almost punch the ground out of anger. You think by yourself: 'you know what, f*ck this sh*t.' You grab a grenade, pull the pin and you hurl the explosive towards the enemies. You quickly hide behind the trash can and almost inmediatly hear the detonation. You look up. Everybody is dead. You think: 'Well, that was a lot easier than I thought.'\n\n10/10

reviewText:
I had extremely high hopes for Dishonored, and whilst it can be quite fun, I feel a little bit let down.

The style of the game is gorgeous, steampunk skylines and all that good stuff, very atmosphereic. I also like how you can complete the entire game without killing anyone.

Pros:

Messing around with the powers can be quite amusing.

Terrific Atmosphere.

Fun Acrobatics.

Cons:

The Story is...Pretty terrible, honestly. Incredibly predictable.

You're very encuraged to kill instead of sneak, seeing as most upgrades are for that purpose, whilst only 1 or 2 are for stealth.

I felt that I was far too powerful in the latter half of the game, it really took away from any tension.


Overall, it's a fun little game on it's own. However compared to the Thief games on merits of stealth, this pales in comparison.

reviewText:
Dishonored is an action/stealth game set in an alternative 19th century.
It was a pleasure to re-discover the gameplay and slick controls Arkhane Studios firstly developed in Dark Messiah of Might and Magic. Commands are so immediate and accurate that gameplay is only limited by player's skill and imagination. New abilities and upgrades expand the possibilities and the spectacularity of the kills, always stimulating the creativity.
The atmosphere of the city reflects the twisted ethics of its inhabitants: dazed by alcohol or confined in their manors, they're unable to react against the plague, which is devouring the slums, and the growing crime and violence. The portrait of this decadent society - as well as the loneliness of the protagonist - are even more clear from the different point of view of the DLCs.

A nice plot with suited characters only makes the background for one of the smoothest gameplay I’ve ever experienced.

91/100

reviewText:
This game. Man. This game. Right, so Arkane Studios had me at hello. Every game they had something to do with development in; I loved. Dark Messiah: Might & Magic was the first game I ever played by them, and man. I PLAYED THE MOTHER ♥♥♥♥ING ♥♥♥♥ OUT OF THAT GAME. Then Bioshock 2, CoD: WaW (level design).

This review might be slightly biased due to my love for both Bethesda and Arkane Studios; so heed my warning. I am also not judging the DLC that had been released for Dishonored, for I haven't even touched it.

Right, so after 85 hours, I can rightfully say that I practically know most of the game, inside and out. Played it on the hardest difficulty without killing anyone and without being spotted once through the entire playthrough.

So a brief rundown on what Dishonored is. It's a stealth based action game, based in a steampunk Victorian Britain. It's very much a choose your own path" game. You can run through it without killing a single being
date: or without being noticed by anyone; or you can get spotted by every one and decapitate them to your heart's content. Most of the level design also allows you to play through a map multiple  times
recommended:
finding lots of ways to clear them.

The game is very story intensive. But the beauty of it is; if you don't wish to explore the lore and story of every inch of the game's setting... Then don't. There are hundreds of books in the game. I literally mean hundreds. Which tell you the story of Dunwall and the isles that surround it. And you can choose to read none of them.

It's hard to say what's wrong with the game

reviewText: An extremely good stealth game, full of good ideas, excellent dialog and a wonderfully created grimdark-steampunk world that doesn't let you down at any point throughout it. Albeit somewhat limited in terms of what you can do with your enemies when attempting a non-lethal playthrough, it rewards you with varying dialogs and final missions depending on the decisions you end up taking, as well as better confrontation mechanics if you aren't shy to spill a little blood. All in all an excellent game that many a game developer should learn from.

reviewText:
Dishonored is an interesting take on the stealth genre, though I think it has some major flaws. The game takes place in a plague-ravaged, post-industrial world where the main source of power is derived from refined whale oil, which has somewhat mystical properties it seems. However, despite the engineering marvels of the day, there are also supernatural forces at play that bestow the player character with magic abilities.

For my very first time playing through the game, I chose the hardest difficulty available, turned off the 'cheaty' UI elements such as objective markers, and avoided using magic entirely (with the exception of the two or three places you absolutely must use Blink).

These are some of the things the game gets right:
- The atmosphere is quite unique
- There are a great number of ways to go about navigating through the missions
- You can choose non-lethal alternatives to completing objectives
- Graphics are very decent
- Smooth controls
- The game provides options for disabling UI elements, such as floating objective markers and NPC awareness markers.

These are some of my criticisms and observations:
- First of all, the Game of the Year edition comes with pre-order packs that give the player a bunch of free upgrades and money after the first mission. ♥♥♥♥ that! Why do game publishers do this? Thankfully, it is possible to get rid of the free ♥♥♥♥ by disabling the pre-order packs in Steam settings, then starting a new game.
- The plot of the story is extremely clichéd and predictable.
- The game introduces quite a bit of mystery surrounding the supernatural agent that your character comes in contact with, however there doesn't seem to be a story resolution that explains its motives. As a result, it feels like a shallow way to write in game-mechanics rather than being about good storytelling.
- While the missions themselves provide a lot of leeway as to how you go about completing them, the actual story progression is entirely linear. The choices the player makes ultimately have no impact the way the events of the story unfold.
- Enemies repeat the same lines over and over, which gets old very quickly.
- The characters you encounter throughout the game are fairly interesting, but your ways of interacting with them are extremely limited. They often feel like walking tape recorders set up to play their few lines of dialogue, rather than actual people.
- The game pushes you toward dealing with threats through lethal means by giving you a substantial arsenal of deadly weapons. Actually using them generally throws the concept of stealth out the window though.
- Very early on in the game, you get the Blink ability (teleport) as part of a tutorial and you can also choose to get Dark Vision (see through walls) immediately after. These abilities in particular make the gameplay utterly trivial. It is possible to use these an unlimited number of times and quickly speed through the game.

Overall Dishonored is a game worth playing, but I don't recommend it highly.

reviewText:
Stands tall on its gameplay, visuals and setting. Disappoints with a predictable main storyline.

*Spoiler free. Combined review discussing Dishonored, Dunwall City Trials, The Knife of Dunwall and The Brigmore Witches.*

I've never been a fan of the silent protagonist. Dishonored and its two DLCs, The Knife of Dunwall" and "The Brigmore Witches" present an interesting opportunity to play as both a silent and a voiced protagonist within essentially the same game. The main game has you playing as Corvo Attano who has a backstory but is otherwise a blank slate for you to control. Both DLCs put you behind the eyes of Daud
date: an assassin that you first run in to as Corvo. It would have been jarring to suddenly strip Daud of the voice he had in the original game
recommended: so he retains it into the DLCs and
hoursPlayed: in my opinion
voteText: they are better for it.\n\nAs Corvo
helpfulPercent: you sit and listen as characters monologue at you or talk to each other. As Daud
votesHelpful: you have conversations
votesTotal: relationships and motives of your own. Giving your protagonist a voice makes him or her interesting
votesFunny: allows for natural conversations and doesn't force the game's writers to avoid lines that would normally elicit a response. And it doesn't come at the cost of robbing players of making choices at key moments
commentsCount: as the DLCs demonstrate.\n\nThere are positives to get to
column16: but let me get through one more negative first. Dishonored's primary story and characters are mostly predictable
column17: standard fare. NPCs are limited to the aforementioned monologues that are generally kept short in favor of gameplay. Both DLCs are significantly better in this regard but don't expect RPG levels of depth. The voice acting
column18: however
column19: is all around excellent.\n\nThe main attraction of Dishonored is its gameplay. It's a fusion of stealth
column22: and both melee and ranged combat. All slickly delivered from a first-person perspective. Besides the blink spell (short range teleport)
column23: you are given the choice of what spells and upgrades you want to unlock first to best match your play style. There are two general play styles that result in different endings to the game: the nonlethal (often stealthy) "low chaos" path and the "high chaos" path that revels in death and battle. This is true in the DLCs as well. Whichever style you choose
column24: the level design will allow you numerous ways to get around and sometimes multiple ways to accomplish an objective. Game length can vary wildly with high chaos being the quicker route.\n\nWhile Dishonored's story may be lackluster
column25: the atmosphere of the world it takes place in is wonderful. The art and sound design both excel at bringing this place to life. The soundtrack takes a more subtle
column26: atmospheric approach that gets the job done but is otherwise unremarkable. You'll find notes and books scattered throughout the game that fill in the details of what goes on in this world. I hesitate to list this as a complaint
column27: but there is a spell that significantly alters how the world looks for the worse but is so useful that I rarely turned it off. It allows you to see enemies through walls while tinting everything orange (similar to the Batman Arkham games' detective mode).\n\nDunwall City Trials is exactly what it sounds like it is: purely gameplay. No story
column29: just arcade style pursuit of high scores. I would suggest replaying the rest of the game at a different chaos level than your first playthrough and then if you're still hungry for more
column30:
play these.

Dishonored: 7/10 --- 16 hours*
Dunwall City Trials: 5/10 --- 3 hours*
The Knife of Dunwall: 8/10 --- 6 hours
column31: no alerts or kills*\nThe Brigmore Witches: 8/10 --- 7 hours
column32: no alerts or kills*\n(* estimated playtime for my single low chaos playthrough)"

reviewText:
*Review Written on July 18th, 2013*

Dishonored recently went on sale on Steam. So, of course, I purchased it and got a bit obsessed. I dropped path of the exile, which had been consuming most of my time, and started playing. I ripped through the first level or two attempting stealth, but mostly ending up killing people. By the third level, I decided to go with a non-violent route.

Now, I’m going to stop right here and talk about how the general public has been treating Dishonored. Most people compare it to Assassin’s Creed, largely for two main reasons. Firstly, it released around the same time as the third Assassin’s Creed. Secondly, some of the gameplay has hints of Assassin’s Creed. This is a rather unfair comparision, however, and I’ll tell you why.

The first thing that struck me while I was playing this game in a more stealthy method, is that you’re stuck in first person the whole time. To most people, this is meaningless, it simply makes it a “bad stealth game”. To those of us, however, that grew up playing Thief: The Dark Project, I instantly switched to Thief mode. Yes, first person view does make it harder to be stealthy. However, unlike Thief, you can lean around corners in Dishonored. Yes, shadows don’t make you invisible in Dishonored, but so what? They don’t make you invisible in real life, either. Shadows were a mainstay in Thief, but in Dishonored, they weren’t as vital.

In Dishonored, you exchange shadows for ledges. In fact, the game is best played for stealth, if you’re good at thinking in 3d spaces. You cannot perform the parkour of Assassin’s Creed, but you’re not as clunky as in Thief. Thief relied on shadows, because you simply didn’t have the fluidity in the game to duck behind corners, or vault onto ledges. Dishonored simply requires you to think in a completely different way, and that throws a lot of people off.

Now, you -can- play Dishonored as a hack and slash action RPGlite, if you want. However, you’ll unlock the bad ending that way, and you won’t get half of the achievements. If anything, the achievements, and ability to “Ghost” an entire level, is a callout to the Thief series.

So I played my first playthrough of Dishonored, as I would have played Thief, and I had a FANTASTIC time playing the game. That said, I probably wouldn’t play the game a second time through as a non-violent stealther, but I might give it a go, one day, as a rabid, swashbuckling mass-murderer. You know, for the bad end and all that.

If you were on the ledge about Dishonored, I can tell you this. Take the game without comparing it to other titles, and you’ll find a fairly fun, well-polished, and smooth game. Sure, there are the rare bugs, but in a gaming world where bugs are becoming more common place among shipped titles, they’re considerably rare. The game really only has three playthroughs in it for someone like me, who devours content and then moves on, but completionists might find a good two or three months of gameplay out of it. Considering the amount of time invested, compared to the money invested, any price tag under 20 dollars is a fair trade off these days.

reviewText:
THE FOLLOWING CONTAINS MINOR SPOILERS

If it were about how much fun I had, this game would easily be the 9/10 that a lot of 'critics' seem to have awarded it. I absolutely loved the world of Dishonored, the washed-out watercoloury art style slotted in perfectly with the nice blend of Steampunk/Old England. I loved the clothing designs (including Corvo's mask of course), and the weapons were really cool in my opinion as well. Blinking from rooftop to alleyway, dashing around guards and taking out targets was an amazingly fun experience for me in Dishonored.

But despite all this I've said, looking at Dishonored from a critical standpoint reveals that it is honestly a mediocre game at best. An example of 'stealth done wrong', with basic elements like hiding bodies and using the environment to avoid combat encouraged only by the prospect of a 'good ending' and a couple achievements. The skill trees" are what really make the game fall short. If you want to end the game not being treated like a blood thirsty merciless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ then you must choose to avoid about 70% of basically ♥♥♥♥ing everything. A whole bunch of skills are virtually useless and some even unusable if you want to keep your chaos (the Good/Neutral/Evil system that is really more like Good/Evil/Satan-Incarnate) low. Lets not forget that using any weapons other than your crossbow
date: with sleep darts only of course
recommended: are strictly off limits as well (minus the choking ability that didn't even have a default keybind on the PC version). Yes
hoursPlayed: that includes that cool rewiring tool that you can use to make the turrets and electric gates only affect the bad guys. Oh
voteText: and to top it all off the game has a huge difficulty flaw in terms of being able to cheese through a whole bunch of the levels if you've maxed out blink and agility.\n\nThe characters are pretty boring and one dimensional also
helpfulPercent: with clique traits following a clique storyline with *surprise* clique betrayals. The plot twists aren't even that much of a shock to player anyway
votesHelpful: as we're barely given much of a chance to do anything with any of the characters we meet before we're shipped off to do another assassination. At least the non-lethal ways of taking out said targets are creative. The bad guys are all typical power hungry schemers or simply megalomaniacs
votesTotal: with the only one who has any bit of depth being Daud and possibly Havelock in the final scene. Corvo is a silent protagonist
votesFunny: not the kind that you can project yourself onto though however. Corvo has more than just a name
commentsCount: he has a backstory with possible love-related connections. You can't fit yourself entirely onto a canvas that's already half full
column16: which has resulted in Convo simply being a really boring character where the only thing you have control over is if he decides to become a horrendous murderer and essentially doom everything by passing on his bad traits to the game's damsel: Princess Emily.\n\nDespite all I've just said
column17: it'd probably be hard for you to believe that Dishonored is one of my favourite games. I just like playing it
column18: despite its horrific flaws and awful characters/plot/mechanics I still find it enjoyable simply because this lame kinda genre appeals to me personally as the type of game I like jump into every now and again. I encourage you to play it for yourself before deciding on whether my judgements on the game are fair or not; I definitly recommend it for a quick playthrough if you're looking for something different yet not necessarily fresh. Thanks for reading!"

reviewText:
This game was really fun.

The gameplay is a first person action/rpgish type game.  You level up certain skills, your right hand is always a sword while your left is gun/powers/crossbow/etc.  You can rely on stealth of various methods or you can just go running in trying to blow stuff up.  The graphics are fine, the gameplay seemed pretty solid as in I didn't have any glitches.  I found the powers you get to be really fun to use and enhance the going stealth or not stealth (which ever you want).  Story is somewhat predictable, but that doesn't take away from the overall experience.  The game let's you go through on a no kill run.  There are alternatives for everything that needs to be done so a complete no kill run is possible.

So far I've completed it once and I went what woudl be considered the 'good' path.  I've already started a 'bad/dark' path to change things up.  Haven't made it to the DLC yet either but that will be after the dark path is finished.  You should look into this!

reviewText: Pretty damn good game. Fun interesting gameplay with many choices to be made. The game can be tailored to your playstyle. Whether a barbaric serial killer, or a pacifist saint, options are always available. World design is excellent, and the graphics are distinct. My only real problem with this game is the powers. It is really fun to play lethally, in fact it is also more challenging. If you play non-lethally, like I did, it's not as fun. You'll be choking people out your entire playthrough, seeing the same animaiton play over and over again. Not only this, but it makes the game easier. For those of us who want a challenge, and still want to play the role of the pacifast, this isn't a good atribute.

reviewText:
Yes this is a great game.

Dynamic playthrough, great story and interesting challenges.

Similar to Games like Splinter Cell, Thief, and somewhat Asasin Creed it is in the genre of a underdog shadow assasin saga.

for Pros..
The good thing is new folks can get into some heavy lifting as it teachs you step by step to become an ultimate stealth shadow. It can also inspire disinterested folks to get into this genre.

cons..
However the gameplay style can" get repetitive as the game closes to the end. The players "adjust" and things can look quite simple as he/she gains experience.

Since this is a non multiplayer and currently a closed dev. game I'd say go torrent if you are wanting to be frugal.
But like I said above
date: it does deserve praise and worth the quality.\nConsider buying it if you want to respect the developers."

reviewText: Dishonored is really great. Plenty of Thief influences and allusions, and what Deus Ex 3 should have been more like: Open environments, multiple paths that don't feel deliberate, plenty of optional areas to explore, quests/player actions have repelling affects, non-lethal options throughout, no stupid boss fights, no nonsensical mini-games...this is grand. Combat is similar to Arkane's Dark Messiah except you're a teleporting badass with super powers and clockwork gadgetry. Bonus points for the unique art direction and the interesting Victorian industrialized city setting replete with an authoritarian regime stymied by a killer rat plague. GOTY material right here.

reviewText:
Pretty fun game, similar to Thief, and actually really in-depth and very atmospheric. Decent story and characters, plus a steampunk/victorian themed world, which is fairly unique for a game.

At first I didn't rate this game that much, the starting section didn't really seem to grab my enthusiasm. But as soon as the game opened up and sent you to your first mission, the game became amazing, you can tackle the levels in a multitude of ways, and it sort resembles a crossover of Thief and Deus Ex in that respect.

Once you get the powers, it gets much more fun too. There's also lots of different fun to use equipment, with melee or ranged combat, and lots of hidden and extra stuff to find.

One thing is that game wasn't too great to play on my old rig, which was 3/4 years old, it's much more enjoyable to play on my new pc, so that might be something you should check on the spec requirements.

I'd rate it 9/10 easily.

reviewText: Challenging but fair, Dishonored is totally worth your money and time, i would even say that this is the best stealth game you will find these days. Will you go out for revenge? Or will you spare them? This is up for you to decide. The only downside its the duration. 9.5 is my rating, i enjoyed my time with Dishonored immensely, and the game design and mechanics are so clever that you will love every single one of them.

I give this game an 8/10.

reviewText:
I tried Dishonored back when it first came back on the 360 and while I thought it looked cool and sounded cooler; it just didn't grab me.  It kept nagging at me though because I thought it was definitely a game I should like.  I gave in during the summer sale and and I’ll be honest; I hit a point at the very beginning where it still didn't grab me.  This time, I pushed through my frustration and it turns out, I love this game!

I was totally caught up in the story and I really dug Korvo.  I was even caught a bit by surprise by the twists and turns that happen.  Hell, I even fell in love with the world of Dunwall and the side stories you find in all the books that you collect along the way.  The Outsiders powers are fun though I really only used Blink and The Ash powers, but they fit well with the combat they've built into the game.

Early on, it was the fact that they give you wide open maps and leave it up to you to figure out how to get get through them that overwhelmed me.  Once I figured out that the key to playing Dishonored is to explore and make your own way, the game really opened up for me and turned into something special.

reviewText:
Dishonored.. Where do I begin!

Let me begin by saying I have 50+ hours in this game, without the dlc and I plan to play alot more aswel as buy the dlc, and it is also one of my favorite games. (probably in my top 30, but I've played alot of games)

TL;DR If this is the game you'd normally play and it looks good, buy it, it's worth it.

[MILD SPOILERS MIGHT BE AHEAD]
The Story
So it all begins with our silent protagonist named Corvo who is the bodyguard of the empress, he was on a mission to seek help from other cities, when he returned the empress was murdered right infront of him and her daughter, Emily kidnapped, Corvo found by the Royal Spymaster with the dead empress in his arms, is arrested and thrown in prison, his appending death awaits him - This is only the intro to the story, things get much more eventful and fun.

The Graphics
The textures are not the best, but they certainly aren't bad, deffinetly playable.



The sound track I have to admit I didn't listen to much, I was distracted by murdering hundreds of people without even being seen, though the voice acting is good.

Gameplay
There are ranged weapons, tools, and supernatrual powers.

You have a choice of plenty of different weapons depending on how you want to play, you can choose to play High Chaos or Low Chaos, if you kill lots of people you'll get High Chaos (per mission), if you don't kill over 3-5 people (per mission) you'll get Low Chaos, on HC you'll get more rats, more weepers, and it will influence Emily negativly, effectivly giving you the bad end"
date: on LC you'll get less rats
hoursPlayed: and it will influence Emily positivly
voteText: effectivly giving you the "good end"\n\nIf you want to play HC
helpfulPercent: there are different tools and weapons ranging from your default sword to grenades
votesHelpful: and even rewiring eletric devices made by the enemy and kill them with it
votesTotal: you can even summoun rat swarms to do the killing and rid of bodies for you.\n\nIf you want to play LW
votesFunny: there are different tools and weapons ranging from choking and knocking out enemies to sleep darts
commentsCount: possesing people without killing them
column16:
and even freezing time to walk straight infront of your enemy without them ever knowing.


Over all
Story is intreasting and eventful - 8/10

Graphics are decent and get the job done - 5/10

Gameplay is fun and gives you plenty of different options to get the job done - 10/10

I'd recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of the genre!"

reviewText:
I used to play this on xBox, and I'm glad I purchased it again.
Dishonored is probably one of my all time favourite games, it has great level design, a great story, great scenery, great characters and great gameplay.
It's a very well optimized game - my PC is not the greatest, and yet I can run it smoothly on 60fps without as much as a stutter.

The only negative thing about this game is that it's so short. If you play it stealthily, you will probably have more fun and it'll last you about 12 - 15 hours at best, wheras if you just hack and slash your way through the streets of Dunwall then it won't take very long at all to reach the end at about 5 - 7 hours.

Super hyped for the sequel
This game is a must to anyone who loves stealth.

Would absolutely reccomend

Optimized / 10



The boldest measures are the safest.

reviewText:
I used to play this on xBox, and I'm glad I purchased it again.
Dishonored is probably one of my all time favourite games, it has great level design, a great story, great scenery, great characters and great gameplay.
It's a very well optimized game - my PC is not the greatest, and yet I can run it smoothly on 60fps without as much as a stutter.

The only negative thing about this game is that it's so short. If you play it stealthily, you will probably have more fun and it'll last you about 12 - 15 hours at best, wheras if you just hack and slash your way through the streets of Dunwall then it won't take very long at all to reach the end at about 5 - 7 hours.

Super hyped for the sequel
This game is a must to anyone who loves stealth.

Would absolutely reccomend

Optimized / 10

reviewText:
Arkane studios did it again!

Let me start off by saying that I loved The Dark Messiah which was also done by same studio. That game was greatly underrated. It had the RPG elements, stealth, great storyline, engaging narrative, great voice-acting, exploration, choice and a few of insane twists, orcs, demons, hot chicks, lust, the ability to kick, the ability to set off traps, alternate paths, dragons, mages, and a long single player campaign. I attempted to review that game on several occasions but failed every time. The game should just be played.


This game follows The Dark Messiah in its footsteps. The melee fighting is nailed once again (unlike in Skyrim). Your melee blows feel real, you can almost feel the weight of your blows and the damage to the enemies is realistic. You don't have to hit someone over the head with a mace ten times for them to die (ahem...Skyrim...ahem...). Overall, we get tight controls, responsive and properly ported mouse, the ability to peek left or right, the ability to climb obstacles. The movement of the character has been nailed perfectly. You move fast when moving forward and you move slow when moving sideways. I should say that it wouldn't hurt for this game to have the kicking ability just like in the Dark Messiah. There are certain instances where you can push the unaware enemies from ledges.


As far as the graphics go. Well, it's nice see a slightly cartoony-Rage-like rendition of the Unreal Engine 3.0, but seriously, why isn't this engine on life support yet? The textures are static, the trees do not move, the faces look like lifeless chunks of plastic. The water looks horrible but swimming under water looks and feels pretty realistic. The DX9 lighting is okaish. The artistic style however almost makes up for the old engine. I wish there were more graphic options to beef up the visuals. However, you can't see your legs and you cast no shadow. It's ironic that in some instances The Source Engine rendition in The Dark Messiah looks better than in this game (that's a 6 year difference).


The gameplay is where the game shines (especially the melee). The melee fights are as satisfying as ever although they don't last as long as in the Dark Messiah. You get to wield a melee weapon and a range weapon. There are plenty of upgrades that you get at your home base, as long as you have the coins and the proper blueprints. The stealth has been pulled off pretty well, which is further expanded with the ability to hid bodies. Although there's no indication if you are hidden or not so you have to rely on your instincts. You have a choice of knocking out or slaying your unaware foes but if things go sour you can easily dispatch them with your weapons too. That happens to be one of the few gripes I have with the game, even though some enemies get tougher later in the game. You also get to teleport which I think makes the game easier in oh so many ways. You also get to collect magic runes and put them towards your character development, (higher jump, more health, the ability to see in the dark, etc.)


I won't spoil the story much. You play as a mute imperial bodyguard/turned assassin, Corvo, bent on restoring the imperial throne and avenging the conspirators in a dystopian alternate reality world. I don't know why FPS developers are having such a difficulty with adding voice to the main character, it kills the immersion. Anyways, you get to put the pieces together, discover what the world has to offer and seek for clues for how the rat plague started. It's also interesting to meet various characters. Each one of them offers something a different view on reality and the nature of society. You get to do secondary quests and backtrack throughout the world. Overall, the pacing of the game feels real.

There are moments when you don't have to fight enemies for a long time if you want the game to play life Thief. You also don't get to fight hordes of enemies although you are almost always in danger of being discovered. And even WHEN you are discovered you can quickly dispatch the enemies. I feel there should have been more danger and repercussions for being discovered. Although, if you play on hardest difficulty, it will only take a guard to slice you 3 times for you to die (maybe 5 with the health upgrade). You can also fight every enemy you see and clear the areas that way although you may run out of ammo quickly.


Overall, this is a great game with many twists and epic moments although there is some slight imbalance as far as your super-powers go, otherwise, everything else has been nailed pretty well. Don't forget, this is a Single-Player only game, which is saying a lot these days.

A LOT of love and effort went into this game.

Story: 24/25 Gameplay: 20/25 Graphics: 24/25 Sound: 25/25

The combat ... if you get stuck and aren't good at blocking. Just run, you WILL die. My other qualm with the gameplay is that if you wish to get the good ending, then half the skills are useless as they are detrimental to the goal of getting that ending. The graphics are awesome with a fairly unique style that I didn't expect in this sort of game, but it works very well and makes the world a lot more interesting. The sound is exactly what I expected from a stealth game. Very good and crisp, so you always knew where the enemies were. so, get this game or pray that the masked man of Dunwall doesn't find you.

reviewText:
It's hard not to recommend this game!

Graphically, it's beautiful; the blooming effect over the buildings are superb.

The action is fluid and the game lets you choose what type of gameplay you will go for, stealth or combat, weapons or magic, murder or nonlethal, or a mix of everything. And the game's most impressive feat is that all of these methods work equally well.

The story, though neither revolutionary nor unpredictable, still is entertaining, with nice bits of steampunk lore spread here and there, and some sidequests, which you are free to ignore if you just want to play.
There are also collectibles and treasures to find for those who like this kind of stuff, but it's still entirely facultative towards your progression.

All these elements show how much the game caters to everyone's taste, and it's why it can easily be recommended just for about anyone.

The multiple gameplay possibilities provide some replay value, which is a good thing since the game is not very long (11 hrs for a playthrough - and that's reading every book and searching for most collectibles).

The normal difficulty is slightly too easy: there are too many potions and ammo scattered everywhere to make it any challenging at all. For any person who likes a challenge I would recommend to do the first playthrough in hard, or to go for the no kills playthrough achievement.

Objectives are permanently highlighted on the HUD which also makes the game easy, but you can switch them off in your option if you want to explore by yourself.

I've had only two gripes with this game. Firstly all the unimportant pedestrians' faces are the same. Some variety would have been nice as it's a bit like walking in a clone world.

Finally an annoying bug: the saved games don't seem to recall the enemy positions accurately so occasionally I have reloaded a save where I was in a stealthed position, only to find myself in the middle of enemies who would immediately discover me.

These inconveniences are of course very minor compared to the pleasure it was playing this game through. Go ahead and try it; you will enjoy the freedom of possibilities!

reviewText:
Dishonored is a first-person stealth action-adventure game set in the fictional plague ridden city of Dunwall. You play as Corvo Attano, body guard to the Empress and friend to her young daughter Emily. Framed for murder, you are forced to become an assassin and spend the majority of the game seeking those who wronged you.

Gameplay for a single campaign can last anywhere from 15 to 40 hours, depending on how you go about accomplishing your objectives.

Because of the games steam punk inspired art style the graphics still look great, despite it being almost four years old.

This game boasts a quality soundtrack, gameplay that can be tailored to a wide range of styles, good artistic direction and a compelling story, but my favorite aspect of Dishonored is what a big emphasis it puts on players choice.

The game allows you to complete each mission in a variety of ways. The more you explore your environment the more options become available to you. Because of this, how you chose to reach and accomplish objectives impacts the environment and the way the story progresses. You can do ‘low chaos’ or ‘high chaos’ runs - deciding to use stealth, weapons, or magic to move forward.

Creating panic and leaving dead bodies spreads disease, increasing the number of rats and weepers roaming Dunwall city streets. Operating under stealth and choosing to spare people usually takes takes more effort, but will make the ending to your story a happier one. Making different choices vastly alters your environment and how NPCs react to you in the game, giving it good replay value.

The DLCs included in the GOTY addition are worth playing. They do a good job of continuing and complementing the story but are not necessary for it to feel complete, which is how downloadable content should be.

reviewText:
Despite this game's best attempts, I enjoyed it.

The story is poorly presented. An interesting world is painted, but the details are obtained through the optional mid-mission, flow breaking reading of found diaries and letters. Pass. The gameplay and missions are quite engaging... stopping to read a wall of text about someone's cousin coming to visit is counter-productive. Feeling obligated to stop and read the final enemy's diary mid-climax is maddening.

With its score keeping system, Dishonored also attempts to steer you towards a strict non-lethal approach... granting intangible bonuses for not being seen or killing anyone. Which is a shame since it's at its best when you're able to use all the wonderful tools it gives you. When 9/10 of your options for getting through any given situation are lethal, feeling compelled to avoid them is cheating yourself out of gameplay. After a few levels, I decided to open up the playbook and feel free to kill when beneficial to the objective... and the game came alive. Dropping from a rooftop sword first onto a guard, shooting his friend, then countering and stabbing a 3rd before vanishing into the shadows is fun as hell. There is no non-lethal equivalent.

Lest you think I'm just bloodthirsty....
There's only one level, the Lady Boyle encounter, where the purely non-lethal approach is just as viable as the lethal ones... and it was my favorite segment. Everyone lived, though not everyone left happy :)

Play naturally. Embrace high" chaos. Dishonored is fun."

reviewText: This game, created by Arkane Studios but published from Bethesda, has everything a fan of stealth, story, gameplay and RPG needs. The graphics are wonderfully stylised, with a selection of interesting characters that aren't too out of the ordinary, but not bland enough to make you forget them. The protagonist in particular, Corvo, is wonderfully created, so you can imagine what kind of man he would be and play him to that image, whether he's the forgiving kind of killer or whether he just wants to see Dunwall burn. The story-line is intriguing and there's plenty of different turns you don't expect that I've enjoyed so far. Plus I love the man eating rats. The game has levels of customisation whether you want to use a gun, crossbow or the supernatural powers you're given early in the game, with plenty of collectbles to find each mission and requires a level of intelligence to find, as getting to them are sometimes puzzling. So far I simply adore this game and if you're a fan of Assassin's Creed, Thief and Bethesda's works, I can't recommend this game enough.

reviewText: Dishonored is fantastic.  It’s stealth mechanics are handled expertly and are balanced nicely with supernatural powers and fast-paced combat.  I’ve played the game through a few times and I enjoyed both stealth heavy and combat heavy playthroughs.  Additionally, the visual presentation, sound design, and music are all really well done and each made a good impression.\n\nComplementing the fun gameplay is some wonderful world building and storytelling.  Characters are believably flawed and nuanced, and I became invested in Corvo’s quest for revenge or redemption.  But stealing the show was the city of Dunwall.  Dunwall is a marvelous setting and I really liked the blend of steampunk, gothic, and Victorian elements.  I’d love to get to see more of this fascinating world that has been created and look forward to any further entries in the series.

reviewText:
A lot of things went through my mind while I played Dishonored. I'd read a lot of things about the game before its release, and I'd read a few reviews and opinions here and there after the fact, but by and large I knew little to nothing about the story besides the basics: you play as an assassin named Corvo; you have a plethora of interesting weapons and supernatural powers; and you're arrested, dishonored (lol) and almost executed for a crime you didn't commit.

So overall, my expectations were set at a middling level; I knew Harvey Smith, one of the designers of the original Deus Ex, was largely involved, but I worried that perhaps this wouldn't mean much, and I'd be funneled through corridors with little choice as to how events unfolded.

Boy, was I wrong. Dishonored drops you in with some very basic in-game tutorials disguised as everyday routines, and it's a beautiful world. The characters seem alive, the landscapes are vast and interesting, and the music eases you into the experience.

Then it all goes wrong, and the ride really begins. The pacing of Dishonored is superb; just when you think you've come to understand the basics of a level, the next level is something completely different. Whether it's infiltrating a high society party, escaping from plague victims and guards alike in broken-down buildings, or breaking into high-rise penthouses, the experience is always fresh and you're always given countless ways to achieve your objectives.

Along the way, you'll pick up Runes, which allow you to purchase and upgrade new powers (and I want to note that throughout my experience, there were a few powers I never played with; Runes aren't scarce, but you will have to budget them well), ranging from a simple powerup that makes the bodies of enemies you kill while unaware disappear to a (somewhat gloriously broken) power that stops time completely, allowing you to set up various murders and let them all happen simultaneously.
You'll also pick up Bone Charms, which have subtle effects on your gameplay such as slightly faster sword attacks or potions giving you more mana.

Each location that you find yourself murdering or non-lethally choking or avoiding confrontation through is beautifully designed, and offers multiple paths to your objectives, including optional objectives that aren't always easy to find. Truly, this is as close to a modern day Deus Ex as we're likely to get anytime soon.

The story is interesting, full of twists and turns, and your actions play huge parts in how it all unfolds. It's touching at times and sickening at others, and it all feels very cohesive.

I hesitate to call anything my GOTY without playing everything released in that year, so I'll just say that Dishonored is one of my Games of All Time. Much closer to Deus Ex than DX:Human Revolution, filled with creativity and choice.

A masterpiece.

reviewText:
My opinion about this game is a mixed bag. There are a lot of things that this game makes incredible well, and then there are some others that suck balls beyond EA levels.

First of all, the price. The hell is this. I don't know if they changed it recently, but this game has stayed with a price tag of 60€ for a year or two after it's release. Is the game long? No. The game has multiplayer? No. Coop? No. Does it deserve the 60€'s?

F#CK NO. Personally, my brother picked up this game in a sale for me as a gift, for 3€, and I think that's what is worth for a semi-dull single-player experience. Yes, I said dull. Here's why.

The story, while it's quite interesting at first, there are points that get a bit boring, because it's usually the same thing over and over, even with some of those small maps re-used with little changes. And the story does have something worse, but that's still to come. So, what's up with the gameplay?

It's kind of flawed. You see, you're extremely over-powered. The enemies have NO DAMN CHANCE against you, because of either their massive brain damage, or bad programming. It's easy to beat them up with a handful of slashes with the sword, it's easy to execute them with a pistol, it's easy to screw them up with a crowssbow, it's HELL EASY to sneak up on them and cut their throats, and don't even get me started on the non-lethal methods. And that's the problem I was talking about before:

There are multiple endings, and there are tons of fun ways to annihilate those peasants the game tells you they're your enemies. But you know what? Killing people won't allow you to see the GOOD ending. And is it fun to sneak up on people and ocasionally knock down the few guards who won't let you go unseen? Frankly, no. I love stealth based games, like Deus Ex. And in Deus Ex HR, they did a good job with all of that crap. But in here? They kinda messed it up. Stealth is boring, combat is fun, yet repetitive, BUT YOU WON'T GET ANYTHING GOOD OUT OF IT, SO STAY IN THE SHADOWS AND GET BORED.

The game also has a few DLC's, but seriously, why should I give a crap about mission-packs, and why they expect me to pay for them? I do recommend this game, don't get me wrong. It's fun for a while. But you should not buy it at full price, unless you like wasting money. Calling this a stealth game is like calling modern CoD games GOOD. This is, rather, a weird hack-n-slash game, with some escort missions and stealth based gameplay. So, 3€ for this? Fine. 60€? F#ck off.

And this thing better not get any sequels. I don't want to see Dishonored 2 for 70€ for the rest of my life.

EDIT: F#ck my life, it's actually getting a sequel. I CALLED IT, I FORESAW THIS!

reviewText:
Dishonored by Arkane Studios brought back the memories of classic PC games like Thief or Deus Ex, the constant need of exploring just one another room, reading just another little note, and then ending up playing for 10 hours straight. Games like these are a rarity in this day and age. This is not your average cookie-cutter first person shooter; I’d even dare to call it a first person stealth choose-your-own-adventure game. You can play it like an FPS. You can play it as a stealth game. You can play it as a mix of both. You can kill everyone in the room, or you can leave no trace behind. The choice is yours.

You control Corvo Attano, a personal bodyguard to the Empress of Dunwall, a fictional steampunk city based on London (though all the voice actors are American, which is a weird decision). About a minute into the game the Empress gets killed, her daughter gets kidnapped, and you get framed for the murder of Her Highness.  Exploring the beautifully crafted city is a great pleasure, although the actual situation in the city is far from lovely. Not only is the crime rampant, but the rat plague is killing citizens not by dozens or hundreds, but by thousands. During your playthrough, about half of Dunwall is already dead, as commented by the city guard. The moments in games when I think “wait, this is ♥♥♥♥ed up” are extremely rare. Seeing a wagon dropping dozens of dead bodies was one of those moments. The wagon appears again and again, throwing off bodies wrapped up in filthy bandages. It empties up and returns full again. The world of Dishonored is brutal, every character you encounter has his own agendas and reasons for acting the way he acts, and nothing is ever black or white.

The approach you take when blasting (stealthing?) through missions is entirely up to you, and you have a nice variety of supernatural powers at your disposal. Do you want to wreak havoc upon your enemies? You’re likely to invest in a Devouring Swarm ability, which creates a devouring swarm (sic) of rats that attack your enemy and then clean up by eating their body. Neat. Are you MGS or pre-2006 Splinter Cell fan? You’ll probably want to upgrade Dark Vision and Possession, one of the most useful tools when it comes to stealth playthrough. Each of the nine missions is designed as a sandbox. Theoretically you could go for an objective marker (which you can turn off, by the way) and finish Dishonored in about 5 hours. But if you want to do that, it’s not the game for you. There are multiple sidequests in each of the missions, and some of them will bring repercussions in the future. The game offers you a choice- do you want a free rune that lets you upgrade your character? OK, but you’re going to have to poison Dunwall’s distillery by the request of a crazy lady. Do you want to kill the real murderer of the Empress, or give him a message and only steal his pouch that he carries by his side? Regardless of your choice, it’s worth playing through the game a second time, just to see the different ways people react to you whether you slaughter everyone or leave unnoticed. By the way- even though you’re an assassin, you can finish the game without killing a single person. That’s right. In times when 3-hour-long corridor shooters earn numerous GOTY awards and critical acclaim, an offer of a choice like this is an excellent touch.

Summing up, Dishonored is a game that begs to be played at least twice. No playthrough will be the same, whether because you choose to end a sidequest differently, upgrade your character in a different manner, or skipping some chunks of content by mistake, because you weren’t patient enough to listen to the guards’ conversation which unlocked a non-lethal way to accomplish your assignment. The over the top picturesque artistic design, fantastic supernatural abilities, excellent voice acting and music, and most importantly- the freedom to tackle the missions in dozens of different ways make this my game of the year.

reviewText:
Incredible game, smooth gameplay, brilliant story. It's a cross between two other incredible games: Rage and Half Life 2.  Set in the 1800s, before the wide use of crude oil, the game's characters fuel their world with refined whale oil. There is a Technocracy which suffers some political drama at the start of the game that the player has to advance from.

The controls are simple and yet there are so many options for play and movement. I did get stuck in two places in the game where my avatar could not move and I had to load from autosave. I felt that something I shouldn't have happen in an AAA game. However, the game is so incredible in every other way that I just overload it!

I highly recommend this game and it's one of the few games where I play it from start to finish. I may even play it again, which is something I don't think I've done for ANY GAME EVER!

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game! If you haven't played it yet and you love games with alternate play styles, engaging storylines and RP choices that have actual impacts on your playthrough, then you're missing out. Keep in mind I may be biased as I normally love any kind of dark, gritty story that takes place in a dystopian society... However trust me when I say that this game is absolutely brilliant! I loved how it was acceptable for me to progress through quests with a clear objective, then to decide halfway through that I did not agree with it and do something completely different to make the ends meet.

I was not led by hand through the game, I was allowed to play as I saw fit; It could be anything from scaling the chandeliers of a house to protecting a local thug from a crazy old bat. With every playthrough I discover something new, characters reacting to me in a different manner, new opportunities, stumbling upon side-characters I've never met before because I chose a different route and so on.

However I do have a wee bit of nitpicking, very insignificant though I might add. I would've appreciated a short prologue in which I was allowed to get to know the Empress and Emily, I found myself not caring much for them, Emily did grow on me though as I got to interact with her. I also would've have liked more side quests that aren't DLCs, while it was refreshing that there were few, I also felt that they were so well made that I sort of wanted more...

TL;DR - 10/10

reviewText:
Atmospheric, well written, and incredibly fun gameplay. The pacing of game machanics alone are realistic, introducing themes and world aspects as the story changes and shifts.
1. Atmospheric: Felt at the level of the first Bioshock, or even Portal 2. I think that's all I need to say.
2. Well written: Good story and pacing. I found a few secrets before they were meant to be revealed, and some secrets I didn't figure out till the closing chapter of the game. But I like that not all is revealed to you, that you have to think about it to figure something out, or it's there to be found if you go exploring in the world. Story told through gameplay and your own intuition.
3. Fun gameplay: The first time I killed someone I said What even are hit boxes?". And that wasn't fair at all to how this game plays. You are either spotted or sneaking past. And the ways they allow you to sneak past makes this one of the best game play experiences I've ever had. Every I time I "Blinked" to get behind an enemy
recommended: or dissapear from an enemy on patrol
hoursPlayed: I was on the edge of my seat.\nI honestly give this game 10/10"

reviewText:
Finally got round to playing this game after picking it up for 4.99 a year ago! There's three things I really like about it:

1. The playability. Movement is smooth and controls intuitive. And you can make lots of customisations to the user interface to make it play exactly as you like it.
2. The steam achievements. There's loads of them and they make you do things in the game you wouldn't normally think about. Adds a layer of depth.
3. Stealth versus lethal. And the combination of weapons and powers. Being able to play the game as you want to in your own style and not be penalised for it, instead it simply changes the story slightly. Genius.

I can see why it scored over 90 in the metacritic score. Excellent game and well worth the fiver!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I like stealth games, so I decided to give Dishonored a go. It is fairly good, but who wouldn't expect that from the same guys who made Arx Fatalis?

The story is compelling. I'll try and spell this out for you while forgoing the spoilers.
You're Corvo, an agent and bodyguard of the Empress, but something terrible happens and you're to blame, stripped of all honorable titles. You must, with the help of some friends, stealthily take down or kill your way through the people who've set you up as the fall guy.

The gameplay is simple and probably deceptively so.
Basically, you're given the an objective, such as, Get from point A to point B and eliminate this target." You'll encounter enemies along the way and you will have to decided to either kill them
date: eliminate them non-leathally or just sneak past.\nTo aid you in your quests you're given tools of magically fast loading flintlock pistols and crossbows
recommended: a sword and some special abilities. These special abilities will help you either sneak or kill. The most important is probably "blink." It's sort of like a teleport
hoursPlayed: but it's not instantaneous and enemies can see you if you blink in front of them. You can also stop time
voteText: possess people and animals
helpfulPercent: the obligatory "reveal all enemies and obsticles for a short period of time" stealth game ability and some other cool stuff.\n\nThe soundwork is pretty good. Nice
votesHelpful: crunchy dissonant orchestral work juxtaposed with some beautiful stuff. My only complaint is that there was one point where there were some fireworks and the sound actually clipped. I hadn't experienced that in a AAA title for... in recent memory. It's not that big of a deal though.\n\nThe level design is great
votesTotal: as it should be. Stealth games rely on good level design and this one doesn't pull any punches. Almost every enemy encounter is a puzzle in itself with more than a few solutions =)\n\nAll in all
votesFunny: I'd say I'm pretty happy with Dishonored. I haven't played the DLC
commentsCount: but I'll get into that later."

reviewText: Great game, spent 200 h on it and still not enough. Try play different ways, sneak around or kill everything in your way. Find different paths to the target, sometimes in water, sometimes on the roof. The battle system is great, and the magics are awesome. DLCs forced player to get familiar with every skill, even when you didn't use it in your main playthrough. The knife oif Dunwall and Brigmore wiches offered player a different view of Dunwall city, and made Daud, one of the most tough enemies in the main game, alive. Now all I'm doing is waiting for Dishonored II to come out, if Bethesda and Arkane are planning to make one.

reviewText: An interesting story with great gameplay, regrettably, there is little character development and interaction between the various NPC's with the protagonist, Corvo. On contrast, the DLC's, Knife of Dunwall and The Brigmore Witches had, personally, a much better story and we see much of an important NPC who barely appeared for some minutes in the main game and set everything in motion.

reviewText: Dishonored is one of the best games I have played this generation and without a doubt it is one of the most stunning. It has the perfect blend of magic and Victorian industrialism which create a truly breathtaking and unique world. Environments range from elegant imperial palaces to disease ridden sewers. The gameplay is completely up to the player you can take out guards silently from the shadows, loud with magic and guns or without killing a soul. This is a perfect game for fans of the Thief or Deus Ex series.

reviewText:
Amazing Game! Stealth here is done very well! It feels so smooth and badass when you knock someone out or slit their throat (Uh...Hehe)
Pros:
-Awesome Stealth
-Very Smooth
-Awesome maps
-Awesome upgrades/powers
-You get to choice if you want to play Leathal or Non-Leathal
-Awesome FPS (I got like 80-110 in almost everything on ultra settings)
-Exploration on maps
-You can choice how to approach missions
-Different Endings depending on your choices

Cons:
-Lacking Story
-Lacking Characters
-Lacking Enemies
-Short Story
-Graphics are below average

reviewText: Whether you want to go full ghost or full assasin; you can do it in Dishonored! It's one of my favourite games I've ever played. Proper dark and steam-punky, the atmosphere is gorgeously gloomy and filthy. Combine your magical powers with your deadly weapons to kill or slip past unnoticed, following a good story, this game should have all you'd want in a stealth game.

reviewText:
Dishonored is my favorite adventure action FPS game ever. Dishonored is an amazing game with an very good and described storyline. Everything you do in Dishonored have an sometime small change in the story, but can also make a very big change to story. When you play the game through you will feel like Corvo Attano (Main person) as you really was him, not just as games where you dont get that special feeling, you will really get into the game and get a bigger understanding in feelings throughout the story, since the game is based on personal things as Revenge,Saving and Silence, you will have choices that throughout the story, you get many options based on revenge, or be a kind person so all your feelings are in this game wether you choose to be the ultimate sneaking assasin lurking in the shadows of Dunwall, or you want to be the mass murder that is feared in every cornor of the city.

Gameplay: I really like the combat technics thats been designed for the game, like you can shoot the head of a man with an arrow, or drop kill him from above when he less suspects, but I would like it a little more detailed as when you kill somebody the body still seems like he alive I think its a little unrealistic but i can live with it. The storyline in the game is also very good I like how they have made the game change the story a little when you can do some tasks for people and so on. The game is very detailed and have a very big storyline if you do all the sidestorys around when you have the possibility, and throughout all the fighting and talking in Dishonored you do even have books an notes all around the game that tells interesting stories of Dunwall city and if you play the game through you can even find easter eggs of some of the stories written in the books.

Hmm of 1/10 I will give this game a sure 10/10 since the only things that are missing is very small and not necessary, but i would like a Dishonored 2 or something even though it nearly seams inpossible to make a game as good and you can not make a succesor to the storyline that would match.

reviewText:
It is labeled as a stealth game but considering the large arsenal of weapons that you can amass and how you can combine weapons/traps/powers, it's more like an inventive murder simulator. You can, however, go through the entire game without firing a single shot nor murdering anyone, which is neat ( and challenging ). At the end of the day, sneaking around is nowhere near as entertaining as using all of your powers and weapons and even simply using your sword to duel guards is more fun than sneaking.

The plot is quite intriguing but it abuses collectable books to explain it properly which may not be of your liking, considering you want to play a video game and not read a book.
The story progression itself offers a nice sense of replayability and the way your perception of a level changes whether you decide to use stealth or go guns blazing just makes replaying it all the more enticing.

The setting is superb ( seriously, the obsession with whales and the lore are a very interesting read ) and the graphic style is quite pleasing and refreshing, definetely not something you see every day.

The two story-based DLCs improve completely with regards to the level design and some of the mechanics of the game and it explains another side of the main story, definitely worth picking up. The rest of the DLCs are not as great but if you end up loving the game and you want time trials and things like that, it is okay.

That being said, it is not a long game, very replayable if you like it a lot but also very short if you do not. You could probably finish it in about 8 hours or less if you go for the main objectives and ignore exploring the levels and doing all the side quests.

reviewText: This game is brilliant. It leads you into the game and its various skills quite gently, so at no point do you feel like you have to remember what everything does or how to use it (i'm looking at you Witcher 2!!!) and before you know it, you're knocking people off, creeping about an being generally, a damn skillful deviant. Story line is pretty cool, as difficult as you want to make it. An it looks ace. Great steampunk aesthetic goin on... I'm def gonna run (creep) through it again on max difficulty and try not to get noticed his time. i went into it as a bit of a clumsy hack an slasher on my first run through but i sense the game is deeper than that... Worth  the dosh for sure but if it comes up on sale, bang it in the can like pronto cos its a def keeper!
